§ 33.01 DEPARTMENT OF AVIATION AND ITS BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS.
   (A)   Creation of Aviation Department. There shall be a Department of
Aviation for the necessity of acquiring and operating an airport in the county.
   (B)   Membership of Aviation Board of Commissioners.
      (1)   There shall be established an Aviation Board of Commissioners which
shall consist of four members to be appointed by the executive of the city (the
Mayor) and the executive of the county (the County Board of Commissioners).
      (2)   No more than two of the members of the Aviation Board of
Commissioners shall be of the same political party, and the executive of the
city (the Mayor) shall have the right to appoint two members to the Aviation
Board of Commissioners; provided, that each appointment is an individual of a
different political party; and, further, the executive of the county (the
County Board of Commissioners) shall have the right to appoint two members to
the Aviation Board of Commissioners, provided each appointment is an individual
of a different political party.
   (C)   Terms of office.
      (1)   The first members of the Aviation Board of Commissioners hold
office as follows: One for the term of four years which the member shall be
appointed by the executive of the city; one for a term of three years, which
member shall be appointed by the executive of the county; one for the term of
two years, which member shall be appointed by the executive of the county; and
one for the term of one year, which member shall be appointed by the executive
of the city.
      (2)   The first members so appointed shall hold office from 12:00 p.m. on
the first Monday in January of the year of their appointment, which shall be
January 5, 1987. On the expiration of their respective terms, the executive of
the respective entity shall appoint a Commissioner or Commissioners to fill the
vacancy or vacancies caused by the expiration, and the Commissioner or
Commissioners so appointed shall hold office for a term of four years and until
their successors are appointed and qualified. If a vacancy occurs in the
Aviation Board of Commissioners by resignation or otherwise, the executive who
made the appointment shall appoint a Commissioner for the remainder of the term
of the Commissioner vacating his or her appointment.
   (D)   Removal of Commissioners. The executive(s) having the appointment
powers may, at any time, remove a Commissioner from office who the executive
has appointed, but only upon filing in writing with the Clerk-Treasurer of the
fiscal body the reason(s) for the removal.
   (E)   Aviation Board’s powers and duties.
      (1)   The Aviation Board of Commissioners shall have all powers and
duties permitted by the laws of the state, pursuant to I.C. 8-22-2-5, and by
rules and regulations it may create which are consistent with the laws of the
state.
      (2)   In general, the Aviation Board of Commissioners shall abide by the
provisions of I.C. 8-22-2-1 et seq., and amendments thereto.
      (3)   In the event the Board wishes to sell part or the whole of the
aviation land or improvements owned by the eligible entities (the city and the
county), then the Board shall prepare an ordinance authorizing the sale and
submit it to the fiscal body of each entity. Before any part of the aviation
land or improvements are transferred, it will require passage of an ordinance
by both the city and the county, by and through their fiscal bodies. Proceeds
of the sale shall be deposited in the Aviation Fund which shall be managed by
the county which shall be responsible for all required accountings of the funds
with state and federal taxing authorities.
   (F)   Tax levy. The county, by and through its proper authority, shall be
responsible for establishing the appropriate tax levy for the Department of
Aviation, acting by its Aviation Board of Commissioners. All appropriations for
the Department of Aviation and/or the Aviation Board of Commissioners shall be
handled by the County Council.
   (G)   Bond issues. In the event the need arises to sell bonds for the
purpose of providing for payment of the cost of construction, extensions,
additions or improvements to the aviation land, or for any reason permitted by
laws of the state, the County Council shall be the fiscal body which is
authorized to issue and sell the bonds pursuant to I.C. 8-22-2-18.
(Prior Code, § 30.015) (Ord. 19-1986, passed 12-23-1986)
§ 33.02 BOARD OF PUBLIC WORKS AND SAFETY.
   (A)   Chief administrative body; departments under control of Board. The
Board of Public Works and Safety shall be the chief administrative body of the
city and have control of the day-to-day operations of the Police Department,
Fire Department, Street and Sanitation Departments and the Utilities
Department.
   (B)   Three-member Board.
      (1)   The members of the Board of Public Works and Safety shall be the
Mayor and two persons who have been voters of the city for at least one year
immediately preceding the appointment.
      (2)   These two persons shall be appointed by the Mayor and shall serve
at the pleasure of the Mayor, subject to I.C. 36-4-11-2.
   (C)   Mayoral appointments of department heads. The Mayor shall appoint the
Chiefs of the Police and Fire Departments, the heads of the Street and
Sanitation and Utilities Departments, subject to approval by the Board of
Public Works and Safety. The appointees serve at the pleasure of the Mayor,
subject to I.C. 36-4-11-2.
   (D)   Clerk of the Board. The Clerk-Treasurer shall serve as Clerk of the
Board of Public Works and Safety without additional compensation.
   (E)   Board meetings. The Board of Public Works and Safety shall make rules
governing the time and place for holding regular meetings and the procedure to
be used for calling and giving notice thereof.
   (F)   Powers of the Board. The Board of Public Works and Safety shall have
any and all powers given to it by ordinance and as set forth in the applicable
state code provisions.
(Prior Code, § 30.016)
§ 33.03 LEGAL DEPARTMENT.
   (A)   Department of Law. The Department of Law shall be headed by the City
Attorney who shall be appointed by and serve at the pleasure of the Mayor
pursuant to I.C. 36-4-9-11.
   (B)   The powers of the City Attorney. The City Attorney shall have the
powers and duties as specified in I.C. 36-4-9-12.
   (C)   Role of City Attorney. The City Attorney shall advise and represent
the city, its officers, departments, boards, commissions and agencies in all
legal matters involving them. The officers, departments, boards, commissions
and agencies shall not employ or retain other attorneys without the written
authorization of the City Attorney.
(Prior Code, § 30.017)
§ 33.04 CITY PLAN COMMISSION.
   (A)   Seven-member City Plan Commission. The City Plan Commission shall
consist of seven members and shall be appointed as follows.
      (1)   The municipal legislative body (The Common Council of the city)
shall appoint three persons, who must be elected or appointed municipal
officials or employees in the municipal government, as members.
      (2)   The municipal executive (the Mayor) shall appoint four citizen
members, of whom no more than two may be of the same political party.
      (3)   Upon the establishment of a seven-member City Plan Commission, two
citizen members shall initially be appointed for a term of three years and two
shall be appointed for a term of four years. Each member’s term expires on the
first Monday of January of the second, third or fourth year, respectively,
after the year of the member’s appointment. Appointments by the municipal
legislative body are for one year. All members are eligible for reappointment.
   (B)   Powers and duties. The members of the City Plan Commission shall have
all powers and duties as prescribed by I.C. 36-7-4-100 et seq.
   (C)   Commission’s role to the Common Council. The City Plan Commission
shall act in an advisory capacity and shall make recommendations to the Common
Council on all zoning ordinances prior to the Common Council taking final
action on the zoning ordinance.
(Prior Code, § 30.018) (Ord. 1-1986, passed 1-14-1986)
§ 33.05 BOARD OF ZONING APPEALS.
   (A)   Advisory Board of Zoning Appeals. The Board of Zoning Appeals shall
operate, pursuant to I.C. 36-7-4-901 et seq., and shall be known as the
Advisory Board of Zoning Appeals.
   (B)   Five-member Board. The Advisory Board of Zoning Appeals shall consist
of five members, and the appointment of members shall be as follows.
      (1)   Three citizen members shall be appointed by the executive of the
municipality (the Mayor), of whom one shall be a member of the City Plan
Commission and two shall not be members of the City Plan Commission. One member
shall be appointed by the municipal legislative body (Common Council of the
city), who must not be a member of the City Plan Commission. One citizen member
shall be appointed by the City Plan Commission, who must be a member of the
City Plan Commission other than the member appointed under division (B)(2)
below.
      (2)   Each appointment shall be for a term of four years. A member shall
serve until his or her successor is appointed and a member is eligible for
reappointment.
(Prior Code, § 30.019) (Ord. 1-1986, passed 1-14-1986)
§ 33.06 TREE BOARD.
   (A)   Creation and establishment of a five-member Tree Board. There is
created and established a City Tree Board under the direction of the Common
Council for the city which shall consist of five members, citizens and
residents of this city, three of whom shall be appointed by the Mayor with the
approval of the Common Council. The City Street Department Commissioner, and a
member of the Common Council shall be the remaining two members of the Tree
Board. Any application for permit or approval from the Tree Board shall be
directed to the office of the City Clerk-Treasurer.
   (B)   Term of office of Tree Board members. The term of the three persons to
be appointed by the Mayor shall be three years except that the term of one of
the members appointed to the first board shall be for only one year and the
term of one member of the first board shall be for two years. In the event that
a vacancy shall occur during the term of any member, his or her successor shall
be appointed by the Mayor for the unexpired portion of the term.
   (C)   No compensation for Board members. Members of the Board shall serve
without compensation.
   (D)   Duties and responsibilities of City Tree Board.
      (1)   It shall be the responsibility of the City Tree Board to study,
investigate, counsel and develop, and/or update and administer a written plan
for the care, preservation, pruning, planting, replanting, removal or
disposition of trees and shrubs along streets and in other public areas. This
plan will include ways to disseminate information for the continuation of
community education concerning tree care. A plan will be presented to the
Common Council and upon its acceptance and approval shall constitute the
official comprehensive city tree plan for the city. The plan may be updated
periodically, and the updated plan will be affective upon approval by the
Common Council.
      (2)   The City Tree Board shall serve as an advisory council to the City
Parks and Recreation Board concerning the care, preservation, pruning,
planting, replanting, removal or disposition of all park trees. However,
authority and control over park trees shall remain with the City Parks and
Recreation Board.
      (3)   The City Tree Board, when requested by the Common Council, shall
consider, investigate, make finding, report and recommend upon any special
matter or question coming within the scope of its work.
      (4)   The Common Council will be responsible for reviewing, approving and
establishing fee schedules for all permits issued by the City Tree Board.
   (E)   Operation and regulations of City Tree Board.
      (1)   The City Tree Board shall choose its own officers, make its own
rules and regulations and keep minutes of its proceedings which will form
permanent records on file in the City Clerk-Treasurer’s office.
      (2)   A majority of the members shall be a quorum for the transaction of
business.
(Prior Code, § 30.020) (Ord. 19-1997, passed 10-28-1997)
§ 33.07 REDEVELOPMENT COMMISSION AND DEPARTMENT.
   (A)   Department of Redevelopment. The City Department of Redevelopment is
controlled and administered by a Redevelopment Commission.
   (B)   Redevelopment Commission. The Redevelopment Commission shall consist
of five members, three of whom shall be appointed by the Mayor and appointed by
the Common Council.
      (1)   Terms of Commissioners. Each Commissioner shall serve for one year
from January 1 after his or her appointment and until his or her successor is
appointed and qualified.
      (2)   Powers of the Redevelopment Commission. The Redevelopment
Commission shall exercise the powers and duties granted it by I.C. 36-7-14.
   (C)   Redevelopment Authority. For the purpose of providing its citizens a
maximum opportunity for rehabilitation, redevelopment or economic development
of areas within the city, the Common Council establishes a Redevelopment
Authority.
(Prior Code, § 30.021) (Ord. 15-2013, passed 10-9-2013)
§ 33.08 ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT COMMISSION.
   (A)   The Common Council, pursuant to I.C. 36-7-11.9 and 36-7-12 (the Act),
establishes the Department of Economic Development and the Economic Development
Commission to meet the needs existing for the financing of economic development
and pollution control facilities in and near the city.
   (B)   The Department, controlled by the Commission, is granted all the
powers and duties of such Department and such Commission as set forth in the
Act.
   (C)   The Common Council shall nominate members of the Commission.
(Ord. 18-2007, passed 11-13-2007)
§ 33.09 PARK ENTITIES.
   (A)   Department of Parks and Recreation. The City Department of Parks and
Recreation shall have administrative and management jurisdiction over Forest
Park and Hendrix Street Park. The Department shall consist of a Parks and
Recreation Board, a Park Superintendent and other personnel that the Board
deems necessary.
   (B)   Parks and Recreation Board. The Parks and Recreation Board shall
consist of four members appointed by the Mayor with no more than two being
affiliated with the same political party.
   (C)   Park Board terms of office. The terms of office and the filling of
vacancies shall be according to applicable state statutes.
   (D)   Park Board powers and duties. The powers and duties of the members of
the Parks and Recreation Board and the Park Superintendent shall be pursuant to
I.C. 36-10-3-1 through 36-10-3-14 and other applicable provisions of this code.
   (E)   Municipal Golf Course Board.
      (1)   The Municipal Golf Course Board shall have the power to govern,
control, supervise and operate the municipal golf course.
      (2)   The Municipal Golf Course Board shall consist of five members
appointed by the Mayor.
      (3)   The terms of office of Board members and the filling of vacancies
shall be according to the powers set forth in Ch. 95 and 96.
(Prior Code, § 30.023) (Ord. 4-2019, passed 1-9-2019)
§ 33.10 HOUSING AUTHORITY.
   (A)   City Housing Authority. The City Housing Authority shall exist
pursuant to I.C. 36-7-18 and shall be administered by five Commissioners
appointed by the Mayor.
   (B)   Terms of office. The terms of office of the Commissioners shall be
governed by I.C. 36-7-18-7 and may be removed from office pursuant to I.C. 36-
7-18-9.
   (C)   Purpose of Housing Authority. The purpose of the Housing Authority is
the clearance, re-planning and reconstruction of areas in which unsanitary or
unsafe housing conditions exist and the providing of safe and sanitary dwelling
accommodations for persons of low income.
(Prior Code, § 30.024)
§ 33.11 POLICE AND FIRE ENTITIES AND POLICIES.
   (A)   Police Pension Board. The Police Pension Board of Trustees shall be
elected and perform certain duties with respect to statutory pension funds for
the city’s police officers pursuant to I.C. 36-8-6 and 36-8-8.
   (B)   Fire Pension Board. The Firefighters’ Pension Board of Trustees shall
be elected and perform certain duties with respect to statutory pension funds
for the city’s firefighters pursuant to I.C. 36-8-7 and 36-8-8.
   (C)   Police reserve unit.
      (1)   The city may establish a police reserve unit.
      (2)   The police reserve unit shall consist of not more than __ persons.
      (3)   Members of the police reserve unit shall be appointed by the same
authority which appoints regular members of the City Police Department.
      (4)   Any person appointed to the police reserve unit may not be a member
of the regular Police Department but shall have all of the police powers of the
regular members, except as limited by the rules and regulations of the
Department and state law.
      (5)   Persons serving as police reserves are not eligible to participate
in any pension program provided for regular members of the Department.
      (6)   The authority appointing the persons to the reserve unit shall
establish rules, regulations and minimum training requirements which shall
govern the police reserve unit.
   (D)   Physical fitness policies for all permanent employees of the City
Police and Fire Departments.
      (1)   (a)   All permanent employees of the City Police and Fire
Departments shall take physical examinations at least once per year at the cost
of the Department.
         (b)   The Police or Fire Chief shall have the discretion to order any
police officer or firefighter to take a physical examination at Department cost
if the Police Chief or Fire Chief has reason to believe that the employee needs
to be medically examined in order to carry out the duties of that employee.
         (c)   If an employee refuses or fails to obey the request of the
Police Chief or Fire Chief to undertake a physical examination at Department
cost, then failure to obey shall be deemed to be a violation of work rules and
policy, a knowing violation of a reasonable and uniformly enforced rule of the
employer, conduct endangering the safety of self and others, refusing to obey
instructions or breach of duty in connection with work which is reasonably owed
employer by an employee.
         (d)   The Police Chief and/or Fire Chief shall not discriminate in
carrying out the powers created through the employment policy set forth above.
In the event the employee fails to obey the reasonable request to take a
physical examination, then the Police Chief and/or Fire Chief shall, in
writing, inform the City Board of Public Works of this refusal and may take
disciplinary action against the employee pursuant to applicable law and due
process.
      (2)   The Chief of the Police Department and/or Fire Department shall
establish a physical agility test that does not discriminate on the basis of
sex, and physical agility testing shall, at a minimum, include testing for:
         (a)   Fear of heights (acrophobia);
         (b)   Fear of confinement (claustrophobia);
         (c)   Muscular strength;
         (d)   Muscular endurance;
         (e)   Cardiovascular endurance; and
         (f)   Musculoskeletal flexibility.
      (3)   The Chief of the respective department also may adopt standards
establishing a written aptitude test, however, all tests shall be administered
in a non-discriminatory manner and with prior written notice to the employees.
      (4)   (a)   The Police Chief and/or Fire Chief shall be authorized to
hire trained instructors for the limited purpose of the aforementioned testing,
however all physical agility tests, written aptitude tests and the temporary
hiring of trained instructors shall be approved by the Board of Public Works
and Safety prior to the administration of testing and hiring.
         (b)   In the event the Police Chief and/or Fire Chief determines that
the employee does not take or pass the physical agility test or written
aptitude test, then the Chief shall immediately, in writing, report the facts
to the City Board of Public Works and Safety which shall subsequently conduct a
hearing on the issue; provided, that applicable law relative to due process and
discipline of Fire Department and Police Department employees are followed.
      (5)   The Police Chief and Fire Chief shall be authorized to establish
any other testing relative to physical fitness or agility of the employee;
provided, that it is administered in a non-discriminatory manner and that other
tests are first approved by the City Board of Public Works and Safety.
   (E)   Salaries of police officers and firefighters. The Common Council shall
establish, by proper ordinance, the annual compensation of members of the
Police and Fire Departments pursuant to I.C. 36-8-3-3.
(Prior Code, § 30.025) (Res. 2-1989, passed 6-13-1989)
§ 33.12 CITY PLANNING AND BUILDING ENTITIES.
   (A)   City Planning and Building Administrator office.
      (1)   The office of the City Planning and Building Administrator shall be
headed and administered by the City Planning and Building Administrator, who
shall be appointed by the Mayor, be subject to removal by the Mayor and shall
work under the supervision of the Mayor.
      (2)   The Mayor may appoint two persons to head and administer the office
of the City Planning and Building Administrator, one being designated as the
City Planning Administrator and one being designated as the City Building
Administrator.
      (3)   As Building Administrator, the person so appointed shall be
responsible for enforcement of the provisions of Title XV and shall have the
authority to enter on private property in any reasonable exercise of his or her
duties to enforce that title.
      (4)   As Planning Administrator, the person appointed shall perform those
duties as prescribed, in Ch. 155 and the duties as prescribed in §
155.021 providing for improvement location permits.
   (B)   Bonds and compensation.
      (1)   The Administrator provided for in this section shall be paid
compensation in a sum set by the Common Council.
      (2)   The city shall provide and furnish the proper forms and supplies
necessary for the Administrator to perform the required duties.
      (3)   The Administrator so appointed shall post an official’s bond in the
amount of $1,000, the premium of which shall be paid by the city.
(Prior Code, § 30.026) (Ord. 14-1982, passed 8-30-1982; Ord. 23-1982, passed
11-22-1982; Ord. 34-1983, passed 10-24-1983)
CHAPTER 34: CITY COURT

§ 34.01 CITY COURT ESTABLISHED.
   The judicial branch of the city shall be composed of a City Court headed by
a judge of the City Court elected pursuant to I.C. 3-8-1-28.5.
(Prior Code, § 33.01)
§ 34.02 JURISDICTION OF CITY COURT.
   There is created a City Court, pursuant to I.C. 33-35, which shall have
criminal jurisdiction of all violations of ordinances of the city and of all
misdemeanors and infractions and civil jurisdiction in all civil cases where
the amount in controversy does not exceed the statutory limit, with the
exceptions of actions for slander, libel, mortgage foreclosure, where the title
to real estate is in issue, matters relating to a decedent’s estate,
appointment of guardians and all related matters and actions in equity.
(Prior Code, § 33.02)
§ 34.03 ELECTION OF CITY JUDGE.
   (A)   The Judge of the City Court shall be elected in the general election
pursuant to I.C. 33-35- 1-1.
   (B)   The Judge shall take office and operate the City Court on January 1
following election.
(Prior Code, § 33.03)
§ 34.04 CITY COURT OPERATIONS.
   All other matters relating to the operation of the City Court shall be
performed pursuant to I.C. 33-35.
(Prior Code, § 33.04) (Ord. 14-1982, passed 8-30-1982)
§ 34.05 SALARY OF THE CITY JUDGE.
   The salary of the City Judge shall be determined by the Common Council in a
like manner as other elected officials.
(Prior Code, § 33.05)
§ 34.06 POWERS OF THE CITY COURT.
   The City Court shall have all powers provided by applicable state law.
(Prior Code, § 33.06)

GENERAL PROVISIONS; CITY FUNDS
§ 35.001 CITY CLERK-TREASURER AS FISCAL OFFICER.
   (A)   Fiscal officer.
      (1)   The Fiscal Branch shall be composed of the City Clerk-Treasurer as
the fiscal officer of the city and head of that branch.
      (2)   The Clerk-Treasurer shall perform his or her duties pursuant to
I.C. 36-4-10-5 and any other duties as the Common Council may, by ordinance,
require.
      (3)   The Clerk-Treasurer may appoint one Deputy Clerk-Treasurer who
shall be paid solely from funds appropriated for the office of Clerk-Treasurer.
      (4)   The Deputy Clerk-Treasurer shall work under the exclusive direction
of the Clerk-Treasurer and shall serve at the pleasure of the Clerk-Treasurer.
(Prior Code, § 30.100)
   (B)   Compensation for services to city utilities by Clerk-Treasurer. The
Clerk-Treasurer shall be compensated for services rendered by him or her to the
various city utilities.
(Prior Code, § 30.101)
(Ord. 14-1982, passed 8-30-1982)
§ 35.002 BOARD OF FINANCE.
   (A)   The Board of Finance of the city is designated and created pursuant to
I.C. 5-13-7.
   (B)   The Board is to meet biennially for the purpose of designating
depositories for the depositing of public funds.
   (C)   The Board is to receive proposals from certain banks and trust
companies for the purpose of being designated and depository for the purpose of
receiving public funds.
   (D)   The Board shall have supervision of all public funds of its city and
the safekeeping and deposit thereof in accordance with the applicable laws of
the state.
   (E)   The Board shall require the City Clerk-Treasurer to deposit and
maintain the balance in each designated depository in proportion to the total
resources of each depository as it bears to the total resources of all
depositories so designated for receiving public funds.
(Prior Code, § 30.102)
§ 35.003 BUDGET, TAX LEVIES AND TAX RATES.
   The city is governed by I.C. 6-1.1-17-1 et seq., addressing procedures for
fixing and reviewing budgets, tax rates and tax levies.
(Prior Code, § 30.103)
§ 35.004 COUNCIL ACTION REQUIRED TO BORROW MONEY, TRANSFER FUNDS; REVENUE FROM
TAXES; APPROPRIATIONS.
   (A)   Ordinance required to borrow money; revenue from taxes.
      (1)   The city is permitted to borrow money in anticipation of current
revenue from taxes in order to meet immediate cash needs pursuant to I.C. 36-4-
6-20.
      (2)   Temporary loans are evidenced by time warrants, using as collateral
receipts from property taxes yet to be collected.
      (3)   The City Common Council is authorized to make temporary loans only
by the passage of a proper ordinance.
(Prior Code, § 30.104)
   (B)   Ordinance required to appropriate additional funds. An ordinance
passed by the Common Council and notice to the public is required when
appropriating additional funds in excess of a budgetary item and reducing
appropriations.
(Prior Code, § 30.105)
   (C)   Resolution required to transfer funds. Pursuant to I.C. 36-7-9-14, the
city may transfer funds from one fund to another by the adoption of a proper
resolution by the Common Council.
(Prior Code, § 30.106)
§ 35.005 CREATION OF POLICE BICYCLE PATROLS DONATIONS FUND.
   (A)   There is created a new restricted donations fund which shall be
designated as the “Police Bicycle Patrols Donations Fund.”
   (B)   The sole purpose of the fund is to allow the Police Department to
receive monetary donations from the community and individuals, deposit
contributions into the Police Bicycle Patrols Donations Fund and disburse
monies therefrom to establish, initiate and promote police bicycle patrols for
the citizens of the city, to purchase items needed for police bicycle patrols,
such as bicycles, bicycle helmets, uniforms, equipment, parts, to provide
training and all other necessary expenses to operate, maintain and promote the
bicycle patrol unit of the City Police Department.
   (C)   The Fund shall be perpetual until terminated pursuant to the terms of
this subchapter.
   (D)   This Fund may be terminated by the enactment of an ordinance and any
fund balance in that fund shall revert back to the Police Department’s General
Fund to be used for any purposes lawfully allowed.
(Prior Code, § 30.107) (Ord. 13-1998, passed 8-25-1998)
§ 35.006 CREATION OF TRAFFIC SAFETY FUND.
   (A)   There is created a new fund as a part of the Police Department’s
General Fund which shall be designated as the Traffic Safety Fund.
   (B)   The purpose of the fund is to allow the Police Department to receive
monetary donations from the community and individuals, deposit contributions
into the Traffic Safety Fund and disburse monies therefrom to establish,
initiate and promote traffic safety and bicycle safety programs for the
citizens and youth of the city and the county, to purchase child safety
devices, such as child safety seats, bicycle helmets and the like.
   (C)   The Fund shall be perpetual until terminated pursuant to the terms of
this subchapter.
   (D)   This Fund may be terminated by the enactment of an ordinance and any
fund balance in that fund shall revert back to the Police Department’s General
Fund to be used for any purposes lawfully allowed.
(Prior Code, § 30.108) (Ord. 6-1997, passed 5-13-1997)

§ 35.010 AUTHORIZATION TO ACCEPT ACH PAYMENTS AT THE AUTHORIZATION OF THE
REQUESTING UTILITY CUSTOMER IN THE CONDUCT OF MONETARY TRANSACTIONS.
   (A)   The Clerk-Treasurer is authorized to establish accounts at, enter into
agreements with and pay fees to First Financial Bank Corporation in the city
(home office: Terre Haute, Indiana) for the purpose of enabling city utilities
to accept ACH payments in the conduct of monetary transactions.
   (B)   ACH payments may only be credited to the customer’s account on the
eighth of each month. If the eighth day should fall on a Saturday or Sunday,
the credit will be applied to the respective utility customer account on the
following Monday.
   (C)   Utility customers must complete and sign, in person, an automatic
payment withdrawal contract and voided check (as prescribed in Exhibit A of
Ordinance 31-2006).
   (D)   In the event that ACH payment results in a non-sufficient fund
transaction, a $15 NSF fee will be applied to the account plus any and all
penalties. If the ACH payment results in three or more non-sufficient fund
transactions within a 12-month calendar year, the utility customer shall lose
all privileges of the ACH payment service offered by the city utilities.
   (E)   (1)   Utility customers shall have the right to withdraw their request
temporarily, not to exceed twice in a 12-month calendar year; however, this
limitation shall not apply to customers who request to temporary withdraw do to
an erroneously large payment, and when the customer has or is expected to apply
for an adjustment.
      (2)   The customer must complete and sign, in person, the necessary form
as prescribed in Exhibit B of Ordinance 31-2006. All requests must be completed
at least one week prior to the scheduled ACH payment, as described in division
(B) above.
   (F)   Utility customers shall have the right to permanently withdraw their
request on completion of the form as prescribed in Exhibit C of Ordinance 31-
2006. All requests must be completed at least one week prior to the scheduled
ACH payment, as described in division (B) above.
   (G)   The city shall not be held liable for any charges incurred by the
utility customer by their financial institution.
   (H)   The user fee is established in the amount of $0.25 per month per
transaction, the fee to be collected and retained by the city for each monetary
transaction paid in part or in whole through the use of an ACH payment.
(Prior Code, § 30.112) (Ord. 31-2006, passed 11-14-2006)
PURCHASING POLICIES
§ 35.025 PURPOSE.
   (A)   I.C. 5-22 applies to every expenditure of public funds by a
governmental body.
   (B)   The city is a governmental body under I.C. 5-22.
   (C)   I.C. 5-22 requires the city to establish purchasing rules and policies
for the city.
(Prior Code, § 30.060) (Ord. 5-1998, passed 7-14-1998)
§ 35.026 PURCHASE OF SUPPLIES MANUFACTURED IN THE UNITED STATES.
   Supplies manufactured in the United States shall be specified for all city
purchases and shall be purchased unless the city determines that:
   (A)   The supplies are not manufactured in the United States in reasonably
available quantities;
   (B)   The prices of the supplies manufactured in the United States exceeds
by an unreasonable amount the price of available and comparable supplies
manufactured elsewhere;
   (C)   The quality of the supplies manufactured in the United States is
substantially less than the quality of comparably priced available supplies
manufactured elsewhere; and
   (D)   The purchase of supplies manufactured in the United States is not in
the public interest.
(Prior Code, § 30.061) (Ord. 5-1998, passed 7-14-1998)
§ 35.027 PROTECTION OF OFFERS AND STATUS OF DOCUMENTS AS PUBLIC RECORDS.
   (A)   Protection of offers prior to opening. The purchasing agent shall
retain all offers received in a secure location prior to the date and time at
which offers will be opened in order to prevent disclosure of the contents
prior to the opening of the offers.
   (B)   Unobstructed evaluation of offers. After offers have been opened, the
purchasing agent shall be responsible for maintaining the offers in a manner so
as to permit evaluation of the offers by the persons responsible for evaluating
the offers.
   (C)   Public records status of bids. Bids submitted in response to an
invitation for bids must be available for public inspection and copying after
the time of the bid opening.
   (D)   Register of proposals. The purchasing agent shall prepare a register
of proposals for each request for proposals issued which shall contain
information concerning the proposals available for public inspection and
copying. Proposals may not be disclosed.
(Prior Code, § 30.062) (Ord. 6-1998, passed 7-14-1998)
§ 35.028 DISCUSSIONS WITH OFFERORS RESPONDING TO A REQUEST FOR PROPOSALS.
   The purchasing agent may conduct discussions with, and best and final offers
may be obtained from responsible offerors who submit proposals determined to be
reasonably susceptible of being selected for a contract award.
(Prior Code, § 30.063) (Ord. 6-1998, passed 7-14-1998)
§ 35.029 DELAY OF OPENING OF OFFERS.
   When the Common Council makes a written determination that it is in the
city’s best interests, offers may be opened after the time stated in the
solicitation. The date, time and place of the rescheduled opening must be
announced at the time and place of the originally scheduled opening.
(Prior Code, § 30.064) (Ord. 6-1998, passed 7-14-1998)
§ 35.030 EVIDENCE OF FINANCIAL RESPONSIBILITY.
   (A)   Purchases less than $25,000. The purchasing agent may not require
evidence of financial responsibility when the estimated cost of a purchase is
less than $25,000.
   (B)   Purchases between $25,000 and $75,000. The solicitation may include a
requirement that an offeror provide evidence of financial responsibility. If
evidence of financial responsibility is required, the solicitation must
indicate the kind of evidence that will be acceptable. If a bond or certified
check is required, it may not exceed 10% of the estimated cost of the purchase.
   (C)   Purchases over $75,000. The solicitation shall include a requirement
that an offeror provide evidence of financial responsibility and must indicate
the kind of evidence that will be acceptable. If a bond or certified check is
required, it may not exceed 10% of the estimated cost of the purchase.
   (D)   Small business set-asides. The purchasing agent may determine that no
evidence of financial responsibility shall be required for a small business
set-aside purchase.
(Prior Code, § 30.065) (Ord. 6-1998, passed 7-14-1998)
§ 35.031 USE OF REQUESTS FOR PROPOSALS FOR PURCHASE OF DESIGNATED TYPES OF
SUPPLIES.
   The Common Council determines that:
   (A)   It is either not practicable or not advantageous to purchase certain
types of supplies by sealed competitive bidding; and
   (B)   Receiving proposals is the preferred method for purchasing the
following types of supplies: Equipment, goods and materials costing less than
$25,000.
(Prior Code, § 30.066) (Ord. 6-1998, passed 7-14-1998)
§ 35.032 MODIFICATION AND TERMINATION OF CONTRACTS.
   (A)   Price adjustments. The purchasing agent may include provisions to
permit price adjustments in a purchase contract. The following provisions for
price adjustments may be included:
      (1)   Price adjustments must be computed by agreement on a fixed price
adjustment before the beginning of the pertinent performance or as soon after
the beginning of performance as possible;
      (2)   Price adjustments must be computed by unit prices specified in the
contract or subsequently agreed upon;
      (3)   Price adjustments must be computed by costs attributable to the
events or situations under clauses with adjustment of profit or fee, all as
specified in the contract or subsequently agreed upon;
      (4)   Price adjustments must be computed in any other manner as the
contracting parties may mutually agree upon; or
      (5)   In the absence of agreement by the parties, price adjustments must
be computed by a unilateral determination by the governmental body of the costs
attributable to the events or situations under clauses with adjustment of
profit or fee, all as computed by the governmental body in accordance with
applicable rules adopted by the governmental body.
   (B)   Adjustments in time of performance. The purchasing agent may include
provisions in a purchase contract concerning adjustments for time of
performance under the contract.
   (C)   Unilateral rights of supplier. The purchasing agent may include in a
purchase contract provisions dealing with the unilateral right of the supplier
to order changes in the work within the scope of the contract or to order
temporary work stoppage or delays in time of performance.
   (D)   Quantity variations. The purchasing agent may include in a purchase
contract provisions dealing with variations between the estimated quantities of
work in a contract and the actual quantity delivered.
(Prior Code, § 30.067) (Ord. 6-1998, passed 7-14-1998)
§ 35.033 PURCHASE OF SERVICES.
   (A)   The Common Council determines that each city agency and department may
purchase services, except for the services of attorneys, in whatever manner the
purchaser determines to be reasonable. Only the Head of the Department of Law
may purchase the services of an attorney.
   (B)   The city purchasing agent may not require any city agency, department
or office to purchase services in any particular manner.
(Prior Code, § 30.068) (Ord. 6-1998, passed 7-14-1998)

(Prior Code, § 30.069) (Ord. 7-1998, passed 7-14-1998)

(Prior Code, § 30.070) (Ord. 7-1998, passed 7-14-1998)
§ 35.036 PURCHASING AGENCY POWERS AND DUTIES.
   (A)   The Purchasing Agency shall have all the powers and duties authorized

by the Common Council and policies adopted by the Purchasing Agency.
   (B)   The Purchasing Agency shall act as the Purchasing Agency for every

   (C)   The Purchasing Agency may designate, in writing, any employee of the

(Prior Code, § 30.071) (Ord. 7-1998, passed 7-14-1998)
§ 35.037 APPLICATION AND USE OF CREDIT CARDS BY OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES.
   (A)   This section is adopted in compliance with the State Board of Accounts
Accounting and Uniform Compliance Guidelines Manual for Cities and Towns, Ch.
7, authorizing a city to use credit cards for purchases.
   (B)   City employees and elected officials may use city credit cards for
purchases related to the performance of city duties when such use is in the
best interest of the city.
   (C)   (1)   The Board of Public Works and Safety (Board of Works) shall
determine which elected officials and employees shall receive credit cards. A
list of all existing credit cards shall be provided to the Board of Works at
its next scheduled meeting following the adoption of this section for approval.
      (2)   Each time a new credit card is to be issued to an employee or
elected official it shall be approved by the Board of Works. A compilation of
all approved credit cards, including name, card number and date of approval,
will be maintained by the Clerk-Treasurer’s office.
   (D)   The Clerk-Treasurer is authorized to make application for and obtain
credit cards for use by city elected officials and employees upon request of
city elected official or department head. All credit card applications shall be
signed by the Mayor and the Clerk-Treasurer.
   (E)   Any credit cards shall have a maximum limit of $15,000.
   (F)   (1)   The Clerk-Treasurer, or his or her designee, shall be
responsible for safekeeping of the credit cards for all departments except the
Utilities Department and the Police Department, including, but not limited to,
Clerk-Treasurer’s office, Sanitation, Cemetery, MVH, Planning and Zoning and
Mayor’s office.
      (2)   The utilities office manager, or his or her designee, shall be
responsible for safekeeping of the credit cards for the Utilities Department,
including, but not limited to, Water, Water Treatment and Wastewater.
      (3)   The Chief of Police, or his or her designee, shall be responsible
for safekeeping of the credit cards issued to the Police Department.
   (G)   City credit cards shall only be used by city employees with the
approval of the department head, or his or her designee. The department head
shall maintain a usage log for each card identified by card account number,
with entries certified by signature of the department head or his or her
designee. The log shall include the following information:
      (1)   The name and position of the individual using the city’s card;
      (2)   Upon issuance: The date the card is issued to the individual, the
estimated amounts to be charged, the type of expenses and the fund and account
numbers to be charged; and
      (3)   Upon return: The date the card is returned and the amount charged
to the card.
   (H)   When the employee is finished using the card, it shall be returned to
the custody of the appropriate custodian of the card, as set forth in division
(F) above, for safekeeping.
   (I)   City credit cards shall be used for purchases relating to the
performance of city business only and which are within the approved budget of
the city. No personal use of a city credit card is allowed, even if an elected
official or employee offers to reimburse the city for the elected official or
employee’s personal use of a city credit card.
   (J)   Within 72 hours of the purchase, the person using the credit card
shall provide a copy of the itemized receipt for the credit card purchase along
with copy of bill paid (if applicable) to the department head, and, also within
72 hours of the purchase, the department head shall, in turn, promptly submit
said documents to the Clerk-Treasurer and at that time inform the Clerk-
Treasurer in writing of the following:
      (1)   The purpose of the purchase;
      (2)   The budget line item from which the purchase is to be paid (if
applicable); and
      (3)   An itemized list of all charges incurred and whether those are paid
from different budget line items.
   (K)   Payment of credit card bills shall be subject to the audit
requirements of accounts payable vouchers in conformity with I.C. 5-11-10 and
36-4-8 and the regulations of the State Board of Accounts. Itemized receipts
are required for all credit card purchases, including restaurant charges.
Payment will not be made on the basis of a credit card statement. Signed charge
slips showing a total charge only, with no itemization of items purchased, are
not acceptable. It is the responsibility of the city elected official or
employee authorizing the charge to obtain proper itemized charges.
   (L)   Credit card charges that do not meet audit requirements, including
charges that include the imposition of sales taxes for which the city is
otherwise exempt, are the responsibility of the city elected official or
employee authorizing the charge. The city will take all necessary steps to
obtain reimbursement for charges which do not meet audit requirements from the
city elected official or employee authorizing the charge.
   (M)   The payment of an annual fee on any credit cards is not authorized.
   (N)   Any interest or penalty incurred due to late filing with the Clerk-
Treasurer of an accounts payable voucher for payment of a credit card bill, or
incurred due to delay in furnishing of documentation required for audit by an
elected official or employee, shall be the responsibility of the elected
official or employee.
   (O)   The Clerk-Treasurer shall be notified immediately if a credit card is
lost or stolen. If a credit card is lost due to negligence on the part of an
elected official or employee, the elected official or employee shall be
responsible for any and all expenses incurred on the lost credit card.
   (P)   The Clerk-Treasurer is authorized to revoke credit cards that have
been used in violation of city policy.
(Res. 8-2011, passed 7-13-2011; Res. 5-2019, passed 11-13-2019)
§ 35.038 BILLS AND PAYABLES SUBMITTED TO CLERK-TREASURER.
   (A)   Any purchase or bill which is to be paid by the Clerk-Treasurer on
behalf of the city is to be submitted to the Clerk-Treasurer as soon as
practicable but no later than 72 hours after the city employee or official
receives the bill or payable.
   (B)   Each bill or payable submitted to the Clerk-Treasurer should indicate:
      (1)   The purpose of the purchase/bill;
      (2)   The budget line item from which the purchase is to be paid (if
applicable); and
      (3)   An itemized list of all charges incurred and whether those are paid
from different budget line items.
   (C)   Any bill or payable not turned into the Clerk-Treasurer within the
time frame set forth in division (A) above and for which a late fee, interest,
penalty or other charges is incurred, said charges will be the responsibility
of the city official or employee who does not timely turn in the bill or
payable.
(Res. 21-2011, passed 12-21-2011)
FIXED ASSET CAPITALIZATION POLICY
§ 35.050 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   CAPITAL OUTLAYS. Expenditures which benefits both the current and future
fiscal periods. This includes costs of acquiring land or structures,
construction or improvement of buildings, structures or other fixed assets and
equipment purchased having an appreciable and calculable period of usefulness.
These are expenditures resulting in the acquisition of, or addition to, the
government’s general fixed assets.
   FIXED ASSETS. Tangible assets of a durable nature employed in the operating
activities of the unit that are relatively permanent and are needed for the
production or sale of goods and services and are termed property, plant and
equipment of fixed assets. These assets are not held for sale in the ordinary
course of business. This broad group is usually separated into classes
according to the physical characteristics of the physical characteristics of
the items (e.g., land, infrastructure, buildings, improvements other than
buildings, machinery and equipment and construction in progress).
   HISTORICAL COST. The cash equivalent price exchanged for goods and services
at the examples of items recognized under the historical cost attribute.
   IMPROVEMENTS OTHER THAN BUILDINGS.
      (1)   Improvements to land for better enjoyment, attached or not easily
removed, and having a life expectancy of greater than two years. Examples are
walks, parking areas and drives, golf cart paths, fencing, retaining walls,
pools, outside fountains, planters, underground sprinkler systems and other
similar items.
      (2)   IMPROVEMENTS do not include roads, street or assets that are of
value only to the public. For example, Main Street is a public street with
greatest value to the public. Roads or drives upon city-owned land that provide
support to the city’s facilities are assets.
      (3)   A sidewalk down the road for public enjoyment is an infrastructure
improvement and is not capitalized. However, sidewalks installed upon city-
owned land for use by the public and for the support of the city’s facility are
capital assets.
   INFRASTRUCTURE. The basic facilities, services and installations needed for
the functioning of a community or society, such as transportation and
communication systems and water and power lines. Infrastructure shall include,
but is not limited to, roads, streets, street lighting systems, bridges,
overpasses, sidewalks, curbs, parking meter, street signs, viaducts, wharfs,
storm and sewer water collection systems and drinking water systems.
INFRASTRUCTURE shall not include driveways or parking lots.
   LAND. Specified land, lots, parcels or acreage, including rights-of-way,
owned by the city, its various departments, boards or authorities, regardless
of the method or date of acquisition. Easements will not be included as the
city does not own them, but as an interest in land owned by another (i.e.,
property owner) that entitles its holder to a specified limited use.
   MACHINERY AND EQUIPMENT. An apparatus, tool or conglomeration of pieces to
form a tool. The tool will stand-alone and not become a part of a basic
structure of building. Machinery combined with other machinery to form one unit
with a total value greater than the limit will be one unit.
   TANGIBLE ASSETS. Assets that can be observed by one or more of the physical
senses. This may be seen and touched and, in some environments, heard and
smelled.
(Ord. 6-2017, passed 8-9-2017)
§ 35.051 ASSET CAPITALIZATION.
   (A)   Land.
      (1)   The city will capitalize all land purchases, regardless of cost.
The value of land shall not be depreciated.
      (2)   A department will record donated land at fair market value on the
date of transfer plus any associated costs.
      (3)   Purchases made using federal or state funding will follow the
source funding policies and above procedures.
   (B)   Infrastructure.
      (1)   Additions and improvements to infrastructure, which increase the
capacity or efficiency of the asset, will be capitalized. All infrastructure
installed prior to the passage of this subchapter will be capitalized based on
the estimated historical cost. Maintenance/repairs will be considered as
necessary to maintain the existing asset and therefore not capitalized. For
example, patching resurfacing, snow removal and the like are considered
maintenance activities and will be expended. In addition, normal department
operating activities such as feasibility studies and preliminary engineering
and design will be expended and not capitalized as an element of the
infrastructure asset.
      (2)   Alleys will not be included as part of the infrastructure for the
following reason: Existing improved alleys will be maintained as gravel alleys,
and the city is responsible only for the maintenance, such as patching and
repairing. Any investments to upgrade the alleys will be done by homeowner
participation. Therefore, the city will not track and value alleys and the
patching/repairs will be expensed as they occur.
   (C)   Machinery and equipment.
      (1)   Improvements or renovations to existing machinery and equipment
will be capitalized only if the result of the change meets all of the following
conditions:
         (a)   Total cost exceeds $5,000; and
         (b)   The useful life is extended two or more years.
      (2)   Examples include:
         (a)   A work truck being equipped with screens, lights or radios for
use as a single unit throughout its life expectancy is considered one unit;
         (b)   If police cars are constantly changing light bars or radios to
other vehicles, the city will capitalize each piece of equipment separately, if
it meets the required dollar amount;
         (c)   A department’s computer (CPU, monitor, keyboard and printer) is
considered one unit;
         (d)   A department will record donated machinery and equipment at fair
market value on the date of transfer with any associated costs; and
         (e)   Purchases made using federal or state funding will follow the
source funding policies and above procedures.
   (D)   Buildings.
      (1)   A department will capitalize buildings at full cost with no
subcategories for tracking the cost of attachments. Examples of attachments are
roofs, heating, cooling, plumbing, lighting or sprinkler systems, or any pail
of a basic building.
      (2)   The department will include the cost of items designed or purchased
exclusively for the building.
      (3)   A department’s new building will be capitalized only if it meets
the following conditions:
         (a)   The total cost exceeds $10,000; and
         (b)   The useful life is greater than two years.
      (4)   A department improving or renovating an existing building will
capitalize the cost only if the result meets all of the following conditions:
         (a)   The total cost exceeds $10,000;
         (b)   The useful life extended two or more years; and
         (c)   The total cost will be greater than the current book value and
less than fair market value.
      (5)   Capital building costs may include preparation of land for the
building, architectural and engineering fees, bond issuance fees, interest cost
(while under construction), accounting costs, if material, and costs directly
attributable to the construction of a building.
      (6)   A department will record donated buildings at fair market value on
the date of transfer with any associated costs.
      (7)   Purchases made using federal or state funding will follow the
source funding policies and above procedures.
   (E)   Improvements other than buildings.
      (1)   The city will capitalize new improvements other than buildings only
if it meets the following conditions:
         (a)   The total cost exceeds $10,000; and
         (b)   The useful life is greater than two years.
      (2)   A department will capitalize improvements or renovations to
existing improvements other than buildings only if the result meets the
following conditions:
         (a)   The total cost exceeds $10,000;
         (b)   The asset’s useful life is extended two or more years; and
         (c)   The total cost will be greater than the current book value and
less than fair market value.
      (3)   A department’s donated improvements other than buildings will be
recorded at the fair market value on the date of transfer with any associated
costs.
      (4)   Purchases made using federal or state funding will follow the
source funding policies and above procedures.
(Ord. 6-2017, passed 8-9-2017)
§ 35.052 CAPITAL ASSETS ACQUISITIONS.
   (A)   The method of acquisition is not a determining factor. Each department
should report items acquired by:
      (1)   Regular purchases;
      (2)   Lease purchase (see division (B) below);
      (3)   Construction by city personnel;
      (4)   Construction by an outside contractor;
      (5)   Resolution/condemnation;
      (6)   Donation/contribution;
      (7)   Addition to an existing asset;
      (8)   Transfer from another department;
      (9)   Trade or barter; and
      (10)   Annexation.
   (B)   Leased equipment should be capitalized if the lease equipment meets
any one of the following criteria:
      (1)   The lease transfers ownership of the property to the lessee by the
end of the lease term;
      (2)   The lease contains a bargain purchase option;
      (3)   The lease term is equal to 75% of the estimated economic life of
the leased property; and/or
      (4)   The present value of the minimum lease payment at the inception of
the lease, excluding executory costs, equals at least 90% of the fair value of
the leased property.
   (C)   Leases that do not meet any of the above criteria should be recorded
as an operating lease and reported in the notes of the financial statements.
(Ord. 6-2017, passed 8-9-2017)
§ 35.053 ASSET TRANSFERS AND DISPOSITIONS.
   (A)   Property should not be transferred, turned-in for auction or disposed
of without prior approval of the department head. The disposal of capital asset
section of the capital asset notification form shall be completed and turned in
to the Clerk-Treasurer’s office. This form is a dual purpose form for TRANSFER,
which means any movement of an asset by virtue of change in location, either by
account, department, building, (floor or room) or retirement (disposal) of
property.
   (B)   If an asset is stolen, the department should notify the Human
Resources or Safety Director as well as the City Clerk-Treasurer’s office.
(Ord. 6-2017, passed 8-9-2017)
§ 35.054 PERIODIC INVENTORIES.
   A physical inventory of all capital assets will be conducted in each
department, excluding utilities, on or about December 31, 2005 and biannually
after December 31, 2005 by the Mayor, Clerk-Treasurer or a designee of their
choosing. A physical inventory of all capital assets will be conducted in each
utility department on or about December 31, 2006 and bi-annually after December
31, 2006 by the Mayor, Clerk-Treasurer or a designee of their choosing.
Department heads will be accountable for the capital asset inventory charged to
their departments by verifying a list of their capital assets at year end.
(Ord. 6-2017, passed 8-9-2017)
§ 35.055 ADMINISTRATION.
   (A)   Responsibilities of Clerk-Treasurer’s office. The fiscal officer will
ensure that according for capital assets is being exercised by established a
capital asset inventory, both initially and periodically in subsequent years.
The fiscal officer will further ensure that the capital asset report will be
updated annually to reflect additions, retirements and transfers and to reflect
the new, annual capital asset balance for financial reporting purposes.
   (B)   Responsibilities of department managers.
      (1)   It is the responsibility of the department manager to act as or
designate a steward for each piece of property. The steward will become the
focal point for questions regarding the availability, condition and usage of
the asset, as well as the contact during the physical inventory process.
      (2)   Someone should be designated to record the receipt of the asset, to
examine the asset to make sure that no damage was incurred during shipment and
to make sure that the asset was received in working order.
      (3)   The steward is also responsible for arranging for the necessary
preventative maintenance and any needed repairs to keep the asset in working
condition. It is necessary to have a responsible person for questions that
arise during a physical inventory or when someone wants to borrow the asset.
The steward ensures that the asset is used for the purpose for which it was
acquired and that there is no personal or unauthorized use. In addition, the
steward should report any property damage or theft to the Human Resources/
Safety Director of the city.
   (C)   Recording and accounting.
      (1)   The city and its various departments shall classify capital
expenditures as capital outlays within the fund from which the expenditures was
made, in accordance with the chart of accounts of the Cities and Towns
Accounting Manual. For purposes of recording fixed assets of the city and its
departments, the valuation of assets shall be based on historical cost or,
where the historical cost is indeterminable, by estimation for those assets in
existence.
      (2)   Some of these arrangements present special problems relating to the
cost to be recorded, for example, in utility accounting, interest during a
period of construction has long been recognized as a part of the asset cost.
Reference to an intermediate accounting acquisition arrangements. For the
purpose of recording fixed assets, the valuation shall be based on historical
cost.
      (3)   In addition, assets shall be rerecorded and maintained to provide a
detailed record of the capital assets of the government unit using the form
approved by the State Board of Accounts.
(Ord. 6-2017, passed 8-9-2017)
§ 35.056 DEPRECIATION METHODS.
   (A)   This section applies to the Utilities Department only.
   (B)   The City Utilities Department only will be depreciation capital assets
by using the straight-line method. The city’s civil departments are not
required to depreciate.
   (C)   Salvage value will be determined on an asset-by-asset basis.
Depreciation will be calculated at year end. Land and infrastructure is not
depreciated according to general accepted accounting principles.
   (D)   All assets accounted for under the capital asset policy will be
depreciated using the straight-line method of depreciation. A gain or loss on
disposal will be recorded. Following is a list of the most common useful lives:

§ 35.071 COPYING OR DUPLICATION FEE.
   (A)   Any person requesting a copy of a public record shall pay in advance
to the Clerk-Treasurer of the city, the actual cost of copying the record which
is determined to be $0.25 per page for standard size copies eight and one-half
by 11 or eight and one-half by 14 and $0.50 per page for non-standard copies.
   (B)   If the city does not have mechanical means for copying a requested
record, the person requesting the record shall be entitled to inspect and
manually transcribe the record. The city shall not charge to inspect a public
record to determine whether the record may be disclosed.
(Prior Code, § 110.05)
§ 35.072 ACCIDENT REPORT FEE.
   (A)   The Police Department of the city shall furnish, upon demand, to any
person who has sustained any loss or damage, by reason of injury or death of
any person or damage to property caused by or resulting from the operation,
maintenance or use of any vehicle upon any public street or highway of this
state, the information as set forth pursuant to applicable state law.
   (B)   The Police Department is authorized to charge as a fee for the
information an amount to be determined by the Common Council by resolution, the
amount to be not less than the sum of $3 for each sum report.
   (C)   The fee collected under this section shall be deposited in a separate
account and entitled “Accident,” which sums may be expended at the discretion
of the chief administrative officer of the Police Department for any Department
purposes reasonably related to the keeping of accident reports and records or
the prevention of street and highway accidents.
(Prior Code, § 110.06)
§ 35.073 MOTOR VEHICLE INSPECTION FEE.
   (A)   There shall be a fee of $5 for each motor vehicle inspection for
purposes of motor vehicle certificate of title applications.
   (B)   A special vehicle inspection fund is established for the purpose of
depositing all money collected for the motor vehicle inspections.
   (C)   The monies collected shall only be used for law enforcement purposes
for the City Police Department.
(Prior Code, § 110.07) (Ord. 15-1988, passed 6-28-1988)

§ 51.01 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   HEAVY TRASH. Any discarded matter which cannot be adequately placed or
wrapped in commercially manufactured plastic garbage or trash bags because of
its size or weight and shall include, but not necessarily be limited to,
appliances, water heaters, furniture, mattresses, box springs, bicycles,
furnace or air conditioning units, metal duct or pipe, large tree limbs, all
other items which are either too large or too heavy to be securely wrapped in
bags as described above herein. Specifically excluded from this definition are
tires, rocks and building or construction materials such as roofing, bricks,
concrete blocks, lumber and automotive parts.
   TRASH or GARBAGE. Any discarded matter, including but not necessarily
limited to, household refuse, paper, glass, food containers, edible food or
portions thereof, waste materials, cut grass, weeds or tree limbs or leaves,
wrappings, metal items or other items of personal property.
(Prior Code, § 90.20) (Ord. 9-1992, passed 7-21-1992)
§ 51.02 PROHIBITING ACCUMULATION OF OPEN TRASH AND GARBAGE.
   It shall be unlawful for any person who owns or rents private residential
property, multi-family dwellings or mobile homes within the corporate limits of
the city to permit or allow the accumulation of open trash and garbage on the
property.
(Prior Code, § 90.21) (Ord. 55-1931, passed 9-22-1931; Ord. 18-1981, passed 10-
26-1981) Penalty, see §
51.99
§ 51.03 MONTHLY TRASH COLLECTION PROCEDURE; FEE.
   Effective January 1, 2020 (utility bills due February 10, 2020), every
person who either owns or rents residential property, multi-family dwellings
units or mobile homes within the corporate limits of the city, whose property
lies outside the corporate limits and along North Murphy Avenue to Hendrix
Street, Hendrix Street, Hendrix Street to Murphy Avenue, all property in Deer
Creek Subdivision or any other property located in the corporate limits of the
city, with the approval of the Board of Public Works and Safety, shall be
charged a monthly trash collection fee in the amount of $18 per household to be
added as a separate charge on his or her monthly water bill and payable at the
city waterworks office. Excluded from this fee are business and commercial
concerns and governmental entities. If a residential owner or occupant does not
pay the monthly trash collection fee within 60 days after it becomes due, the
city shall discontinue the collection service to that residential unit, and it
will be the obligation of the owner or occupant to either make other
arrangements for trash collection and removal or pay the past due fees plus a
continuation of service charge of $10 for resumption of city service to that
residence.
(Ord. 2-2018, passed 6-13-2018; Ord. 21-2019, passed 12-11-2019)
§ 51.04 TRASH COLLECTION FUND.
   The collected fees shall be deposited in a separate fund and identified as
the Trash Collection Fund, and only the costs of operation and maintenance of
the service shall be paid from the fund. Any net accumulated surplus after
payment of operational and maintenance costs shall be retained to pay for
future increases in costs, replacement of or additions to trash collection
equipment or future reductions of the trash collection fee by ordinance.
(Prior Code, § 90.23)
§ 51.05 MONTHLY REPORTING TO COMMON COUNCIL.
   The city waterworks shall receive an amount equal to 6% of the total monthly
fee collected to cover its costs of collection, computation and billing, and it
shall send a monthly report to the Common Council of customers in arrears in
their payments and discontinuations in services.
(Prior Code, § 90.24)
§ 51.06 PERIODIC REVIEW OF COLLECTION FEE REQUIRED.
   The amount of the monthly trash collection fee shall be periodically
reviewed by the Common Council and the Mayor, and not more than 24 months shall
elapse without a review.
(Prior Code, § 90.25) (Ord. 18-1981, passed 10-26-1981; Ord. 5-1982, passed - -
)
§ 51.07 WEEKLY TRASH COLLECTION.
   For residential premises and all multi-family dwelling units and mobile
homes located and situated inside the corporate limits of the city, trash
collection by the city shall occur once each week.
(Prior Code, § 90.26)
§ 51.08 BI-ANNUAL HEAVY TRASH COLLECTION.
   (A)   Heavy trash collection shall occur a minimum of twice each year, once
during the spring of the year and once during the fall, plus at any other time
deemed necessary by the Mayor.
   (B)   Collection will occur for one week for each quadrant of the city after
proper advertisement in a local newspaper at least seven days prior to the
designated day.
   (C)   Residents wishing heavy trash collection shall notify the waterworks
office by telephone at least 24 hours prior to the designated heavy trash
collection day.
(Prior Code, § 90.27) (Ord. 9-1992, passed 7-21-1992)
§ 51.09 TRASH CONTAINER REGULATIONS.
   All ordinary and usual trash and garbage to be collected shall be packed and
securely contained in commercially available plastic bags and be light enough
in weight for one person to conveniently lift, and the maximum of ten bags will
be collected from any one residence or residential unit. Garbage or trash in
paper sacks, wrapped in paper or in cartons shall not be collected. Loose and
open trash and garbage shall not be collected.
(Prior Code, § 90.28)
§ 51.10 EXCLUDED ENTITIES.
   Trash collection shall not be made at business or commercial establishments
and non-city governmental entities, including, but not limited to, county
hospitals and schools.
(Prior Code, § 90.29) (Ord. 19-1981, passed 10-26-1981)
§ 51.11 HOURS OF OPERATION FOR COMMERCIAL, INDUSTRIAL AND/OR BUSINESS ENTITIES.
   Every person, firm, corporation, partnership or sole proprietorship engaged
in the business of hauling, carrying and/or collecting trash, debris, garbage
or rubbish from commercial, industrial and/or business entities (including
apartments) that lies adjacent to any property zoned for R-1, R-2 or R-3 uses
or any property that is zoned T but whose use is that of a residential nature,
shall conduct the business within the city’s corporate limits between the hours
of 4:00 a.m. and 10:00 p.m. The business shall not be conducted after 10:00
p.m. or before 4:00 a.m.
(Prior Code, § 90.30) (Ord. 22-2017, passed 12-6-2017) Penalty, see §
51.99

      (2)   For violations of §§

GENERAL PROVISIONS
§ 52.001 PURPOSE AND POLICY.
   (A)   This chapter sets forth uniform requirements for users of the publicly
owned treatment works for the city and enables the city to comply with all
applicable state and federal laws, including the Clean Water Act (33 U.S.C. §§
1251 et seq.) and the general pretreatment regulations (40 C.F.R. part 403).
The objectives of this chapter are:
      (1)   To prevent the introduction of pollutants into the publicly owned
treatment works that will interfere with its operation;
      (2)   To prevent the introduction of pollutants into the publicly owned
treatment works that will pass through the publicly owned treatment works,
inadequately treated, into receiving waters or otherwise be incompatible with
the publicly owned treatment works;
      (3)   To protect both publicly owned treatment works personnel who may be
affected by wastewater and sludge in the course of their employment and the
general public;
      (4)   To promote reuse and recycling of industrial wastewater and sludge
from the publicly owned treatment works;
      (5)   To provide for fees for the equitable distribution of the cost of
operation, maintenance and improvement of the publicly owned treatment works;
and
      (6)   To enable the city to comply with its national pollutant discharge
elimination system permit conditions, sludge use and disposal requirements and
any other federal or state laws to which the publicly owned treatment works is
subject.
   (B)   This chapter shall apply to all users of the publicly owned treatment
works. This chapter provides for monitoring, compliance and enforcement
activities; establishes administrative review procedures; and provides for the
setting of fees for the equitable distribution of costs resulting from the
program established herein.
(Prior Code, § 52.001) (Ord. 2-2007, passed 1-23-2007)
§ 52.002 ADMINISTRATION.
   (A)   Except as otherwise provided in this chapter, the Superintendent shall
administer, implement and enforce the provisions of this chapter.
   (B)   Any powers granted to or duties imposed upon the Superintendent may be
delegated by the Superintendent to other city personnel.
(Prior Code, § 52.002) (Ord. 2-2007, passed 1-23-2007)
§ 52.003 ABBREVIATIONS.
   The following abbreviations, when used in this chapter, shall have the
designated meanings:
BOD    Biochemical oxygen demand
C.F.R. Code of Federal Regulations
