GENERAL PROVISIONS
§ 53.001 CONTROL OF WATERWORKS.
   (A)   The Department of Waterworks shall be abolished, and the Board of
Trustees of the Department shall be dissolved. The operation of the waterworks
shall be returned to the Board of Public Works and Safety. The effective date
of the abolition of the Department of Waterworks was February 1, 1964, except
that the Board of Trustees of the Department shall have no authority from the
date of passage of this chapter to make any contract, obligations or promises
which will create any liability on the part of the city, without approval of
the Board of Public Works and Safety.
   (B)   The Board of Trustees of the Department of Waterworks shall turn over
the possession, care and custody of all assets including real estate, personal
property, books and funds under its control to the Board of Public Works and
Safety. The assets shall include, but not be limited to, all property turned
over to the control of the Board of Trustees of the Department by Res. 16-1963,
passed by the Common Council of the city. All bank accounts shall be
transferred into the name of the City Clerk-Treasurer.
(Prior Code, § 53.001) (Ord. 1-1964, passed 1-14-1964)
§ 53.002 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   CONSUMER. The person, firm, corporation or association having an interest,
whether legal or equitable, sole or only partial, either as owner, tenant or
occupant, in any premises which is or is about to be supplied with water by the
waterworks.
   PREMISES. Any building under the same roof and belonging to the same person,
or any single piece of real estate, together with its buildings and adjuncts,
and which belongs to the same person. Each dwelling house together with its
outbuildings and appurtenances shall be considered a single piece of real
estate or a PREMISES within the meaning of this chapter.
   WATERWORKS. The city waterworks, municipally owned by the city.
(Prior Code, § 53.002) (Ord. 1-1964, passed 1-14-1964)
§ 53.003 GROUNDWATER RESTRICTIONS.
   (A)   (1)   This section applies only to the geographic area of the city
within the following boundaries: See map attached to the ordinance codified in
this section as Exhibit A and list of included legal descriptions, parcel
numbers and current owners’ names attached as Exhibit B. Such geographic area
shall be referred to in this section as the restricted area.
      (2)   This section does not apply to monitoring wells or groundwater
wells that may be used as part of an environmental investigation or remediation
project. The contamination source is the former Adamson’s Fabric Care Services
site, 608 West National Avenue, Brazil, Indiana.
   (B)   Installation and use of private water wells for human and domestic
purposes within the restricted area are hereby prohibited. Occupants or users
of real property within the restricted area must be connected to the public
water supply utility.
   (C)   Any private water well within the restricted area existing as of the
date of the taking effect of this section, or thereafter, must be disconnected
from the water supply system and such disconnection of the well must be
inspected and approved by the Utility Director of the city.
   (D)   Any use of private water wells within the restricted area after the
taking effect of this section shall constitute a violation thereof and shall be
subject to penalty in the form of a fine not to exceed $2,500 for each
violation. Each day such use shall occur or continue shall constitute a new and
separate violation and shall be subject to additional fine, each such day’s
fine not to exceed $2,500.
   (E)   The city, acting by and through the Clerk-Treasurer, shall provide
written notice to the State Department of Environmental Management at least 60
days before the amendment or repeal of the ordinance codified in this section
and no later than 30 days after the passage, amendment or repeal of the
ordinance codified in this section. Written notice shall be sent to the
following address:
 
IDEM, Office of Land Quality Remediation Services Branch Attn: Branch Chief
IGCN Suite 1101
100 N. Senate Ave
Indianapolis, IN 46204-2251
 
(Ord. 2014-6, passed 10-8-2014)
CONNECTIONS AND SERVICE CONTRACTS
§ 53.015 REQUIRED APPLICATION, METER DEPOSIT AND INITIAL CHARGE.
   (A)   All persons desiring to be supplied with water from the city
waterworks at a property now connected with the mains, must apply in person, or
by a legal representative, at the waterworks office for water, before using the
same.
   (B)   Each new customer of the waterworks shall pay a meter deposit of $25.
This deposit is to be held by the city as a guarantee that water bills will be
paid on presentation of monthly or quarterly statements of the same, the city
to pay interest on all deposits at the rate of 5% per annum. No interest shall
be paid for less than six months.
   (C)   There shall be a charge of $15 for initiation of service at a location
where a water meter is not in service. No water shall be turned on to any
premises which are indebted to the waterworks for work done or material
furnished until the indebtedness has been paid; and, provided further, that no
applicant shall be supplied with water for any purpose whatsoever who, at the
time of application for same, is indebted to the waterworks for water
previously supplied him or her until such indebtedness has been paid.
(Prior Code, § 53.015) (Ord. 9-1981, passed 5-26-1981; Ord. 16-1981, passed 10-
12-1981)
§ 53.016 TERM OF CONTRACT.
   (A)   Ordinary contracts for water supply service, unless otherwise
specified, expire in one year from date of the application, subject to the
following conditions and provisions. Contracts for metered water supply service
expire on the first of the month which follows the end of the first year from
date of application.
   (B)   All contracts shall continue in force by renewal without act or notice
from either party to the other, from year to year, unless 30 days’ notice in
writing is given by either party to the other of a desire to terminate the
contract.
(Prior Code, § 53.016) (Ord. 21-1931, passed 9-22-1931)
§ 53.017 CHANGE OF OWNERSHIP.
   (A)   In the event of any change of consumer, located at any premises,
connected to the system of the waterworks for water supply service, the
waterworks shall be immediately notified, in writing, of the change giving in
notice the name and address of the new consumer, whereupon the waterworks shall
require the new consumer to make application for water supply service in the
same manner as is provided for new service connections.
   (B)   In absence of an application by a new consumer, the use of the
waterworks service, may at the option of the waterworks, to be taken and
presumed to be an acceptance by the new consumer of all the contract
obligations of the preceding consumer with the waterworks.
   (C)   In the event any consumer fails to notify the waterworks, in writing,
of a change in occupancy of any premises connected for water supply service,
that consumer shall continue to be liable to the waterworks for all rates and
charges accrued and accruing for the service, until either the end of the
contract period in which he or she may later notify the waterworks of his or
her desire to cancel, or the waterworks shall, of its own volition, have
canceled the contract with the consumer, but this clause shall not preclude the
waterworks from also demanding, from the new consumer, the payment of all or
any charges and rates which shall, at the time of the demand, be unpaid or
unsecured, without regard to whether the same accrued prior or subsequent to
any change in occupancy or ownership.
   (D)   In no case of change of consumer shall the preceding consumer be
released from any contract obligations to and with the waterworks until the
expiration of the contract period, properly terminated in accordance with these
rules, except at the option of the waterworks, evidenced by a written release
from the waterworks.
(Prior Code, § 53.017) (Ord. 21-1931, passed 9-22-1931)
§ 53.018 REVIVING CANCELED CONTRACTS.
   Any contract which has been canceled cannot be revived, nor can service
thereunder, which has been discontinued, be resumed except at the option of the
waterworks, and then only on further conditions as it may impose, and on
payment to the waterworks or all charges and rates due and unpaid under the
canceled contract, together with the usual turn-on charges, and on the payment
of the water rates applicable under these rules.
(Prior Code, § 53.018) (Ord. 21-1931, passed 9-22-1931)
§ 53.019 WHEN RATES FOR SERVICE BEGIN TO ACCRUE.
   When applications for water supply service is made, the service together
with the charges and rates therefor shall begin in accordance with these rules
on the date the water is turned on by the waterworks.
(Prior Code, § 53.019) (Ord. 21-1931, passed 9-22-1931)
§ 53.020 CANCELLATION OF CONTRACT AND DISCONTINUANCE OF SERVICE.
   All contracts shall be subject to cancellation at the option of the
waterworks, and service thereunder may be discontinued by the waterworks for
any of the following reasons:
   (A)   For misrepresentations or concealment in the application as to the
premises or fixtures to be furnished with water supply service or the use to be
made of the service;
   (B)   For adding to the premises or fixtures, or to the use to be made of
the water supply service, without notice, in writing, to the waterworks, and
first obtaining its written assent to the addition;
   (C)   For waste or excessive use of water through improper or imperfect
pipes, fixtures or appliances, or in any other manner;
   (D)   For refusal or neglect to make or renew any advance payment, if any is
required by the waterworks, or to pay bills for service rendered when due, or
for refusal or neglect to comply with any requirements of the waterworks as to
meter or service connection maintenance, alteration or renewal, or other
requirements relating to the water supply service of the waterworks;
   (E)   For the use of water supply service for, or in connection with, or for
the benefit of, any other premises or purpose than that described in the
application, where pipes or plumbing fixtures have been installed without
securing a permit therefor from the waterworks, or where the arrangements of
the pipes or the plumbing fixtures are not in accordance with the rules of the
waterworks;
   (F)   (1)   For any interference or tampering, whether by act or omission,
with the seals on any meter, or with any meter box or vault, or with service
pipes or valves or any seals thereon, or with the curb stopcock, or with any
appliance of the waterworks or with any appliance of the owner, which was or is
required by the waterworks for controlling or regulating the water supply
service.
      (2)   For the purpose of this rule, any interference or tampering by any
person whomsoever with any appliances used in connection with or for
controlling or regulating the water supply service to any premises shall be
construed and taken to be the act or omission of the consumer at the premises;
   (G)   For failure to maintain, protect and safeguard the meter in working
order satisfactory to the waterworks, where the meter is owned by either the
consumer or the waterworks;
   (H)   In cases of continued vacancy of the premises;
   (I)   For violation of any rule of the waterworks;
   (J)   When there has been a change in occupancy of the premises, but no
application from the new consumer has been made and approved by the waterworks;
   (K)   When there has been a discontinuance of the use of the water or of the
service of the waterworks;
   (L)   When the contract has been in any way terminated by the consumer.
Likewise, unless all bills, accounts and charges of the waterworks have been
paid or until they are properly secured to the satisfaction of the waterworks;
   (M)   When any consumer refuses or neglects payment of any bills, accounts
or charges for or on account of the premises;
   (N)   When the consumer commits any act of bankruptcy or makes an assignment
for the benefit of creditors, or has made against him or her an application for
the appointment of receiver;
   (O)   When the waterworks has been or is being defrauded in any way; and/or
   (P)   When any consumer becomes irresponsible or on his or her death.
(Prior Code, § 53.020) (Ord. 21-1931, passed 9-22-1931)
§ 53.021 SERVICE CONNECTIONS AND WATER CONNECTION PERMIT FEES.
   (A)   (1)   Service connections shall be installed only with a valid permit.
      (2)   The service connection means the service pipe beginning at the
coupling on the water main ending at the meter well.
   (B)   The waterworks shall make the tap in the water main. It shall be the
responsibility of the consumer to expose the water mainline, set saddle,
install corporation stops and pay for the installation of service from water
main.
   (C)   Water connection permit fees shall be as follows.
      (1)   Permit fee for developments for multiple single-family home sites
shall be $1.25 per linear foot of waterline to cover the cost of reviewing
construction drawings, issuing the permit and conducting periodic inspections
of the construction.
      (2)   Permit fee for site development to connect to water mainline to a
building or single-family dwelling shall be as follows:
 
Size                 Tap Fee
2 inch or less meter $500
 
      (3)   The charge for a tap larger than the two-inch meter shall be the
cost of labor, materials, power machinery, transportation and overhead cost for
installing the tap, but shall not be less than the charge for a two-inch meter
tap.
   (D)   Written application for all new service shall be made at City Hall,
specifying that the applicant will use water and pay for same at scheduled
rates of a period of at least one year, beginning within 90 days from date of
application; the application to be made on printed forms of the waterworks.
(Prior Code, § 53.021) (Ord. 7-2005, passed 4-13-2005)
§ 53.022 REPAIRS, RENEWALS AND REPLACEMENTS.
   All repairs, renewals and replacements of small service connections,
originally furnished by the waterworks, and not otherwise, shall be made by the
waterworks free of charge, on notice, in writing by the consumer of any
requirement of the repairs, renewal or replacements. Where repairs to service
pipes or water fixtures beyond service connections or the curb stop are
necessary, the consumer shall, without delay, employ a plumber licensed by the
waterworks to do the work. Failure, refusal or neglect of the consumer to make
repairs within three days after notice is sent by the waterworks, shall
authorize the waterworks to shut off the water and to discontinue the service
without further notice.
(Prior Code, § 53.022) (Ord. 21-1931, passed 9-22-1931)
§ 53.023 SIZE OF SERVICE PIPE; UNDERWRITERS PUMP.
   (A)   In all cases, the waterworks shall decide the size of the service
pipe. In all cases where underwriters pumps are to be installed, a suction pipe
sufficient internal area to deliver a quantity of water equal to the full rated
capacity of the pipe will be allowed, and no enlargement of the suction pipe
inside the premises will be permitted.
   (B)   If, however, this service pipe is run to a surge tank placed in close
proximity to the pump, the full size of the suction which the pump calls for
may be run from the pump to the tank.
(Prior Code, § 53.041) (Ord. 21-1931, passed 9-22-1931)
§ 53.024 SIZE OF SERVICE CONNECTION PRESCRIBED.
   The waterworks in every instance reserves the right, at its option to
designate and prescribe the size of a service connection, either on original
installation of a new connection or on any renewal or replacement of any old
connection. The service pipe may be extended from the curb by any plumber
licensed by the waterworks when the necessary permit has been secured.
Reasonable sizes shall be designated and prescribed.
(Prior Code, § 53.023) (Ord. 21-1931, passed 9-22-1931)
§ 53.025 SEPARATE SERVICE CONNECTION FOR EACH PREMISES.
   Each separate premises shall have its separate and distinct service
connection, and in no case shall more than one premises be furnished with
service from one connection, except only in cases where, in the discretion of
the waterworks, the conditions make this impossible or inadvisable, in which
event the waterworks may permit the use of one service connection.
(Prior Code, § 53.024) (Ord. 21-1931, passed 9-22-1931)
FIRE PROTECTION SERVICES
§ 53.040 INSTALLATION SERVICE.
   All private fire protection services will be installed by the waterworks
which will ascertain the best location for same and lay the pipe from the
street main to a point just inside the wall of the building or within the
building line of open yards, where buildings are set back from the building
line. The consumer will be charged for time and materials. The service will be
so installed that the water used therefrom will not flow through the meter but
will be separate and apart from the regular water service.
(Prior Code, § 53.040) (Ord. 21-1931, passed 9-22-1931)
§ 53.041 NUMBER OF SERVICES.
   (A)   One service only will be allowed to any one building or premises
unless, in the opinion of the waterworks, the general public fire protection
will not be jeopardized and more than one is absolutely necessary for the
proper protection of the premises.
   (B)   All fire equipment connected to the waterworks service shall be
confined within the application, and where two or more connections are made for
one building or premises, they shall be kept separated, unless special
permission is obtained from the waterworks to connect the same in a manner
approved by it.
(Prior Code, § 53.042) (Ord. 21-1931, passed 9-22-1931)
§ 53.042 TEST OF FIRE SERVICES.
   Whenever a fire service system is to be tested under the regulations of the
fire insurance underwriters, the consumer must notify the waterworks of the
proposed test, naming the day and hour when the same is intended to be made so
that, if desired, the waterworks may have an inspector present during the test.
(Prior Code, § 53.043) (Ord. 21-1931, passed 9-22-1931)
§ 53.043 CONTAMINATION OF WATER SUPPLY.
   Any fire protection system supplied with water from the waterworks service
shall be supplied exclusively with the water, and no connection will be allowed
with any other system drawing its supply from any other source whereby the
waterworks water supply may be contaminated by the failure to close valves or
leaking check valves, and no auxiliary or secondary suction pipe to any
underwriters pump taking water from wells, streams or other sources whatever
will be permitted. Any fire protection system using water from wells, streams
or sources other than the waterworks service shall be kept separate from any
system supplied from the waterworks service.
(Prior Code, § 53.044) (Ord. 21-1931, passed 9-22-1931)
§ 53.044 INSPECTION; APPROVAL OF THE FIRE CHIEF; GUARANTEES.
   (A)   All fire service shall be subject to inspection by the waterworks from
time to time, and the consumer shall give the inspectors all reasonable
facilities for making the inspections and any information concerning the same
that the inspector or the waterworks may require. Care will always be taken
that inspections will be made with as little inconvenience to the consumer or
occupant as possible.
   (B)   All applications for private fire protection shall be subject to the
written approval of the Chief of the Fire Department, who, upon approval, shall
state that in his or her opinion the public fire protection will not be
endangered by the connection proposed to be made by the waterworks when
properly safeguarded by the placing of an indicator post valve as near the main
as possible, the valve to be under the control and orders of the Chief of the
Fire Department, at time of fires, with full authority to close the valve.
   (C)   The waterworks in no manner guarantees to furnish a proper quantity of
water through the fire protection service, nor does it undertake to guarantee
anything relative to the services, but it will endeavor to maintain the
efficiency of its service under all conditions. The granting of a permit for
private fire protection is under the express condition that the waterworks
shall not be considered or deemed in any manner to have undertaken to
extinguish fire or to protect any person or property against loss or damage by
fire or otherwise; the waterworks is not an insurer of persons or property and
it shall be free and exempt from any and all claims for damage on account of
any injury to persons or property by reason of fire, water, failure to supply
water or pressure, or for any other cause whatsoever, and, in the event of the
destruction of the premises of the consumer, the contract between the
waterworks and the consumer shall immediately cease.
(Prior Code, § 53.045) (Ord. 21-1931, passed 9-22-1931) Penalty, see §
53.999
USE OF WATER SYSTEM AND METERS
§ 53.055 PLANS AND DRAWINGS.
   The consumer will furnish an accurate sketch showing the pipes, valves,
hydrants, connections and appurtenances on the premises of the consumer and
connected with the mains of the waterworks and also an accurate sketch of any
other water pipe system and fixtures that may exist on the premises.
(Prior Code, § 53.046) (Ord. 21-1931, passed 9-22-1931)
§ 53.056 EXTENSIONS OF MAINS AND INSTALLING PUBLIC HYDRANTS.
   (A)   On receipt of written instruction from the city, the waterworks will
extend its water mains in graded streets and install fire hydrants, all at its
own expense, one fire hydrant to be installed, approximately, for every 300
feet of water mains so ordered and extended.
   (B)   The waterworks will extend its main in graded streets, adjoining
existing mains, when there is sufficient new business, satisfactorily
guaranteed in writing, to give an additional revenue of $50 per annum for a
period of three years for every 300 feet of mains so extended, in making up the
$50 for every 300 feet, the waterworks will not include any existing business
or any premises that can be supplied from existing mains. Under this
arrangement, the city may transfer fire hydrants from other portions of the
city by paying the actual costs of moving the hydrants and connecting the same
to the new mains, and the city shall pay the rental for the hydrants in their
new locations instead of in the original locations.
   (C)   The waterworks will also extend its mains into subdivisions where
satisfactory arrangements can be made with realty companies or owners, who are
promoting the sale of real estate, on the basis of a guaranteed return of
$17.50 per annum, for a period of five years for each 100 feet of main pipe
extended.
(Prior Code, § 53.047) (Ord. 21-1931, passed 9-22-1931)
§ 53.057 MONTHLY READINGS; BILLS; COMPLAINTS.
   (A)   Meters will be read monthly in the last week of each month, and all
bills shall become due and payable the first day of the following month.
   (B)   (1)   All persons regarding themselves overcharged can, by applying to
the waterworks office within 15 days after their bills are due, have their
premises inspected or meter tested, examined and reread, but all bills against
which no complaints have been entered within the time shall be considered
correct and must be paid without any change in the amount of same.
      (2)   All persons making complaints are required to get a written
acknowledgment of same from the waterworks office showing the nature and amount
of the complaint. Without the written acknowledgment, no complaint will be
considered.
(Prior Code, § 53.048) (Ord. 21-1931, passed 9-22-1931) Penalty, see §
53.999
§ 53.058 DEFECTIVE METER.
   No bills will be calculated on the registration of any meter the setting of
which and the quality thereof has not met the approval of the waterworks, and
the waterworks reserves the right at any time to test any meter in actual
service. Should a meter prove to be defective on any test, it will be taken out
of service at once and the charge for the water will be adjusted by estimate.
(Prior Code, § 53.049) (Ord. 21-1931, passed 9-22-1931)
§ 53.059 METERS NOT REGISTERING.
   If any meter stops registering, the consumer will be charged for the month
based on the average for the corresponding period in preceding years or months.
(Prior Code, § 53.050) (Ord. 21-1931, passed 9-22-1931)
§ 53.060 CONSUMER RESPONSIBLE FOR ALL WATER REGISTERED.
   (A)   The consumer supplied through meter will be held responsible for all
water registered by the same, and no reduction will be allowed on account of
leaks or wastage.
   (B)   There shall be no waste of water either to prevent freezing or for any
other purpose. Water will not be furnished where there are leaky pipes or
fixtures.
   (C)   When the conditions are found to exist, the supply will be shut off
until repairs are made.
(Prior Code, § 53.051) (Ord. 21-1931, passed 9-22-1931)
§ 53.061 DISCONNECTION FOR LATE PAYMENT.
   (A)   It is the policy of the city to discontinue utility service to
customers by reason of nonpayment of bills only after notice and a meaningful
opportunity to be heard on disputed bills. The city’s form for application for
utility service and all bills shall contain, in addition to the title, address,
room number and telephone number of the official in charge of billing, clearly
visible and easily readable provisions to the effect that:
      (1)   All bills are due and payable on or before the date set forth on
the bill;
      (2)   If any bill is not paid by or before that date, a second bill will
be mailed containing a cutoff notice that if the bill is not paid within ten
days of the mailing of the second bill, service will be discontinued for
nonpayment; and
      (3)   Any customer disputing the correctness of his or her bill shall
have a right to a hearing, at which time he or she may be represented in person
and by counsel, or any other person of his or her choosing, and may present
orally or in writing his or her complaint and contentions to the city official
in charge of utility billing. This official shall be authorized to order that
the customer’s service not be discontinued and shall have the authority to make
a final determination of the customer’s complaint.
   (B)   (1)   Requests for delays or waivers of payment will not be
entertained; only questions of proper and correct billing will be considered.
      (2)   In the absence of payment of the bill rendered or resort to the
hearing procedure provided herein, service will be discontinued at the time
specified, but in no event until the charges have been due and unpaid for at
least 30 days.
   (C)   When it becomes necessary for the city to discontinue utility service
to a customer for nonpayment of bills, service will be reinstated only after
all bills for service then due have been paid, along with a turn-on charge in
the sum of $20.
(Prior Code, § 53.052) (Ord. 21-1931, passed 9-22-1931; Ord. 9-1981, passed 5-
26-1981)
§ 53.062 SETTING OF METERS; DISTURBING METER.
   (A)   (1)   All meters shall be put in and connected up under the direction
and in conformity with the rules and regulations of the waterworks, whether
placed on-premises or in the street.
      (2)   The waterworks reserves the right to decide the location.
      (3)   Any consumer desiring to move the location of the meter, including
meter pit and/or hardware, shall first obtain the permission of the waterworks,
and said consumer shall bear the cost and expense of the waterworks for moving
the meter.
      (4)   When placed in premises where a hot water tank is used, the meter
must not be placed nearer than 20 feet of the hot water tank, and a good check
valve must be placed in the supply pipe between the hot water tank and the
meter.
      (5)   If this rule is not complied with, the consumer will be charged
with all damages to the meter caused by hot water.
   (B)   (1)   No person, unless authorized by the waterworks, shall connect,
disconnect, remove or repair or otherwise disturb any meter. The waterworks
will repair all meters two inches and less in size free of charge.
      (2)   Actual cost or repairs on all meters larger than two inches will be
charged to consumers having the meters.
(Prior Code, § 53.053) (Ord. 11-2011, passed 9-14-2011) Penalty, see §
53.999
§ 53.063 CONSUMERS RESPONSIBLE FOR METERS AND ARRANGING PIPES.
   (A)   Consumers will be held responsible for any damage meters may sustain
from freezing (except where set in tree row), hot water or steam settling back
from the boiler or from any other cause, and any necessary repairs resulting
from the cause will be made at the expense of the consumer, the charges to be
paid to the waterworks before water is turned on.
   (B)   Before any meter is placed by the waterworks, the consumer shall, at
his or her own expense, have pipes so arranged that all water will pass through
the meter. Consumers shall provide ready and easy access to their meters so
that they may frequently be read and examined by the waterworks.
(Prior Code, § 53.054) (Ord. 21-1931, passed 9-22-1931)
§ 53.064 ACCESS TO PREMISES.
   Through its proper officers, the waterworks shall, at all reasonable hours,
have a free access to all parts of premises to which water is supplied for the
purpose of making necessary examinations.
(Prior Code, § 53.055) (Ord. 21-1931, passed 9-22-1931)
§ 53.065 TEMPORARY USERS.
   Any residential property owner that wishes to establish temporary service
for a period of not more than five business days every 30 days shall pay a
charge of $15 for the use of 100 cubic feet or less of water and wastewater.
Any usage in excess of 100 cubic feet shall be paid at the normal metered rate
for water and wastewater.
(Prior Code, § 53.056) (Ord. 12-2014, passed 12-10-2014)
§ 53.066 USE OF FIRE HYDRANT.
   No person, except a duly authorized agent of the Waterworks Department or
Fire Department, shall open, for public or private use, any fire hydrant or
take water from any outlet whatever, unless the person shall first obtain
permission from the Superintendent of the Waterworks.
(Prior Code, § 53.057) (Ord. 21-1931, passed 9-22-1931)
§ 53.067 CONNECTIONS TO WATER MAIN ON MAIN WATER PIPE; SPRINKLING.
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person, except a duly authorized agent of
the waterworks, to make or attempt to make any extension of, or connection
with, or tap to any main, distributing pipe or service pipe of the waterworks
system by which water is furnished by the waterworks to any consumer, whether
the main or pipe is owned by the city or private individuals.
   (B)   (1)   The use of water for sprinkling purposes must be limited to four
hours per day, from 6:00 a.m. to 7:00 a.m. and from 5:00 p.m. to 8:00 p.m.
      (2)   The use of water for sprinkling purposes outside of these hours is
positively prohibited. Sprinkling shall be by hand only, and the use of
automatic sprinklers or a hose fixed on a support is positively prohibited.
      (3)   During all alarms of fire and while the fire pressure is on the
pipe, the use of water for yard or street sprinkling is positively prohibited,
and violation of either of these rules will forfeit the right to use of the
water at the option of the waterworks.
(Prior Code, § 53.058) (Ord. 21-1931, passed 9-22-1931) Penalty, see §
53.999
§ 53.068 DISCONNECTING THE USE OF WATER.
   Persons desirous of discontinuing the use of the water must give notice to
the waterworks office prior to the stopping thereof or they will be charged
until the notice is given.
(Prior Code, § 53.059) (Ord. 21-1931, passed 9-22-1931)
§ 53.069 CONTROL OF STOPCOCKS.
   (A)   (1)   Stopcocks will be placed at the curb of property line and shall
be under the exclusive control of the waterworks.
      (2)   No person shall, without written authority from the waterworks,
turn on the water to any service.
   (B)   This rule shall not prevent plumbers from testing their work, but they
must not in any case leave the water turned on without special permit.
(Prior Code, § 53.060) (Ord. 21-1931, passed 9-22-1931)
§ 53.070 LIABILITY OF WATERWORKS.
   In no case will the waterworks be liable for damage for shutting off the
water to any consumer either while making repairs to mains or service pipes, or
for any violation of the rules and regulations of the waterworks.
(Prior Code, § 53.061) (Ord. 21-1931, passed 9-22-1931)
§ 53.071 BOILERS.
   Steam boilers and gas engines taking a supply of water directly from the
service pipe, depending on the pressure of the pipe system of the waterworks
for supplying the boilers under working pressure, will do so at the risk of
parties making attachments as the waterworks will not be responsible for any
accident or damages. House boilers for domestic use must in all cases be
provided with vacuum valves to prevent collapsing when the water is cut off
from the distributing pipes, and for accidents or damages from the imperfect
action of the valves, the waterworks will not be responsible in any case.
(Prior Code, § 53.062) (Ord. 21-1931, passed 9-22-1931)
§ 53.072 TAPPING THE WATER MAINS.
   It shall be unlawful for any person except a properly qualified agent of the
waterworks to enter on any alley or street within the city for the purpose of
laying service or distributing pipes, or to do any plumbing in connection with
the waterworks or the city in the streets or alleys, or to dig in any street or
alley, or, for any purpose, to do plumbing in connection with the waterworks,
or to make any connection with any main distribution service or other pipe
belonging to or forming a part of the waterworks system of the city, until the
person has procured a permit so to do.
(Prior Code, § 53.063) (Ord. 21-1931, passed 9-22-1931) Penalty, see §

   It shall be the duty of everybody, and especially all city employees, to
report to the waterworks all cases of leakage or waste of water or any

belonging to the waterworks and intended for public use shall be subject to the
same supervision, rules and regulations as are made for the protection of the
waterworks against abuse, destruction and unnecessary use or waste of water.
(Prior Code, § 53.065) (Ord. 21-1931, passed 9-22-1931)

   All persons taking water must provide a stop and waste valve properly
located inside the building and have pipes so arranged that water can be drawn

ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT
§ 53.090 PLUMBER REGULATIONS.
   (A)   No plumber shall be authorized to carry on the business of plumbing in
connection with the waterworks until he or she has given satisfactory bond in
the sum of $1,000 and received a license as provided by ordinance affecting
plumbers.
   (B)   Plumbers will be required to have their bonds renewed on or before
January 1 of each year, otherwise their license will become inoperative.
   (C)   No plumber shall lay any service pipe or do any kind or work in
connection with the introduction and supply or water without first having
obtained a written permit from the waterworks for each separate job of plumbing
work which he or she may wish to perform. All plumbing must be done subject to
the approval of the waterworks. Water closets and urinals must be provided with
self-flushing valves unless supplied through a meter.
   (D)   Plumbers shall make a full and complete return of the use for which
water is supplied under any permit granted. The return must be made by the
plumber doing the work within 48 hours after the completion of any work.
   (E)   If a plumber, in making an attachment or in shutting off or turning on
water, should not properly replace the curb box or in any way injure any of the
property of the waterworks, he or she shall be charged with the expense of
making all necessary repairs. On his or her failure to report the damage or pay
the charges, he or she shall be refused further permits until the damages are
paid.
   (F)   After testing any work, the plumber shall turn off the water from the
premises except where the work is a simple extension or addition attachment on
a service then in use and where a permit has been obtained to make the same.
Where water is turned off previous to making any alterations or repairs,
plumbers shall not leave water turned on when work is completed.
   (G)   Plumbers are particularly cautioned to leave curb cocks in the
condition in which they find them, either on or off. Disregard of this rule
will result in forfeiture of license.
   (H)   Plumbers shall report in writing to the waterworks all repairs to any
water service within 48 hours after completion of the repairs. This division
(H) specifically includes leaks.
   (I)   Plumbers shall not loan or sell any valve keys.
   (J)   All pipes used must be either standard weight cast iron, properly
coated, galvanized wrought iron or extra heavy lead. The use of block wrought
iron or steel pipe is prohibited.
   (K)   All work shall be inspected before being covered up, if underground,
and the plumber doing the work shall give the waterworks at least two hours’
notice that the work will be ready for inspection.
   (L)   Where services are metered, no connection shall be made between meters
and curb box.
   (M)   Plans for fire protection lines or other special or unusual uses shall
be submitted to the waterworks for approval before any work is done in
connection therewith.
   (N)   The cross-connection of one premises with another, whether owned by
the same person or not, is strictly prohibited. Each property must have its own
individual curb cock.
   (O)   Any plumber violating any of the waterworks rules and regulations
governing the introduction, supply and consumption of water or who shall either
voluntarily or at the request of any consumer or subscriber introduce any pipe,
hydrant, bath or fixture which is prohibited by the waterworks will be
prosecuted and shall be subject to the penalties hereinafter provided and may,
at the option of the Waterworks Committee, be required to forfeit his or her
license to do plumbing.
(Prior Code, § 53.068) (Ord. 21-1931, passed 9-22-1931) Penalty, see §
53.999
§ 53.091 DUTIES OF THE SUPERINTENDENT.
   (A)   The Superintendent, under the direction of the Waterworks Committee
and the Common Council, shall have charge of the city waterworks.
   (B)   It shall be his or her duty to see that all rules and regulations are
complied with and that the conditions of all contracts by or with the city
relating to the waterworks are faithfully complied with; he or she shall audit
all accounts and claims and submit the same to the Waterworks Committee with
the information that will enable them to act advisedly thereon, with authority
from the Waterworks Committee, and he or she shall purchase all supplies for
the city waterworks.
   (C)   He or she shall keep a correct account of all persons using water and
shall see that the accounts are kept according to the rules of the State Public
Service Commission and report to it at least once a year, and he or she shall
collect all the water rents and deposit same with the City Clerk-Treasurer at
least once each week.
(Prior Code, § 53.069) (Ord. 21-1931, passed 9-22-1931)
§ 53.092 REBATE OF DEPOSITS.
   (A)   When the water is turned off, a rebate of the deposit made by the
consumer will be given after all bills of the waterworks have been paid. If the
consumer moves out owing bills, the deposit will be used as a payment of the
bills. The deposit receipt must in all cases accompany the application for
rebate.
   (B)   The Superintendent shall pay the rebate due the depositor and take a
receipt for the same, and on filing a claim, with a receipt attached, the
Common Council shall reimburse the Superintendent for the money advanced by him
or her.
(Prior Code, § 53.070) (Ord. 21-1931, passed 9-22-1931)
§ 53.093 SUPERINTENDENT TO MAKE CONTRACTS.
   The Superintendent is authorized and directed to execute, on behalf of the
city, all contracts for water and other contracts provided for in this chapter,
the same to be executed according to the terms and conditions specified in this
chapter. In the absence of a Superintendent, the contracts shall be executed by
a duly authorized agent of the city.
(Prior Code, § 53.071) (Ord. 21-1931, passed 9-22-1931)
§ 53.094 BYPASS THIEVERY.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to construct or install any device to
circumvent the metering of water flow.
(Prior Code, § 53.072) (Ord. 21-1931, passed 9-22-1931) Penalty, see §
53.999
§ 53.095 UNLAWFUL USE OF WATER SERVICE LINE.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to use a city water service line or the
water therefrom without having the line or water metered without written
permission of the City Waterworks Department. Any person violating this section
shall have his or her water service discontinued until proper application for
water service and meter has been made and approved.
(Prior Code, § 53.073) (Ord. 16-1981, passed 10-12-1981) Penalty, see §
53.999
§ 53.096 TURNING ON OR SHUTTING OFF WATER SERVICE.
   Normally, a request to turn on or shut off water service will be honored
within 24 business hours of the request being made to the utility office.
Additional time may, however, be required depending on the work schedules and
responsibilities of utility personnel.
(Ord. 5-2014, passed 5-14-2014)
RATES AND CHARGES
§ 53.110 ALL WATER SOLD BY METER MEASUREMENT.
   All water will be sold to the consumer by meter measurement at the rate
established by the State Public Service Commission.
(Prior Code, § 53.025) (Ord. 21-1931, passed 9-22-1931)

   There shall be and there are hereby established for the use of and the
service rendered by the waterworks utility of the city, the following rates and
charges, based on the use of water supplied by said waterworks system.
   (A)   Metered rates per month. For use of and service rendered by the
waterworks system of the city, based on the use of water supplied by said

   (D)   Sales for resale. The customer shall pay for each service connection a

      (1)   Service charge(s) based on the size of the meter(s) through which
the customer receives such service; and
      (2)   A volume charge based on the metered amount of water consumed. The

         (a)   Service charge.

5/8-inch meter $13.14

4-inch meter   $130.90
 
         (b)   Volume charge. All cubic feet of metered water consumed shall be
purchased at the rate of $2.04 per 100 cubic feet.
   (E)   Temporary users. Water furnished to temporary users such as
contractors, circuses and the like shall be charged on the basis of the metered
rates per month as hereinabove set forth as estimated and established by the
Waterworks Superintendent.
   (F)   Tapping fees.
      (1)   Service connections shall be installed only with a valid permit.
Written application for all new service shall be made at City Hall, specifying
that applicant will use water and pay for same at scheduled rates for a period
of at least one year, beginning within 90 days from date of application; the
application shall be made on printed forms of the waterworks.
      (2)   The waterworks shall make the tap in the water main. It shall be
the responsibility of the waterworks to expose the water mainline, set saddle,
install corporation stop, install the service line to the water meter pit,
install meter pit, meter and terminate approximately two feet from the meter
pit for connection by the customer.
      (3)   Water connection permit fees shall be as follows.
         (a)   The permit fee for a five-eighths- or three-fourths-inch meter
tap shall be $1,200, plus the cost of the meter (as determined by the
waterworks).
         (b)   The permit fee for a tap larger than three-fourths-inch shall be
the cost of labor, materials, machinery, transportation, overhead costs and
other costs determine by the waterworks to be applicable to install the tap,
but shall not be less than $1,200, plus the cost of the meter (as determined by
the waterworks).
         (c)   The permit fee for developments for multiple single-family home
sites shall be $1.25 per linear foot of waterline to cover the cost of
reviewing construction drawings, issuing the permit and conducting periodic
inspections of the construction.
         (d)   If written approval is received from the Board of Public Works
and Safety and the Waterworks Superintendent, a developer of multiple single or
multiple family home sites may install all water lines and meter pit wells at
developers cost. The developer shall pay Waterworks a tap permit fee of $100
plus the cost of the meter (as determined by the waterworks).
   (G)   Connection/reconnection charge.
      (1)   The charge to establish a new service connection or to re-establish
service for an account or customer that had not previously had service
disconnected for nonpayment within the previous 12-month period prior to said
request shall be $20.
      (2)   The charge to re-establish service for an account or customer who
previously had said service discontinued because of nonpayment within the
previous 12-month period prior to said request shall be $35.
      (3)   For each re-establishment of service within a 12-month period for
nonpayment, the service re-establishment charge shall increase by $35 for each
subsequent re-establishment after disconnection for nonpayment within a 12-
month period.
      (4)   When the service is turned off for nonpayment of bill, or whenever
for any reason beyond the control of the waterworks a re-establishment of
services is required by any one customer, the charge will be made by the
waterworks to cover the cost of discontinuance and re-establishment of service.
The charge, together with any arrears due the waterworks, shall be paid by the
customer before service will be re-established.
   (H)   Bad check charge. There shall be a charge of $20 for any check
returned for insufficient funds or because the check is written on a non-
existent bank account.
   (I)   Customer meter deposit.
      (1)   An existing customer making application for service and who shall
be responsible for the monthly billings shall pay a “meter deposit” in the
amount of $60.
      (2)   A customer making application for service and who shall be
responsible for the monthly billings who has never before been a customer for
said service or who has had previous water service from the city, but has had
delinquent billings or water service terminated due to nonpayment shall pay a
meter deposit in the amount of $100 ($40 of which shall be refunded after one
year of continuous service).
      (3)   Said deposit shall be made by the customer making application for
the respective service, and who shall be responsible for the monthly billings.
Said representative deposits, less than the amount of any current and/or
delinquent bills owing, shall be refunded to said customer at such time as said
customer requests disconnection or termination of the respective service.
      (4)   In regards to “lawn meters,” the fee for a lawn meter shall be $100
($50 of which shall be refunded to the customer when the lawn meter is returned
to the waterworks at disconnection or termination of services in regard to the
use of lawn meters). For existing customers who have paid a fee for a lawn
meter prior to this May 25, 2004, then the amount refunded shall be one-half of
the amount paid.
      (5)   The fee to purchase a lawn meter shall be $75. The specific rules
and regulations regarding the lawn meter program will be set forth by the Board
of Public Works and Safety.
   (J)   Collection and deferred payment charges.
      (1)   All bills for water services not paid within 15 days from the due
date thereof, as stated in such bills, shall be subject to the collection or
deferred payment charge of 10% on the first $35 and 3% on the excess over $3.
      (2)   The Common Council elects to receive payment in lieu of taxes from
the waterworks and to earn a reasonable return on net utility plant on sales
for resale.
(Ord. 12-2008, passed 1-13-2009; Ord. 11-2012, passed 9-19-2012; Ord. 10-2014,
passed 12-10-2014; Ord. 13-2014, passed 12-10-2014; Ord. 10-2020, passed 5-13-
2020) Penalty, see §
53.999
§ 53.113 PUBLIC FIRE PROTECTION RATES.
   (A)   The amount to be paid by the city for fire hydrant rental per year is
$200 per year.
   (B)   When the city desires water for flushing a city sewer which has become
clogged, and satisfactory notice is given the waterworks by a city official
that the water is desired, the waterworks will send one of its people to open a
fire hydrant and put a hose valve on the same so that the water can be
controlled by the city employees without using the main valve on the fire
hydrant. The fire hydrant must be opened by an employee of the waterworks. No
charge will be made for the water or the service.
(Prior Code, § 53.028) (Ord. 21-1931, passed 9-22-1931; Ord. 9-1981, passed 5-
26-1981)

   (A)   The following rates for private fire protection service are based on
the size of the service pipe entering the building or grounds and which, in any

pipes, stand-pipes and fire hydrants.
   (B)   The rates for yearly service, payable in advance are:

   (C)   The amount to be paid for private fire hydrant service shall be $200

   (A)   Any person violating any provision of this chapter for which no
specific penalty is prescribed shall, on conviction thereof, be fined in any
sum not less than $50 nor more than $250 for each offense.
(Prior Code, § 53.999)
   (B)   Any person violating the provisions of §
53.062 shall, on conviction thereof, be fined in any sum not less than $50 nor
more than $250 for each offense.
   (C)   Any person found to have constructed or installed any device in
violation of §
53.094 shall be fined $2,500.

53.095 shall be fined $2,500; this shall not preclude the Board of Public Works
and Safety from collecting from the person a reasonable sum for water used in

53.095, in addition to the fine herein established.
(Prior Code, § 53.073)

CHAPTER 54: CROSS-CONNECTIONS AND BACKFLOW
Section
   
54.01   Responsibility
   
54.02   Definitions
   
54.03   Water system requirements
   
54.04   Compliance
   
54.05   Inspection
   
54.06   Discontinuance of service
   
54.07   Installation of backflow prevention assembly
   
54.08   Type of protective assembly
   
54.09   Approval of backflow prevention assembly
   
54.10   Adoption of standards by reference

§ 54.01 RESPONSIBILITY.
   (A)   The city waterworks shall be responsible for the protection of the
public potable water distribution system from contaminants or pollutants
through the water service connection.
   (B)   If, in the judgment of said waterworks an approved backflow prevention
assembly is required as defined by 327 I.A.C. 8-10, rule for the safety of the
water system, city waterworks shall give notice in writing by mail to said
customer to install such an approved backflow prevention assembly at the
specific consumer’s own expense; and, failure, refusal or inability on the part
of the customer to install, have tested and maintain said assembly shall
constitute a grounds for discontinuing water service to the premises until such
requirements have been satisfactorily met.
(Ord. 4-2011, passed 5-11-2011)
§ 54.02 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   AIR-GAP.
      (1)   The unobstructed vertical distance through the free atmosphere
between the lowest opening from any pipe or faucet supplying water to a tank,
plumbing, fixture or other device and flood level rim of said vessel.
      (2)   An approved AIR-GAP shall be at least double the diameter of the
supply pipe, measured vertically, above the overflow rim of the vessel; and in
no case less than one inch.
   APPROVED. Accepted by the city waterworks as meeting an applicable
specification stated or cited in this chapter, or as suitable for the proposed
use.
   AUXILIARY WATER SUPPLY. Any water supply on or available to the premises
other than the utility’s approved public water supply. These auxiliary waters
may include water from another utility’s public potable water supply or any
natural source(s) such as a well, spring, river, stream and the like, or “used
waters” or “industrial fluids.” These waters may be contaminated or polluted,
or they may be objectionable and constitute an unacceptable water source over
which the water utility does not have sanitary control.
   BACKFLOW. The reversal of the normal flow of water caused by either
backpressure or backsiphonage.
   BACKFLOW PREVENTER. An approved assembly or means designed to prevent
backflow.
   BACKPRESSURE. The flow of water or other liquids, mixtures or substances
under pressure into the distribution pipes of a potable water supply system
from any source or sources other than the intended source.
   BACKSIPHONAGE. The flow of water or other liquids, mixtures or substances
into the distribution pipes of a potable water supply caused by the reduction
of pressure in the potable water supply system.
   CONTAMINATION. An impairment of the quality of the portable water by sewage,
industrial fluids or waste liquids, compounds or other materials to a degree
which created an actual or potential hazard to the public health through
poisoning or through the spread of disease.
   CROSS-CONNECTION. Any physical connection or arrangement of piping or
fixtures between two otherwise separate piping systems, one of which contains
potable water and the other non-potable water or industrial fluids of
questionable safety, through which, or because of which, backflow may occur
into the potable water system.
   CROSS-CONNECTION CONTROL BY CONTAINMENT. The installation of an approved
backflow prevention assembly at the water service connection to any customer’s
premises where actual or potential cross-connections within the customer’s
water system; or it shall mean the installation of an approved backflow
prevention assembly on the service line leading to and supplying a portion of a
customer’s water system where there are actual or potential cross-connections
which cannot be effectively eliminated or controlled at the point of the cross-
connection.
   CROSS-CONNECTIONS CONTROLLED. A connection between a potable water system
and a non-potable water system with an air-gap or approved backflow prevention
assembly properly installed and maintained so that it will continuously afford
the protection commensurate with the degree of hazard.
   DEGREE OF HAZARD. An evaluation of the potential risk to public health and
the adverse effect of the hazard upon the potable water system.
   DOUBLE CHECK VALVE ASSEMBLY. An assembly of two independently operating,
approved check valves with resilient, seated shut-off valves on each end of the
check valves, plus properly located resilient, seated test cocks for testing of
each check valve. The entire assembly shall meet the design and performance
specifications as determined by a laboratory and field evaluation program
resulting in an approval by a recognized and city waterworks approved testing
agency for backflow prevention assemblies. To be approved, these assemblies
must be readily accessible for in-line testing and maintenance. Confined space
installations will not be accepted.
   HEALTH HAZARD. Any condition, device or practice in the water supply system
and its operation, which could create or, in the judgment of the city
waterworks, may create a danger to the health and well-being of the water
consumer.
   INDUSTRIAL FLUIDS SYSTEM. Any system containing a fluid or solution, which
may be chemically, biologically or otherwise contaminated or polluted in a form
or concentration such as would constitute a health, system, pollution or
plumbing hazard if introduced into an approved water supply. This may include,
but not be limited to: Polluted or contaminated water; all types of process
waters and “used water” originating from the public potable water system which
may have deteriorated in sanitary quality; chemicals in fluid form; plating
acids and alkalis; circulating cooling waters connected to an open cooling
tower and/or cooling towers that are chemically or biologically treated or
stabilized with toxic substance; contaminated natural waters such as from
wells, springs, streams, rivers, irrigation canals or systems and the like;
oils, gases, glycerin, paraffin, caustic and acid solutions; and other liquid
and gaseous fluids used in industrial or other purposes or for firefighting
purposes.
   NON-POTABLE WATER. Water which is not safe for human consumption or which is
of questionable potability.
   PLUMBING HAZARD. A plumbing type cross-connection in a consumer’s potable
water system that has not been properly protected by an approved air-gap or
approved backflow prevention assembly.
   POLLUTION. The presence of any foreign substance (organic, inorganic or
biological) in water which tends to degrade its quality so as to constitute a
hazard to the public health but which docs adversely and reasonably affect such
waters for domestic use.
   POLLUTION HAZARD. An actual or potential threat to the physical water system
but which would constitute a nuisance or be aesthetically objectionable or
could cause damage to the system or its appurtenances, but would not be
dangerous to health.
   POTABLE WATER. Any water which, according to recognized standards, is safe
for human consumption.
   REDUCED PRESSURE PRINCIPAL ASSEMBLIES. An assembly of two independently
acting approved check valves together with a hydraulically operating,
mechanically independent differential pressure relief valve located between the
check valves and at the same time, below the first check valve, the unit shall
include properly located resilient seated test cocks and resilient shut-off
valves at each end of the assembly.
      (1)   The entire assembly shall meet the design and performance
specifications as determined by a laboratory and a field evaluation program
resulting in an approval by a recognized and city waterworks approved testing
agency for backflow prevention assemblies. The assembly shall operate to
maintain the pressure in the zone between the check valves at an acceptable
level less than the pressure on the public water supply side of the assembly.
      (2)   At cessation of a normal flow, the pressure between the two check
valves shall be less than the pressure on the public water supply side of the
assembly. In case of leakage of either of the check valves, the differential
relief valve shall operate to maintain the reduced pressure in the zone between
the check valves by discharging to the atmosphere. When the inlet pressure is
two pounds per square inch or less, the relief valve shall open to the
atmosphere. To be approved, these assemblies must be readily accessible for
inline testing and maintenance and be installed in a location where no part of
the assembly will be submerged. Confined space installations will not be
approved.
   SUPERINTENDENT. The Superintendent of the Water Department of the city who
is vested with the authority and responsibility for the implementation of an
effective cross-connection control program and for the enforcement of the
provisions of this chapter.
   SYSTEM HAZARD. An actual or potential threat of severe damage to the
physical properties of the public potable water system or the consumer’s
potable water system or of a pollution or contamination which would have a
protracted effect on the quality of the potable water in the system.
   USED WATER. Any water supplied by a water utility from a public potable
water system to a consumer’s water system after it has passed through the point
of delivery and is no longer under the sanitary control of the water utility.
   WATER SERVICE CONNECTION. The terminal end of a service connection from the
public potable water system; i.e., where the water utility loses jurisdiction
and sanitary control over the water at its point of delivery to the customer’s
water system. If a meter is installed at the end of the SERVICE CONNECTION,
then the SERVICE CONNECTION shall mean the downstream end of the meter is
installed inside a building, then the water utility jurisdiction terminates at
the downstream end of the outside shut off valve to the water service. There
should be no unprotected takeoffs from the service line ahead of any meter or
ahead of any backflow prevention assembly. Service connection shall also
include water service connection from a fire hydrant and all other temporary or
emergency WATER SERVICE CONNECTIONS from the public potable water system.
(Ord. 4-2011, passed 5-11-2011)
§ 54.03 WATER SYSTEM REQUIREMENTS.
   The water system shall be considered as made up of two parts, the utility
system and the customer system.
   (A)   The utility system shall consist of the source facilities and the
distribution system and shall include all air-gaps or approved backflow
prevention assemblies properly installed and components of the facilities
utilized in the production, treatment, storage and delivery of water to the
distribution system. The distribution system shall include the network of mains
used for the delivery of water from the source to the customer’s system.
   (B)   The customer’s system shall include those parts of the facilities
beyond the termination of the utility distribution system which are utilized in
conveying utility-delivered domestic water to points of use.
(Ord. 4-2011, passed 5-11-2011)
§ 54.04 COMPLIANCE.
   No water service connection to any premises shall be installed or maintained
by the city waterworks unless the water supply is protected as required by
state rules and regulations of this chapter. Service of water to any premises
by this chapter is not installed, tested and maintained, or if it is found that
a backflow prevention assembly has been removed or bypassed, or if an
unprotected cross-connection exists on the premises. Service will not be
restored until such conditions or defects are corrected.
(Ord. 4-2011, passed 5-11-2011) Penalty, see §
54.99
§ 54.05 INSPECTION.
   The customer’s system must be open for inspection at all reasonable times to
authorized representatives of the city waterworks to determine whether there
exist cross-connections or other structural or sanitary hazards, including
violations of this chapter or regulations which are adopted through this
chapter.
(Ord. 4-2011, passed 5-11-2011) Penalty, see §
54.99
§ 54.06 DISCONTINUANCE OF SERVICE.
   When a volatile condition becomes known, the Superintendent may deny or
immediately discontinue service to the premises by providing for a physical
break in the service line until the customer has connected the condition(s) in
conformance with the state statutes and city ordinances relating to plumbing
and water supplies and the regulations adopted pursuant thereto.
(Ord. 4-2011, passed 5-11-2011)
§ 54.07 INSTALLATION OF BACKFLOW PREVENTION ASSEMBLY.
   An approved backflow prevention assembly, as defined by the IDEM Rule,
I.A.C. 8-10, shall also be installed on each service line to a customer’s water
system at or near the property line or immediately inside the building being
serviced; but, in all cases, before the first branch line leading off the
service line wherever the following conditions exist.
   (A)   In the case of premises having an auxiliary water supply which is not
or may not be of safe bacteriological or chemical quality and which is not
acceptable as an additional source by the city waterworks, the public water
system shall be protected against backflow from the premises by installing an
approved backflow prevention assembly in the service line appropriate to the
degree of hazard.
   (B)   In the case of premises on which any industrial fluids or any other
objectionable substance is handled in such a fashion as to create an actual or
potential hazard to the public water system, the public system shall be
protected against backflow from the premises by installing an approved backflow
prevention assembly in the service line appropriate to the degree of hazard.
This shall include the handling of process waters and waters originating from
the utility system which have been subject to deterioration in quality.
   (C)   In the case of premises having internal cross-connection that cannot
be permanently corrected or controlled, or intricate plumbing and piping
arrangements, or where entry to all portions of the premises are not readily
accessible for inspection purposes, making it impractical or impossible to
ascertain whether or not dangerous cross-connections exist, the public water
system shall be protected against backflow from the premises by installing an
approved backflow prevention assembly in the service line or lines where
potential hazards could exist.
(Ord. 4-2011, passed 5-11-2011)
§ 54.08 TYPE OF PROTECTIVE ASSEMBLY.
   The type of protective assembly required shall depend upon the degree of
hazard which exists as follows.
   (A)   In the case of any premises where there is an auxiliary water supply,
the public water system shall be protected by an approved backflow prevention
assembly as defined by the IDEM Rule, 327 I.A.C. 8-10.
   (B)   In the case of any premises where there is water or a substance that
would be objectionable but not hazardous to health if introduced into the
public water system, the public water system shall be protected by an approved
double check valve assembly.
   (C)   (1)   In the case of any premises where there is any material
dangerous to the health such as to create an actual or potential hazard to the
public water system, the public water system shall be protected by an approved
air-gap separation or an approved reduced pressure principle backflow
prevention assembly.
      (2)   Examples of premises where these conditions will exist include, but
are not limited to, sewage treatment plants, sewage pumping stations, chemical
manufacturing plants, hospitals, mortuaries and planting plants.
   (D)   In the case of any premises where there are uncontrolled cross-
connections, either actual or potential, the public water system shall be
protected by an approved air-gap separation or an approved reduced pressure
principle backflow prevention assembly at the service connection.
   (E)   In the case of any premises where, because of security requirements or
other prohibitions or restrictions, it is impossible or impractical to make a
complete in-plant cross-connection survey, the public water system shall be
protected against backflow from the premises by either an approved air-gap
separation or an approved reduced pressure principle backflow prevention
assembly on each service to the premises.
   (F)   In case of any premises having a lawn irrigation system, the public
water system shall be protected by an approved pressure vacuum breaker backflow
prevention assembly or an approved reduced pressure principle backflow
prevention assembly.
(Ord. 4-2011, passed 5-11-2011)
§ 54.09 APPROVAL OF BACKFLOW PREVENTION ASSEMBLY.
   (A)   Any backflow prevention assembly required herein shall be a model and
size approved by the city waterworks.
   (B)   For the purpose of this section, the term APPROVED BACKFLOW PREVENTION
ASSEMBLY shall mean an assembly that has been manufactured in full conformance
with the standards established by the American Water Works Association (AWWA)
entitled AWWA C506-84 Standards for Reduced Pressure Principle and Double Check
Valve Backflow Prevention Devices. Said assembly shall meet the laboratory and
field performance specifications of the Foundation for Cross-Connection Control
and Hydraulic Research (FCCC&HR) of the University of Southern California
established by Specifications of Backflow Prevention Assemblies and by § 10 of
the most current issue of the Manual of Cross-Connection Control. Final
approval shall be evidenced by a certificate of approval issued by an approved
testing laboratory certifying full compliance with the said AWWA standards and
FCCC&HR specifications.
(Ord. 4-2011, passed 5-11-2011)
§ 54.10 ADOPTION OF STANDARDS BY REFERENCE.
   The AWWA and FCCC&HR standard and specifications specifically referenced in
§
54.09 are hereby adopted and incorporated herein by reference.
(Ord. 4-2011, passed 5-11-2011)
§ 54.11 DUTY TO TEST AND REPAIR.
   (A)   It shall be the duty of the customer or user at any premises where
backflow prevention assemblies are installed to have certified inspections and
operational tests made upon installations and at least once per year. In those
instances where the Waterworks Superintendent deems the hazard to be great
enough, the Superintendent may require certified inspections at more frequent
intervals.
   (B)   These inspections and tests shall be at the expense of the water user
and shall be performed by a certified tester approved by the state and the city
waterworks. It shall be the duty of the city waterworks to see that these tests
are made in a timely manner. If a customer or user does not have its backflow
prevention assembly tested within 30 days of notification, city waterworks may
discontinue water service to the premises to maintain the safety of the public
water system.
   (C)   These assemblies shall be repaired, overhauled or replaced at the
expense of the customer or user whenever said assemblies are found to be
defective. Records of such tests, repairs and overhaul shall be kept and made
available to the city waterworks.
(Ord. 4-2011, passed 5-11-2011)
§ 54.12 EXEMPTIONS.
   All presently installed backflow prevention assemblies which do not meet the
requirements of this section that were approved devices for the purposes
described herein at the time of installation and which have been properly
maintained, shall be excluded from the requirement of these rules so long as
the city waterworks is assured that they will satisfactorily protect the
utility system. However, whenever the existing device is moved from the present
location, fails testing or requires more than minimum maintenance or when the
city waterworks finds that the assembly or its maintenance constitutes a hazard
to health, the unit shall be replaced, at the consumer’s expense, by an
approved backflow prevention assembly meeting the requirement of this section.
(Ord. 4-2011, passed 5-11-2011)
§ 54.13 CERTIFICATION OF TESTERS.
   Certified testers shall be listed with the city waterworks and shall provide
proof of six contact hours annually of approved continuing education to the
city waterworks. In addition, certified testers will provide proof that test
gauges used in testing backflow prevention assemblies have been calibrated and
certified annually.
(Ord. 4-2011, passed 5-11-2011)
§ 54.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter for which no other penalty is
otherwise specifically provided shall be fined not more than $1,000. A separate
offense shall be deemed committed on each day that a violation occurs or
continues.
(Ord. 4-2011, passed 5-11-2011)
