GENERAL PROVISIONS
§ 70.01 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this traffic code, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   AUTHORIZED EMERGENCY VEHICLE. Vehicles of the Fire Department, state and
county, and municipal police departments and ambulances when on emergency calls
shall be considered AUTHORIZED EMERGENCY VEHICLES.
   INDIVIDUAL PARKING SPACE. A portion of the paved surface of the street of
sufficient length or depth from the sidewalk curb to accommodate a vehicle to
be parked, as shall be specified and marked off by the Board of Public Works
and Safety.
   INTERSECTION. The area embraced within the prolongation of the lateral curb
lines or, if none, then the lateral boundary lines of two or more streets or
highways which join one another at an angle, whether or not one of the streets
or highways crosses the other.
   OPERATOR. Any person in actual control of any vehicle.
   PARKING. The standing of a vehicle on a street, whether the vehicle is
occupied or not, and whether the vehicle is occupied or not by an operator for
a period of time in excess of two minutes.
   PEDESTRIAN. Any person afoot.
   SILENT POLICE OFFICER. Any suitable device, safety zone, post, sign,
standard or automatic signal light placed within any street or public place as
a warning or for control or direction of traffic.
   TRAFFIC OFFICE. The police headquarters of the city.
   VEHICLE. Any motor vehicle, automobile, motorcycle, truck, trailer, semi-
trailer, truck tractor, bus, school bus, recreational vehicle, construction
vehicle, tractor and bicycle.
(Prior Code, § 70.01) (Ord. 6-1980, passed 5-2-1980; Ord. 8-1984, passed 10-23-
1984)
§ 70.02 POLICE DEPARTMENT’S DUTY TO ENFORCE TRAFFIC REGULATIONS.
   (A)   It shall be the duty of the Police Department of this city to enforce
the provisions of this title. Officers of the Police Department are authorized
to direct all traffic either in person or by means of visible or audible signal
in conformance with the provisions of this title; provided, that in the event
of a fire or other emergency or to expedite traffic or to safeguard
pedestrians, officers of the Police or Fire Departments may direct traffic as
conditions may require, notwithstanding the provisions of this title.
   (B)   The Police Department is empowered to make and enforce regulations
necessary to make effective the provisions of this chapter and to make and
enforce temporary regulations to cover emergencies.
(Prior Code, § 70.02) (Ord. 8-1931, passed 9-22-1931)
§ 70.03 OBEDIENCE TO POLICE DEPARTMENT OFFICIALS REQUIRED.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to refuse or to fail to comply with any
lawful order, signal or direction of a police officer.
(Prior Code, § 70.03) (Ord. 8-1931, passed 9-22-1931) Penalty, see §
70.99
§ 70.04 NOTIFICATION OF VIOLATION; FILING OF CITATION.
   (A)   Whenever a member of the Police Department shall observe violations of
§§
70.03,
70.40 through
70.43,
71.01 through
71.13 or
Ch. 73, Sch. II, by the operator of any vehicle, the officer shall notify the
operator in writing by the issuance to the violator a citation stating the
violation, the license number plus make and year of the vehicle, the violator’s
name and address, the violator’s drivers license number, the date and location
of the violation and the date of initial court appearance. The original
citation shall be filed in the County Superior Court or any other proper court
of competent jurisdiction to hear ordinance violations in the city. A copy of
the citation shall also be filed in the office of the City Clerk-Treasurer who
will forward the same to the City Attorney for prosecution.
   (B)   Whenever a member of the Police Department shall observe violations by
any person of any other provisions of this title not specifically set forth in
division (A) above, the officer shall notify the operator in writing by the
issuance to the violator a citation stating the violation, the license number,
the make and year of the vehicle, the violator’s name and address (if
available) and the date and location of the violation. The original citation
shall be filed at the office of the City Clerk-Treasurer. The violator shall
present himself or herself with the copy of the citation at the office of the
City Clerk-Treasurer for the purpose of paying the proper penalty within 72
hours after the date of issuance. If the violator fails to appear and pay the
appropriate penalty, the Clerk-Treasurer shall notify the City Attorney who
shall file, or cause to be filed, in the County Superior Court or other court
of competent jurisdiction to hear ordinance violations, an affidavit charging
the violator with the violation specified in the citation.
   (C)   Whenever a member of the Police Department shall observe violations of
any provisions of
Ch. 74, the violators and citations shall be processed pursuant to the
provisions of division (A) above.
(Prior Code, § 70.04) (Ord. 7-2002, passed 5-14-2002) Penalty, see §
70.99
§ 70.05 PARKING IN CERTAIN AREAS RESTRICTED.
   (A)   Parking of certain types of trailers, as hereinafter defined, on the
streets within the corporate limits of the city, with a zoning district
designation as an “R District, Residential” as provided for under the Zoning
Code is restricted in that no person shall stop, stand or park certain types of
trailers, as defined herein, upon any street within an “R District,
Residential” area designation under the Zoning Code and within the corporate
limits of the city, except as follows:
      (1)   While expeditiously loading or unloading passengers, freight,
materials or merchandise between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 9:00 p.m.;
      (2)   While affecting emergency repairs when a vehicle is so disabled as
to render it unsafe to proceed further;
      (3)   Vehicle and equipment engaged in street construction, maintenance
and repair, or the construction, maintenance or repair of public service
utilities; and
      (4)   Vehicles serving as emergency vehicles.
   (B)   (1)   For the purpose of this section, SEMI-TRAILER applies to semi-
trailers defined as a trailer that is in excess of 25 feet in length and is the
type of trailer that has wheels only at the rear, requiring the front end to be
supported by a towing vehicle, which is not an automobile, a van, a mini-van,
an SUV or a pickup truck.
      (2)   Measurements for length shall be the overall length of the trailer,
including the hitch, if it extends beyond the trailer body.
   (C)   Any trailer, as defined herein, found stopped, standing or parked in
violation of any provision of this section is subject to being removed and
impounded at the owner’s expense.
   (D)   (1)   This section incorporates by reference
Ch. 73, which may further restrict parking in regard to the streets contained
within the corporate limits of the city.
      (2)   Further, parking may further be restricted by the rest and
remainder of the sections contained in this title.
(Prior Code, § 70.05) (Ord. 14-2006, passed 4-25-2006) Penalty, see §
70.99
§ 70.06 VEHICLE IMPOUND RELEASE FEE.
   (A)   Police Department impound service fee. All vehicle owners or lien
holders who have a vehicle impounded due to an enforcement action taken by the
Police Department shall be responsible for payment in the amount of $100 for a
vehicle impound release fee.
   (B)   Proof of vehicle ownership. The owner must provide proof of ownership
by submitting a state vehicle registration that lists the person as the owner
or a properly completed title for the vehicle showing ownership. Proof of
ownership is supplied to the Police Department for determination.
   (C)   Impound release receipt. An impound release receipt will be provided
to the vehicle owner once ownership is established and the impound release fee
is paid. The owner will then take the impound release receipt to the towing
service and pay all tow fees that are due to the towing service for removing
the vehicle.
   (D)   Police Continuing Education Fund. There is an established fund known
as the Law Enforcement Continuing Education Fund for the purpose of purchases
made by the Police Department for equipment, supplies, continuing education and
law enforcement training. The Fund shall be comprised of fees collected by the
Police Department from the following actions:
      (1)   Vehicle inspections;
      (2)   Accident/crash reports;
      (3)   Handgun permit licenses;
      (4)   Background checks; and
      (5)   Impound releases.
(Ord. 1-2017, passed 4-12-2017)
SPEED BUMPS AND OTHER SPEED MODIFICATIONS
§ 70.20 MANDATORY PROCEDURES GOVERNING SPEED CONTROL MODIFICATIONS.
   The following procedure must be strictly followed before a speed bump or
other traffic or speed control modifications of the surface or grade of any
public street or alley way can be constructed or made by any elected or
appointed officials of the city and any employee or agent of the city or by any
contractor or citizen of the city.
(Prior Code, § 70.15) (Res. 3-1992, passed 12-22-1992)
§ 70.21 CITY AGENCIES INVOLVED.
   A written request shall be submitted by the Supervisor of the City Street
Department to the Board of Public Works and Safety (hereinafter referred to as
“Board.”) Prior to submission, the request shall be submitted to the Chief of
the Police Department for investigation and approval. The Chief shall sign the
request either approving or disapproving the request and state the reasons
therefor. If the Chief determines or desires to recommend modifications or
alternative to the written request, he or she may do so thereon prior to
signing the same.
(Prior Code, § 70.16) (Res. 3-1992, passed 12-22-1992)
§ 70.22 CONTENT OF WRITTEN REQUESTS AND ROLE OF AFFECTED RESIDENTS.
   (A)   The request shall state the actual location of the proposed placement
or removal of the speed bump or speed control modification and the reason
therefor.
   (B)   Accompanying the request shall be a written approval for the proposed
placement, removal or modification signed by at least 75% of the residents
located within the block of the proposed modification plus those located at
least one block of either side of the affected block.
(Prior Code, § 70.17) (Res. 3-1992, passed 12-22-1992)
§ 70.23 DESIGN AND CONSTRUCTION OF SPEED CONTROL MODIFICATIONS.
   Any speed bump or speed control modification must be so designed and
constructed that a traveling vehicle may proceed over the same at the speed of
at least 20 mph without causing damages to the vehicle or severe jarring of the
driver thereof or, in the alternative, in compliance with state or nationally
approved design requirements therefor.
(Prior Code, § 70.18) (Res. 3-1992, passed 12-22-1992)
§ 70.24 NOTICE AND HEARING REQUIREMENTS OF BOARD INITIAL DETERMINATION.
   (A)   Upon the submission of the written request, the Board shall advertise
for and hold a public hearing on the request which shall be open to the public.
Published notice of the hearing shall be placed in a newspaper of general
circulation within the city, pursuant to I.C. 5-3-1.
   (B)   At the conclusion of the public hearing, the Board shall determine
whether to approve or deny the request and so indicate its reasons for its
decision. A majority of the Board is necessary for approval of the request.
(Prior Code, § 70.19) (Res. 3-1992, passed 12-22-1992)
§ 70.25 ROLE OF BOARD OF PUBLIC WORKS AND SAFETY.
   Following six months after the placement, removal or modification of the
street or alleyway as approved by the Board, the Board shall advertise for and
hold a public hearing which shall be open to the public to review its initial
determination and to receive public input regarding that determination.
Following that hearing, the Board may reverse, modify or affirm its initial
determination if it determines that the public welfare and safety are adversely
affected thereby.
(Prior Code, § 70.20) (Res. 3-1992, passed 12-22-1992)
TRAFFIC-CONTROL DEVICES
§ 70.40 OBEDIENCE TO TRAFFIC-CONTROL DEVICES.
   It shall be unlawful for any operator of any vehicle to disobey the
instructions of any official traffic sign or signal placed in accordance with
the provisions of this subchapter, unless otherwise directed by a police
officer.
(Prior Code, § 71.01) (Ord. 8-1931, passed 9-22-1931) Penalty, see §
70.99
§ 70.41 TRAFFIC-CONTROL SIGNAL LEGEND.
   (A)   At all places where the silent police officers are placed, drivers or
operators of vehicles shall be controlled by the warning or direction given
thereby.
   (B)   Whenever traffic at an intersection is alternately directed to proceed
and to stop by the use of automatic colored lights or the words “GO” or
“CAUTION” and “STOP,” these lights are terms shall indicate as follows.
      (1)   GREEN or GO. Traffic facing the signal may proceed, except that
vehicular traffic shall yield the right-of-way to pedestrians and vehicles
lawfully within a crosswalk or the intersection at the time the signal was
exhibited.
      (2)   CENTER or MIDDLE YELLOW or CAUTION. When shown following the green
or “GO” signal. Traffic facing the signal shall stop before entering the
intersection unless so close to the intersection that a stop cannot be made in
safety.
      (3)   RED or STOP. Traffic facing the signal shall stop before entering
the intersection and remain standing until the green or “GO” signal is shown.
(Prior Code, § 71.02) (Ord. 8-1931, passed 9-22-1931)
§ 70.42 INTERFERENCE WITH OFFICIAL TRAFFIC-CONTROL DEVICES PROHIBITED.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to willfully deface, injure, move,
obstruct or interfere with any official traffic sign or signal.
(Prior Code, § 71.03) (Ord. 8-1931, passed 9-22-1931) Penalty, see 70.99
§ 70.43 ESTABLISHMENT OF SAFETY ZONES, BUS STOP ZONES AND TAXICAB STANDS.
   (A)   The Common Council’s Committee on Public Safety is empowered to
establish safety zones of a kind and character and at places as it may deem
necessary for the protection of pedestrians.
   (B)   Safety zones shall be marked off and indicated by painted lines,
discs, standards or loading platforms.
   (C)   The Committee shall also have the power to establish bus stop zones
and taxicab stands.
   (D)   It shall be unlawful for the operator of a vehicle at any time to
drive the same through or over or to the left of any safety zone so established
as herein provided.
(Prior Code, § 71.04) (Ord. 8-1931, passed 9-22-1931) Penalty, see §
70.99
MOVING TRAFFIC VIOLATION DEFERRAL PROGRAM
§ 70.55 PROGRAM USER FUND.
   There is created a Moving Traffic Violation Deferral Program User Fund
within the City Department of Law Budget.
(Prior Code, § 72.01) (Ord. 8-1997, passed 5-13-1997)
§ 70.56 PROGRAM ESTABLISHED.
   It is the desire of the City Attorney, in agreement with the Police
Department, to create and establish a moving traffic deferral program pursuant
to I.C. 34-28-5-1, whereby any person charged with a moving traffic violation
pursuant to the ordinances of the city may enter the deferral program by
executing a written deferral agreement and paying required user fees in lieu of
admitting the violation or having the violation tried before the court in which
the violation charge is filed.
(Prior Code, § 72.02) (Ord. 8-1997, passed 5-13-1997)
§ 70.57 USER FEES ESTABLISHED.
   Pursuant to I.C. 34-28-5-1 and 33-37-4-2, any person charged with a moving
traffic violation pursuant to the ordinances of the city and agreeing to enter
into the deferral program shall be required to pay an initial user’s fee of $52
and a monthly user’s fee of $10 as part of the City Attorney’s deferral program
agreement.
(Ord. 11-2007, passed 9-28-2007)
§ 70.58 PAYMENT OF TRAFFIC VIOLATION DEFERRAL PROGRAM FEES.
   (A)   The initial and monthly user’s fees, along with an additional
statutory fee, as provided in I.C. 34-28-5-1(f)(4), shall be collected by the
City Attorney or the administrator of the deferral program appointed by the
City Attorney and approved by the Board of Public Works and Safety.
   (B)   The fees shall then be deposited by the City Attorney or the program
administrator to the court clerk in which the violation is filed pursuant to
I.C. 34-28-5-1.
   (C)   The clerk of the court shall transfer collected deferral program
user’s fees to the City Clerk-Treasurer within 30 days after they are collected
pursuant to I.C. 33-37-5-17.
(Ord. 11-2007, passed - -2007)
§ 70.59 USAGE OF FUNDS FROM THE PROGRAM.
   The City Attorney shall have control over the use of the collected deferral
program user fees in the fund. At his or her discretion, the funds may be
dispersed therefrom to fund requested needs and equipment for the Police
Department or the Department of Law in the administration of the deferral
program or the prosecution of moving traffic violation ordinances.
(Prior Code, § 72.05) (Ord. 8-1997, passed 5-13-1997)
§ 70.60 DURATION OF PROGRAM.
   (A)   The Moving Traffic Violation Deferral Program User Fund shall be
perpetual until terminated at the request of the City Attorney, pursuant to
this subchapter.
   (B)   This Fund may be terminated at the request of the City Attorney by the
enactment of an ordinance, and any fund balance in that fund shall be
transferred to the City General Fund to be used for any purposes lawfully
allowed.
(Prior Code, § 72.06) (Ord. 8-1997, passed 5-13-1997)
§ 70.99 PENALTY.
   (A)   (1)   Any person violating the provisions of this title shall be
subject to a civil penalty of $12. The violator shall also be responsible for
court costs for any violations filed in court in addition to the civil penalty.
      (2)   A separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day that a
violation occurs or continues.
      (3)   Any vehicle illegally parked shall be subject to being removed,
towed and stored at the owner’s expense.
(Prior Code, § 70.99)
   (B)   (1)   Whoever violates any provisions of §§
70.40 through
70.43 for which no penalty is otherwise provided shall be fined subject to a
civil penalty of not less than $65 and not more than $200.
      (2)   The penalty for the first violation shall be $65; for the second
violation $100; and for each subsequent violation $200.
      (3)   A separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day that a
violation occurs or continues.
(Prior Code, § 71.99)
(Ord. 6-1994, passed 5-24-1994; Ord. 7-2002, passed 5-14-2002)

GENERAL PROVISIONS
§ 71.01 STOP REQUIRED BEFORE EMERGING FROM AN ALLEY, PRIVATE DRIVE OR BUILDING.
   It shall be unlawful to drive a motor vehicle from any alley, driveway or
building into any public street without first bringing the vehicle to a full
stop at or immediately before the edge of the improved surface of the street.
(Prior Code, § 73.01) (Ord. 10-1970, passed 10-13-1970) Penalty, see §
71.99
§ 71.02 OVERTAKING AND PASSING VEHICLES.
   (A)   The operator of a vehicle shall not overtake and pass on the left of
any street or inter-urban car proceeding in the same direction, whether
actually in motion or temporarily at rest.
   (B)   The operator of a vehicle overtaking any street or inter-urban car
stopped or about to stop for the purpose of receiving or discharging any
passenger shall stop the vehicle at a distance not less than six feet from the
rear thereof and shall keep the vehicle stationary until any passenger has
boarded the vehicle or reached a place of safety, except that where a safety
zone has been established, a vehicle need not be stopped before passing any
vehicle, but may proceed past the vehicle with due caution for the safety of
pedestrians.
   (C)   The drivers in meeting other vehicles shall pass to the right thereof
and in overtaking other vehicles shall pass on the left side of the vehicle
overtaken.
(Prior Code, § 73.02) (Ord. 10-1970, passed 10-13-1970) Penalty, see §
71.99
§ 71.03 OPERATING VEHICLES ON APPROACH OF EMERGENCY VEHICLE.
   (A)   Authorized emergency vehicles are given the right-of-way over all
other vehicles.
   (B)   On the approach of any authorized emergency vehicle giving audible
signal by bell or horn or siren and/or having its emergency lights flashing,
the operator of every other vehicle shall immediately drive the same to a
position as near as possible and parallel to the right-hand edge or curb of the
highway, clear of any intersection.
   (C)   The operator/driver shall stop and remain in that position until the
authorized emergency vehicle shall have passed, unless otherwise directed by a
Police or Fire Department officer.
   (D)   The operator/driver shall not drive the same into any street
intersection if a Police or Fire Department or other authorized emergency
vehicle are approaching the street intersection within 500 feet thereof.
(Prior Code, § 73.03) (Ord. 8-1931, passed 9-22-1931) Penalty, see §
71.99
§ 71.04 HANGING ON OR ATTACHING TO VEHICLES.
   It shall be unlawful for any person traveling on any bicycle, motorcycle,
coaster, sled, roller skates or any toy vehicle to cling to, or attach himself
or herself or his or her vehicle to any other moving vehicle on any highway in
the city.
(Prior Code, § 73.04) (Ord. 8-1931, passed 9-22-1931) Penalty, see §
71.99
§ 71.05 CROSSING FIRE HOSES.
   No vehicle shall be driven over any unprotected hose of the Fire Department
when laid down on any street, private driveway to be used at any alarm of fire,
without the consent of the Fire Department official in command.
(Prior Code, § 73.05) (Ord. 8-1931, passed 9-22-1931) Penalty, see §
71.99
§ 71.06 SOLICITING RIDES PROHIBITED.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to stand in a highway for the purpose of
soliciting a ride from the operator of any private vehicle.
(Prior Code, § 73.06) (Ord. 8-1931, passed 9-22-1931) Penalty, see §
71.99
§ 71.07 DRIVING THROUGH FUNERAL OR OTHER PROCESSIONS PROHIBITED.
   It shall be unlawful for the operator of any vehicle or bus to drive the
same between the vehicles comprising a funeral procession or any authorized
civic, military or public procession while the vehicles comprising the
procession are in motion; provided, that the vehicles are conspicuously so
designated.
(Prior Code, § 73.07) (Ord. 8-1931, passed 9-22-1931) Penalty, see §
71.99
§ 71.08 FOLLOWING EMERGENCY VEHICLES RESTRICTED.
   It shall be unlawful for the operator of any vehicle to follow closer than
300 feet to any fire apparatus traveling in response to a fire alarm, or to
drive into or stop any vehicle within one block where the fire apparatus has
stopped in answer to a fire alarm.
(Prior Code, § 73.08) (Ord. 8-1931, passed 9-22-1931) Penalty, see §
71.99
§ 71.09 LOAD LIMITS.
   During the months of February, March and April of each year, the Board of
Public Works and Safety is authorized and instructed to have posted load limits
imposed on certain streets in the city as is appropriate to prevent damage from
being done to the street from heavy vehicles.
(Prior Code, § 73.09) (Ord. 11-1966, passed 4-26-1966)
§ 71.10 TRACTION ENGINES AND HEAVY MACHINE RESTRICTIONS AND REQUIREMENTS;
LIABILITY.
   (A)   It is made unlawful for any person in charge of any traction engine or
other heavy machine likely to injure any paved street in the city, to drive or
run the same on, over or along any paved street in the city, except as provided
this section.
   (B)   When it shall become necessary, in the movement of any traction engine
or other heavy machine, to pass the same over any paved street crossing, the
person in charge of the same shall apply to the city engineer for a permit to
run the engine or machine over the paved crossing.
   (C)   The engineer, before permitting the passage of the engine or machine
over a paved crossing shall require the person in charge thereof to lay heavy
planks over the crossing on which the engine or machine shall be moved and the
same shall be done in a manner so as to effectually protect the paved crossing
from injury and should injury occur to any paved street or crossing by reason
of an engine or machine passing over the same, then the owner of the engine or
machine shall be liable to the city for the injury, notwithstanding the permit.
(Prior Code, § 73.10) (Ord. 8-1931, passed 9-22-1931) Penalty, see §
71.99
§ 71.11 OBSTRUCTING TRAFFIC AND OPEN EXHAUST OR CUT-OUTS PROHIBITED.
   (A)   All vehicles traveling or being driven at a slow rate of speed shall
keep as near as possible to the proper side of the street so that other
vehicles driven at a higher rate of speed may pass the same on the left-hand
side without inconvenience and so as to obstruct as little of the side of the
street as is reasonably possible and facilitates public travel.
   (B)   The driving of a motor vehicle with the exhaust or cut-out open and
unmuffled is strictly forbidden.
(Prior Code, § 73.11) (Ord. 8-1931, passed 9-22-1931) Penalty, see §
71.99
§ 71.12 CROSSING STREETS, TURN AND U-TURN REGULATIONS.
   The drivers of motor vehicles and other vehicles shall not cross any streets
or turn a vehicle therein, except at street intersections.
(Prior Code, § 73.12) (Ord. 8-1931, passed 9-22-1931) Penalty, see §
71.99
§ 71.13 RIDING ON SIDEWALKS RESTRICTED.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to ride or drive any horse or mule, or
to drive any wagon or other vehicle hitched to any horse or mule, or to run or
drive any automobile, motorcycle or other motor vehicle, or to ride any bicycle
on, along or across any sidewalk in the city, unless the same be done in the
necessary act of crossing the sidewalk, and it shall also be unlawful for any
person to hitch any animal in a manner as that the same may get on any
sidewalks.
(Prior Code, § 73.13) (Ord. 8-1931, passed 9-22-1931) Penalty, see §
71.99
SPEED LIMITS GENERALLY
§ 71.25 MAXIMUM SPEED LIMITS ESTABLISHED.
   The maximum speed limit for any motor vehicle being operated on any public
street, alley or public way located within the corporate limits of the city,
shall be 25 mph, unless otherwise posted.
(Prior Code, § 73.25) (Ord. 16-2011, passed 11-9-2011) Penalty, see §
71.99
§ 71.26 UNLAWFUL TO EXCEED MAXIMUM SPEED LIMITS.
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a motor vehicle on any
public street in excess of 25 mph, unless a different speed is otherwise
posted.
   (B)   It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a motor vehicle on any
public street, alley or public way located within the corporate limits of the
city in excess of the posted speed limit.
(Prior Code, § 73.26) (Ord. 10-1997, passed 5-27-1997) Penalty, see §
71.99
TRUCK ROUTES
§ 71.40 FINDINGS BY THE CITY.
   The city has determined that the streets and roads within the corporate
limits of the city are not capable of handling commercial truck traffic.
(Prior Code, § 73.40) (Ord. 1-1990, passed 2-13-1990)
§ 71.41 ROLE OF THE COMMON COUNCIL.
   The Common Council of the city deems it appropriate to designate certain
streets within the city limits under the jurisdiction of the Common Council of
the city to be used for commercial truck traffic.
(Prior Code, § 73.41) (Ord. 1-1990, passed 2-13-1990)
§ 71.42 AUTHORITY TO ESTABLISH REGULATIONS ADDRESSING TRUCK ROUTES.
   The Common Council has the authority to establish a truck route, pursuant to
I.C. 9-20-1-3.
(Prior Code, § 73.42) (Ord. 1-1990, passed 2-13-1990)
§ 71.43 STATE ROAD 59 AND U.S. 40 TRUCK TRAFFIC.
   This subchapter shall in no way supersede laws of the state in regard to the
use of State Road 59 or U.S. 40 for the purposes of truck traffic.
(Prior Code, § 73.44) (Ord. 1-1990, passed 2-13-1990)
EMERGENCY VEHICLE LANES
§ 71.55 PURPOSE.
   It is deemed necessary for the public health and safety that emergency
vehicle lanes be designated and properly marked and posted at or adjacent to
buildings being used or occupied for multi-family residences, or for business
or commercial purposes and that non-emergency type vehicles be prevented from
being parked or left standing in a designated emergency vehicle lanes so that
police, fire and other emergency or rescue vehicles have free and unobstructed
access to bush buildings in order to perform their respective emergency
functions either being impaired by other vehicles parked adjacent to these
buildings as they normally contain large numbers of people who may quickly need
emergency service or evacuation from them during an emergency.
(Prior Code, § 73.55) (Ord. 4-1981, passed 4-13-1981; Ord. 17-1981, passed 10-
12-1981)
§ 71.56 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   BUILDING BEING USED OR OCCUPIED FOR MULTI-FAMILY RESIDENCES OR FOR BUSINESS
OR COMMERCIAL PURPOSES. Any apartment, condominium, high-rise building or
structure used for multi-family housing; any building or structure used for
business office, wholesale or retail and industrial purposes; and any shopping
center or mall project.
   EMERGENCY or EMERGENCY SITUATION. Any occurrence or event that endangers the
health and safety of persons which results in personal injury damage to real or
personal property, and which violates the personal rights and privileges of
innocent people, including, but not necessarily limited to, the commission of
any crime or law violation, a working fire in or near a building or structure,
any occurrence which necessitates immediate medical attention or first aid
treatment and any occurrence which necessitates the evacuation of persons from
any building or structure to avoid personal injury.
   EMERGENCY VEHICLE. Any police patrol car or investigation vehicle, police
prisoner (paddy) wagon, police explosive protection truck and any other vehicle
owned by the Police Department used for responding to police emergencies or
calls, any fire truck, aerial ladder, pumper or snorkel fire suppression truck
or other fire suppression apparatus, fire investigation or prevention
automobile or truck and rescue truck owned by the Fire Department used for
responding to working fires and other fire-related emergencies; any ambulance,
emergency medical or paramedic vehicle, county police vehicle, state police
vehicle, volunteer fire department vehicle or apparatus, civil defense vehicle
and Red Cross vehicle used for responding to emergency situations.
(Prior Code, § 73.56) (Ord. 4-1981, passed 4-13-1981; Ord. 17-1981, passed 10-
12-1981)
§ 71.57 DESIGNATION AND ESTABLISHMENT PROCEDURES.
   (A)   Whenever the owner, manager, tenant or occupant of any building being
used or occupied for multi-family residences, or for business or commercial
purposes desires to establish, adjacent to the building, designated emergency
vehicle lanes, or the Fire Chief, after investigation determine that emergency
vehicle lanes are vital and necessary for the protection of the building and
the health and safety of persons therein, the Fire Chief shall inspect the
location and determine the areas thereof to be designated as emergency vehicle
lanes and notify the owner, manager, tenant or occupant of the building as to
location thereof as well as the proper method of designating the location of
signs to notify the public of the existence of the emergency vehicle lanes.
   (B)   The owner, manager, tenant or occupant of the building must first
request in writing to the Fire Chief his or her desire to establish emergency
vehicle lanes at the building and an inspection for the purpose of determining
the necessity, feasibility and location of lanes.
   (C)   Following an inspection, the Fire Chief shall determine the need for
emergency vehicle lanes and notify in writing the owner, manager, tenant or
occupant of the building as to the proper location of the lanes.
   (D)   The owner, manager or tenant of the building shall be responsible for
having the curb (if one exists in the designated emergency vehicle lane area)
painted yellow, along with the posting and maintenance of signs placed at or
within the emergency vehicle lane area at least five feet high, which indicate
that the area is an emergency vehicle lane, the exact location of the lane and
that the stopping or parking of a vehicle in that area is prohibited except for
emergency vehicles.
   (E)   The owner, manager, tenant or occupant of the building is responsible
for requesting in writing to the Police Chief that the officers of the Police
Department patrol the area of the building and the designated emergency vehicle
lanes, and enforce the provisions of this subchapter pertaining to the
prohibition of any non-emergency vehicle from stopping or parking in the lanes
if the lanes are located on private property. The Police Department has no
authority to enter on private property for the purpose of enforcing this
subchapter without the written permission of the owner, manager, tenant or
occupant thereof.
(Prior Code, § 73.57) (Ord. 4-1981, passed 4-13-1981; Ord. 17-1981, passed 10-
12-1981)
§ 71.58 STOPPING, STANDING AND PARKING PROHIBITED.
   (A)   It shall be unlawful to cause or permit any vehicle, other than
emergency vehicles responding to an emergency situation, to stop, stand, park
or remain in any designated emergency vehicle lane established pursuant to this
subchapter obstructing the access and free passage of any emergency vehicle
responding to an emergency situation or performing an emergency function.
   (B)   A person operating a non-emergency vehicle may stop or park the
vehicle for a period not to exceed ten minutes for the sole purpose of loading
or unloading a handicapped or otherwise physically incapacitated person, and
once the loading or unloading of a person has been accomplished, the vehicle
must be removed from the area.
(Prior Code, § 73.58) (Ord. 4-1981, passed 4-13-1981; Ord. 17-1981, passed 10-
12-1981) Penalty, see §
71.99
§ 71.99 PENALTY.
   (A)   Generally. Any person violating any provision of this chapter for
which no specific penalty is prescribed shall be subject to §
10.99
   (B)   Speed limits. Any person violating the provisions of §§
71.25 or
71.26 shall be fined a civil penalty of $12 plus court costs as established by
the court pursuant to this chapter.
   (C)   Truck routes. A fine of not less than $10 and not more than $100 shall
be levied against operators of any commercial vehicle violating §§
71.40 through
71.43.
   (D)   Emergency vehicle lanes.
      (1)   Any person violating the provisions of §§
71.55 through
71.58 shall be guilty of a Class C infraction and subject to a penalty of $5,
and any vehicle so illegally parked shall, at the officer’s discretion, be
subject to being removed, towed and impounded at the owner’s expense.
      (2)   If the penalty is not paid within ten days from the date of the
offense, the penalty shall be $10.
      (3)   If the penalty is not paid within 30 days from the date of the
offense, the violator shall be summoned into court and be subject to a fine of
up to $500.
      (4)   If a person is issued a second or subsequent citation for violation
of §§
71.55 through
71.58 within a period of one year, the vehicle shall be towed at the owner’s
expense and impounded.
(Prior Code, § 73.99) (Ord. 4-1981, passed 4-13-1981; Ord. 17-1981, passed 10-
12-1981; Ord. 1-1990, passed 2-13-1990; Ord. 10-1997, passed 5-27-1997)
CHAPTER 72: RECREATIONAL VEHICLES

GOLF CARTS AND OFF-ROAD VEHICLES
§ 72.01 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   ALL-TERRAIN VEHICLE.
      (1)   For the purpose of I.C. 14-8-2-185, a motorized, off-highway
vehicle that:
         (a)   Is 50 inches or less in width;
         (b)   Has a dry weight of 1,200 pounds or less;
         (c)   Is designed for travel on at least three non-highway or off-
highway tires; and
         (d)   Is designed for recreational use by one or more individuals.
      (2)   The term includes parts, equipment or attachments sold with the
vehicle.
(I.C. 14-8-2-5.7)
   CITY STREET. The entire width between the boundary lines of every way
publicly maintained when any part of the way is open to the use of the public
for the purpose of vehicular travel within the corporate limits of the city.
   DRIVER’S LICENSE. A valid license to operate a motor vehicle issued by the
state or any other state.
   FINANCIAL RESPONSIBILITY. As set forth in I.C. 9-25-2-3, the ability to
respond in damages for each motor vehicle registered by a person for liability
that arises out of the ownership, maintenance or use of the motor vehicle in
the following amounts:
      (1)   Twenty-five thousand dollars because of bodily injury to or death
of any one person;
      (2)   Subject to the limit in division (1) of this definition, $50,000
because of bodily injury to or death of two or more persons in any one
accident; and
      (3)   Beginning July 1, 2018, $25,000 because of injury to or destruction
of property in any one accident.
   GOLF CART. As set forth in I.C. 9-13-2-69.7, a four-wheeled motor vehicle
originally and specifically designed and intended to transport one or more
individuals and golf clubs for the purpose of playing the game of golf on a
golf course.
   OFF-ROAD VEHICLE. Pursuant to I.C. 9-13-2-117.3, as defined in I.C. 14-8-2-
185 and as follows:
      (1)   For the purpose of I.C. 14-16-1 and I.C. 14-19-1-0.5, a motor-
driven vehicle capable of cross-country travel:
         (a)   Without benefit of a road; and
         (b)   On or immediately over land, water, snow, ice, marsh, swampland
or other natural terrain.
      (2)   The term includes the following:
         (a)   A multi-wheel drive or low-pressure tire vehicle;
         (b)   An amphibious machine;
         (c)   A ground effect air cushion vehicle;
         (d)   An all-terrain vehicle (as defined herein);
         (e)   A recreational off-highway vehicle (as defined herein); and
         (f)   Other means of transportation deriving motive power from a
source other than muscle or wind.
      (3)   The term does not include the following:
         (a)   A farm vehicle being used for farming, including, but not
limited to, a farm wagon (as defined in I.C. 9-13-2-60(2));
         (b)   A vehicle used for military or law enforcement purposes;
         (c)   A construction, mining or other industrial related vehicle used
in performance of the vehicle’s common function, including, but not limited to,
a farm wagon (as defined in I.C. 9-13-2-60(2));
         (d)   A snowmobile (as defined herein);
         (e)   A registered aircraft;
         (f)   Any other vehicle properly registered by the Bureau of Motor
Vehicles;
         (g)   Any watercraft that is registered under state statutes; or
         (h)   A golf cart vehicle.
   OPERATE or OPERATION. To exercise any control over the function or movement
of a golf cart or off-road vehicle.
   RECREATIONAL OFF-ROAD VEHICLE. For the purpose of I.C. 14-8-2-185, a
motorized, off-highway vehicle that:
      (1)   Is 65 inches or less in width;
      (2)   Has a dry weight of 2,000 pounds or less;
      (3)   Is designed for travel on at least four non-highway or off-highway
tires; and
      (4)   Is designed for recreational use by one or more individuals.
(I.C. 14-8-2-233.5)
   SNOWMOBILE. For the purpose of I.C. 14-16, a motor-driven vehicle:
      (1)   Designed for travel primarily on snow or ice; and
      (2)   Of a type that uses:
         (a)   Sled type runners or skis;
         (b)   An endless belt tread; or
         (c)   Any combination of these or other similar means of contact with
the surface upon which the vehicle is operated.
(I.C. 14-8-2-261)
(Ord. 5-2019, passed 3-13-2019)
§ 72.02 OPERATION GENERALLY.
   (A)   Operation of golf carts or off-road vehicles. The operation of golf
carts or off-road vehicles within the city on a city street is strictly
prohibited unless the machine is operated and equipped in full compliance with
this subchapter.
   (B)   Operator.
      (1)   Only persons over 16 years of age and holding a valid driver’s
license may operate a golf cart.
      (2)   Only persons over 16 years of age may operate an off-road vehicle.
   (C)   Time of operation. No golf carts or off-road vehicles shall be
operated one-half hour before sunset and one-half-hour after sunrise, unless
the golf cart or off-road vehicle is equipped with two operating headlights
(one on each side of the front of the golf cart or off-road vehicle) and two
operating taillights with brake lights (one on each side of the rear of the
golf cart or off-road vehicle), all of which are visible from a distance of 500
feet.
   (D)   Place of operation.
      (1)   Golf carts or off-road vehicles may be operated on city streets
which have a posted speed limit of 30 mph or less.
      (2)   Golf carts or off-road vehicles may not be operated on sidewalks.
      (3)   Golf carts or off-road vehicles may not be operated on the
following highways, except to cross the highways at intersections in a path 90
degrees to the highways: State Road 59 and U.S. Highway 40.
(Ord. 5-2019, passed 3-13-2019) Penalty, see §
72.99
§ 72.03 FINANCIAL RESPONSIBILITY.
   (A)   The operator or owner of a golf cart or off-road vehicle must show
financial responsibility when operating a golf cart or off-road vehicle.
   (B)   Written proof of financial responsibility must be available on the
golf cart or off-road vehicle or carried by the operator at all times of
operation of the golf cart or off-road vehicle.
(Ord. 5-2019, passed 3-13-2019)
§ 72.04 UNATTENDED VEHICLES.
   No person shall leave or allow any golf carts or off-road vehicles to remain
unattended on any city street while the motor is running or the key is in the
ignition.
(Ord. 5-2019, passed 3-13-2019) Penalty, see §
72.99
§ 72.05 OCCUPANTS.
   The number of occupants in a golf cart or off-road vehicle shall be limited
to the number of persons for whom factory seating is installed and provided on
the golf cart or off-road vehicle. The operator and all occupants shall be
seated in the golf cart or off-road vehicle, and no parts of the bodies of the
operator or any occupants shall extend outside the perimeter of the golf cart
or off-road vehicle while the golf cart or off-road vehicle is being operated.
(Ord. 5-2019, passed 3-13-2019) Penalty, see §
72.99
§ 72.06 TRAFFIC RULES.
   The operator of a golf cart or off-road vehicle shall comply with all
traffic rules and regulations adopted by the state and the city which govern
the operation of motor vehicles.
(Ord. 5-2019, passed 3-13-2019) Penalty, see §
72.99
§ 72.07 SLOW-MOVING VEHICLE SIGN.
   All golf carts and off-road vehicles must display on the back of the golf
cart or off-road vehicle a “slow moving vehicle” according to the provisions
set forth in I.C. 9-21-9-2 or a red or amber flashing lamp according to the
provisions set forth in I.C. 9-21-9-4.
(Ord. 5-2019, passed 3-13-2019) Penalty, see §
72.99
§ 72.08 REGISTRATION.
   (A)   Golf carts and off-road vehicles.
      (1)   All golf carts and off-road vehicles shall be required to register
annually with the city.
      (2)   The annual amount of registration, per golf cart or off-road
vehicle, shall be $5 each year due by May 1 of each year.
      (3)   Each registrant will be provided with a decal to be affixed to his
or her golf cart or off-road vehicle.
      (4)   Registration will be good from May 1 (of the current year) through
April 30 (of the following year).
      (5)   For the year 2019, only the deadline to register will be extended
until June 30, 2019.
   (B)   Off-road vehicles.
      (1)   In addition to city registration requirements set forth above, off-
road vehicles must also comply with any registration requirements set forth by
the state.
      (2)   Off-road vehicles must comply with all provisions of I.C. 14-16-
1 et seq.
(Ord. 5-2019, passed 3-13-2019) Penalty, see §
72.99
§ 72.99 PENALTY.
   (A)   Violation of any provision of this chapter shall be subject to the
following penalties:
      (1)   For a first violation: $50;
      (2)   For a second violation: $100; and
      (3)   For a third and subsequent violations: $250.
   (B)   A violation is defined as any separate violation which may occur in a
single occurrence of operation.
   (C)   Any funds recovered for violation of this chapter shall be deposited
in the General Fund of the city.
(Ord. 5-2019, passed 3-13-2019)

SCHEDULE II. LOADING ZONES AND PARKING AREAS.
   (A)   Loading zones; how designated. The Board of Public Works and Safety is
authorized and empowered to designate certain spaces or zones on the streets
and thoroughfares in the city, to be designated as loading zones.
   (B)   Restricted parking in loading zones.
      (1)   No vehicle shall be parked or left standing whether occupied or
not, within the boundaries of marked-off areas, designated as a loading zone,
unless the driver of that vehicle is making a delivery of, or providing repairs
or services for the premises of business places, or receiving items of
merchandise or personal property used in the normal course of business by
merchants or business persons within the city block wherein a loading and
unloading zone is located.
      (2)   Parking shall not be deemed to be within the meaning of this
section, unless that motor vehicle is left standing for a period of time longer
than is necessary to accomplish the purpose of loading and unloading.
   (C)   Angle parking. In parking motor vehicles and other vehicles along the
side of all streets and avenues in the city, parking shall be parking flat
along and within one foot of the curb.
 
Street          Side Between                     Requirement

                                                 an angle of 35 degrees with

Harrison Street West National Avenue and Jackson See division (C) above
                     Street
 
   (D)   Double parking and parking for repairs along street restricted.
      (1)   It shall be unlawful to park any vehicle double in the city or to
park any vehicle on any of the streets or avenues of the city in any other
manner than as specifically provided for in this chapter.
      (2)   It shall be unlawful to park any vehicle for the purpose of repairs
or service at any point along National Avenue in the city if and when repairs
shall render the motor vehicle unable to be moved away under its own power.
      (3)   These provisions are enacted for the purpose of providing greater
safety and to prohibit unnecessary fire hazards.
   (E)   Parking prohibited on any tree row. No motor vehicle shall be parked
on any tree row in the city.

   (G)   Parking meter fund and fees.
      (1)   All parking meter fees and license fees collected from mechanical
parking devices, commonly known as parking meters, used and operated in the
city, shall continue to be deposited with the Clerk-Treasurer, to the credit of
the city, in a special fund, which the special parking meter fund shall be
disbursed and paid out only under the orders and directions of the Board of
Public Works and Safety or the Common Council.
      (2)   The Clerk-Treasurer shall be entitled to receive and shall be paid
additional compensation for keeping records and handling parking meter fees
collected and expended; which compensation shall be in addition to all other
compensation received by the Clerk-Treasurer. The additional compensation shall
be paid solely and only out of the special parking meter fund.
      (3)   All other monies in the parking meter fund shall continue, as
heretofore, to be used an expended solely and only for the payment of the cost
of parking meters, the maintenance and repair of parking meters and the repair
and maintenance of any of the public streets and highways, where any parking
meters are used, and all other public streets and highways connected therewith
in the city.
      (4)   All of the parking meter funds received by the city are
appropriated for the uses and purposes provided in this section.
   (H)   Penalties for parking in prohibited areas.
      (1)   Any person violating the provisions of division (D) above or
Schedule I of this chapter shall be guilty of a Class C infraction and shall be
subject to a penalty of $5, and any vehicle in violation thereof shall be
subject to being removed, towed and impounded, at the owner’s expense.
      (2)   If the above penalty is not paid at the office of the Clerk-
Treasurer within ten days from the date of the violation, the penalty shall be
$10.
      (3)   If the penalty is not paid within 30 days from the date of the
violation, the violator shall be summoned into court and be subject to a
judgment of up to $500.
(Prior Code, Ch. 74, Sch. II) (Ord. 9-1931, passed 9-22-1931; Ord. 3-1935,

   (B)   Definitions. For the purpose of this chapter, the following
definitions shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a
different meaning.
      PARKING. The standing of a vehicle on the municipal parking lot, whether
the vehicle is occupied or not, and whether the vehicle is occupied or not by
an operator.

trailer, truck-trailer, bus, school bus, recreational vehicle, construction
vehicle, tractor and bicycle.

fined the sum of $25. A public offense shall be deemed committed for each
violation that occurs or continues to occur for a period in excess of two
hours, and a vehicle illegally parked shall be subject to being removed, towed
and stored at the owner’s expense.

SCHEDULE IX. RESTRICTED PARKING IN CONGESTED AREAS.
   These streets shall be declared a congested traffic area, and the Common
Council determines that because of the flow of traffic on the streets or
portions of the streets within this area that parking therein shall be subject
to the following provisions.
   (A)   The Board of Public Works and Safety is authorized and directed to
designate and mark off individual parking spaces as it deems proper along the
streets in the congested traffic area for the parking of vehicles. At each
place where individual parking spaces are so marked off, each vehicle shall be
parked entirely within an individual parking space.
   (B)   It shall be unlawful for any person to cause, allow, permit or suffer
any vehicle registered in the name of, or operated by, any person to be parked
in any individual parking space within the congested traffic area for a period
of more than two consecutive hours, during the hours of 8:30 a.m. to 4:30 p.m.,
inclusive, and between the days of Monday through Friday, inclusive, except
holidays.
 
Street          Between                     Location
National Avenue Alabama and Sherman Streets -
Sherfey Street  -                           Within one block of National Avenue
Walnut Street   -                           Within one block of National Avenue

   (A)   Generally. Any person violating any provision of this schedule for
which no specific penalty is prescribed shall be subject to §
70.99.
   (B)   Blaine Street (between Alabama and Meridian). Any person violating
this provision shall be guilty of a Class C infraction and subject to a penalty
of $5, and any vehicle in violation thereof shall be subject to being removed,
towed and impounded at the owner’s expense. If the penalty is not paid within
ten days from the date of the violation, the penalty shall be $10. If the
penalty is not paid within 30 days from the date of the violation, the violator
shall be summoned into court and be subject to a judgment of up to $500.

SCHEDULE VII. THROUGH STREETS.
   (A)   The streets and avenues referred to in this schedule are declared to
be through or preferential streets for the purpose of regulating traffic on or
crossing the same and every operator of a vehicle or other conveyance traveling
on any street or roadway intersecting any through street. Operators/drivers
shall bring their vehicle to a full complete stop at the place where the street
meets the prolongation of the nearest property line of a through street,
subject, however, to the direction of any official traffic-control sign or
signal or the directions of any police officer at the intersection.
   (B)   The operator of any vehicle who has come to a full stop as required
above, on entering the through street, as well as operator of vehicles on a
through street, shall be subject to the usual right-of-way rule prescribed by
state law governing the meeting of vehicles at street or highway intersections.
   (C)   The Common Council’s Committee on Public Safety is authorized to place
and maintain or cause to be place of maintained on each and every street
intersecting a through street as designated above, and at or near the property
line of the through street, appropriate signs on or near the street (and in
addition thereto may place and maintain any appropriate device or mark in or
near the highway) signs, devices or marks to bear the word “STOP” or the legend
“STOP THRU STREET” or the legend “STOP THRU STREET, POLICE ORDERS.”
   (D)   It shall be unlawful for the operator of any vehicle to disobey any
signs, signals or devices erected by order of the Committee of the Common
Council.
   (E)   The following streets and parts of streets are declared to constitute
through streets.
 
Street          Description
Forest Avenue   -
Hendrix Street  Between Alabama and Meridian Streets, both inclusive, except at
                Forest Avenue
Meridian Street Between National Avenue and Compton Street
National Avenue -
Walnut Street   Between National Avenue and Logan Street

§ 90.01 CITY’S AUTHORITY TO REGULATE.
   The city may regulate the conduct or use or possession of property which
might endanger the public health, safety or welfare of its citizens.
(Prior Code, § 90.01)
§ 90.02 AUTHORITY TO ESTABLISH A POLICE AND A FIRE DEPARTMENT.
   (A)   The city may establish, maintain and operate a police and law
enforcement system to preserve public peace and order and may provide
facilities and equipment for that system.
   (B)   The city may establish, maintain and operate a firefighting and fire
prevention system and may provide facilities and equipment for that system.
(Prior Code, § 90.02)
§ 90.03 CITY’S AUTHORITY TO REGULATE AIR AND SOUND.
   The city may regulate the introduction of any substance or odor into the
air, or any generation of sound.
(Prior Code, § 90.03)
§ 90.04 AUTHORITY TO REGULATE PUBLIC GATHERINGS.
   The city may regulate public gatherings such as shows, demonstrations,
fairs, conventions, sporting events and exhibitions.
(Prior Code, § 90.04)
§ 90.05 OFFENSES AGAINST PUBLIC HEALTH, ORDER AND DECENCY.
   All offenses against public health, order and decency not addressed by this
code shall be governed by applicable state statute.
(Prior Code, § 90.05)
