ADMINISTRATION OF FACILITIES
§ 95.01 AUTHORITY TO OPERATE.
   The city may establish, aid, maintain and operate public parks, playgrounds
and recreation facilities and programs.
(Prior Code, § 97.01)
§ 95.02 DEPARTMENT OF PARKS AND RECREATION.
   The City Department of Parks and Recreation shall have administrative and
management jurisdiction over Forest Park, Hendrix Street Park and George N.
Craig Park. The Department shall consist of a Parks and Recreation Board, a
Park Superintendent and other personnel that the Board deems necessary.
(Prior Code, § 97.02) (Ord. 4-1992, passed 5-10-1992; Ord. 4-2019, passed 1-9-
2019)
§ 95.03 FOUR-MEMBER PARKS AND RECREATION BOARD.
   (A)   The Parks and Recreation Board shall consist of four members,
appointed by the Mayor.
   (B)   The terms of office and the filling of vacancies shall be according to
applicable state statutes.
(Prior Code, § 97.03) (Ord. 4-1992, passed 5-10-1992; Ord. 3-2018, passed 8-8-
2018)
§ 95.04 POWERS OF THE BOARD AND PARK SUPERINTENDENT.
   The powers and duties of the members of the Parks and Recreation Board and
the Park Superintendent shall be pursuant to I.C. 36-10-3-1 through 36-10-3-14
and other applicable provisions of this code.
(Prior Code, § 97.04) (Ord. 4-1992, passed 5-10-1992)
§ 95.05 DESIGNATION OF THREE CITY PARKS AND OTHER RECREATIONAL AREAS.
   (A)   The city, under the jurisdiction of the Department of Parks and
Recreation, operates the following city parks:
      (1)   Hendrix Street Park;
      (2)   Forest Park (formerly Hendrix Park);
      (3)   George N. Craig Park; and
      (4)   The skate park located at 611 West Jackson Street in the city.
   (B)   There are established the following designated tracts or areas as and
for public playgrounds and recreation centers under and by virtue of Ch. 1742
of the Acts of 1925, as amended:
      (1)   The tract or parcel of land adjacent to and south of Forest Park
proper which was acquired from the school city and on which is situated
playground equipment, the swimming pool, the bathing beach, the bath house, the
athletic field stadium and the camping or picnic area;
      (2)   The tract or parcel of land adjacent to and southeast of Forest
Park proper, and to the east of and adjacent to the last above designated
tract, acquired from Fred Nichols, and on which is situated that certain
playing field used and maintained as and for a municipal golf course;
      (3)   The tract or parcel of land situated at the southwest intersection
of North Meridian Street and West Hendrix Street, acquired from diverse
persons, and commonly known as Hendrix Park;
      (4)   The tract or parcel of land situated within the lands owned by
Harry Bradshaw, located north of Hendrix Street and east of State Highway 59,
under lease by the city, from year to year; and
      (5)   The area located in the southwest corner of Forest Park proper on
which is situated certain games and playing courts and similar layouts.
   (C)   All structures, buildings and other improvements situated on the above
designated tracts, parcels or areas are permitted to be used for playground or
recreational purposes pursuant to the provisions of and for the purposes
designated in this section.
(Prior Code, § 97.05) (Ord. 10-1949, passed 8-2-1949; Ord. 35-1983, passed 11-
28-1983; Ord. 6-2013, passed 10-9-2013; Ord. 12-2017, passed 9-13-2017; Ord. 4-
2019, passed 1-9-2019)
§ 95.06 CREATION OF SKATE PARK FUND.
   (A)   There is hereby created a new fund as a part of the City Parks and
Recreation Department Non-Reverting Fund which shall be designated as the
“Skate Park Fund.”
   (B)   The purpose of the Fund is to allow the city to receive monetary
donations from the community and individuals, deposit contributions into the
Skate Park Fund and disburse monies therefrom to construct and maintain for the
citizens and youth of the city and the county a skate park located at 611 West
Jackson Street in the city.
   (C)   The Fund shall be perpetual until terminated pursuant to the terms of
this section.
   (D)   This Fund may be terminated by the enactment of an ordinance and any
fund balance in that fund shall revert to the City Parks and Recreation
Department Non-Reverting Fund to be used for any purposes lawfully allowed.
(Prior Code, § 97.06) (Ord. 22-2005, passed 8-10-2005; Ord. 6-2013, passed 10-
9-2013)
PARK RULES AND REGULATIONS
§ 95.20 AUTHORITY TO ADOPT RULES AND REGULATIONS BY THE BOARD.
   (A)   The Parks and Recreation Board shall adopt and establish rules and
regulations for the control, maintenance, use and regulation of playground and
recreation facilities, bathing areas, swimming and wading pools and other park
and recreation property; for providing and maintaining all necessary equipment,
supplies, building structures and all other property under its control and
jurisdiction; for establishing standards and qualifications for the appointment
of personnel.
   (B)   All promulgated rules and regulations are subject to the approval by
the Mayor before becoming effective.
   (C)   The Board may by the rules and regulations provide for, regulate, set
aside and allocate the use by persons, vehicles and animals of the public
parks, playgrounds and other public places under its control, but without being
limited to classifications, for and into the following general classes or uses
and purposes:
      (1)   Playground areas, including all sports and recreation activities,
bathing areas, swimming and wading pools, other bodies of water and beaches,
athletic fields, child recreation and playground areas; and uses, with all
buildings and structures and equipment appurtenant thereto;
      (2)   Picnic areas, including roadside and park tables, shelter houses
and outdoor ovens for eating and drinking;
      (3)   Public meeting areas, including grandstand areas, music buildings
and exhibition pavilion, use of which may be obtained after receiving
permission from the Board with restrictions on the use of loudspeakers and
other sound amplification devices; and
      (4)   Areas for concerts, amusement attractions and theatrical
performances.
   (D)   The Board is authorized and empowered to restrict or set aside all
various areas of the city’s parks, including the entire parks, on specified and
reasonable limited occasions or periods of time for concerts, carnivals and
other amusement attractions and theatrical performances or for some other
special purpose, and may prohibit the use of any or all areas by other persons
at any times, except for the use thereof which is prescribed and then allowed
for any like area.
   (E)   No person of the opposite sex, except children under the age of four
years when accompanied by an adult, shall enter a facility provided for the
opposite sex.
(Prior Code, § 97.20) (Ord. 35-1983, passed 11-28-1983) Penalty, see §
95.99
§ 95.21 PARK HOURS.
   (A)   During the season, when so declared by the Board of Parks and
Recreation, the public parks shall be open to the public during hours specified
by the Board. However, on special occasions and certain sponsored events, the
hours may be changed and fixed generally different from those specified hours.
   (B)   It shall be unlawful for any person, other than an employee of the
city in the course of his or her employment, or except while traveling on an
established highway through a park, to be or remain in any park during any time
it is not open, or to use any park at any time for any unlawful meetings or
purposes.
(Prior Code, § 97.21) (Ord. 8-1978, passed 4-11-1978) Penalty, see §
95.99
§ 95.22 UNLAWFUL TO DAMAGE OR DESTROY PARK/CITY PROPERTY.
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person to write on, cut, mutilate,
deface, damage, remove or destroy in any manner any building, swimming or
wading pool, golf course, equipment, structure, fountain, fence, bench,
masonry, statue, ornament or any other property, real or personal, or any
appurtenance thereto, owned or operated by the city or its Board of Parks and
Recreation, and located on or in any park, golf course, playground or any other
place or property under the control of the Board.
   (B)   It shall be unlawful to damage or destroy any property leased or
loaned to or by the Board, including any property on which a concession has
been granted by the Board, or belonging to any person and rightfully on park
property.
   (C)   It shall be unlawful to remove, relocate, damage or destroy any
benches, seats, tables, equipment or other movable property, at any time from
their places in any park, golf course or other park property, without
permission from the Park Superintendent, Golf Course Manager or other
authorized park official.
(Prior Code, § 97.22) (Ord. 8-1978, passed 4-11-1978) Penalty, see §
95.99
§ 95.23 INJURY TO PLANTS AND TREES PROHIBITED.
   It shall be unlawful for any person who is not an employee of the Board of
Parks and Recreation or who is not authorized to do so by the Board, to pull,
pluck, break, plant, trample, climb into, injure, mutilate, remove or destroy
any tree, shrub, plant, vine, hedge, flower or fruit, whether wild or
cultivated, or to cut, break down, bend, damage the bark, or trim any sapling,
tree, shrub or plant, or any limbs, branches, twigs or leaves thereof, that is
growing and located in any public park, street, tree row or playground, or any
property controlled, leased or loaned to others by the Board or on concession
has been granted by it, or on any other property outside a park and which is
under the control or supervision of the Board.
(Prior Code, § 97.23) (Ord. 8-1978, passed 4-11-1978) Penalty, see §
95.99
§ 95.24 PROHIBITED CONDUCT.
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person to use profane, obscene, lewd,
threatening or abusive language; or to fight, quarrel or throw any stone or
missile; or to behave in a loud or disorderly manner; or to commit any offense
against decency, good morals or contrary to law; or to litter, dump or deposit
any garbage or other offensive substance or article on any park, playground or
any other property under the control or supervision of the Board of Parks and
Recreation, or on any property leased or loaned or on which a concession has
been granted by it; or to use or participate with others in using any places
for any subversive, seditious or other unlawful purposes.
   (B)   No unlawful, threatening, abusive, profane, lewd or indecent language,
gesture or conduct shall be permitted in, or in the vicinity of, any bathing
beach, wading or swimming pool, recreation center or playground, nor shall any
person who is lawfully at any place be so annoyed or unlawfully touched.
   (C)   (1)   During festivals held in city parks, it shall be unlawful to
have any animal within the festival perimeter as established by the Park Board
or by any entity having a contract with the city to utilize any portion of a
city park for a festival, during festival operating hours. Festivals shall
include, but not be limited to, the Popcorn Festival, the Rotary 4th of July
Celebration and Christmas in the Park. The Park Board shall have the authority
to designate other events as festivals, pursuant to §
95.20.
      (2)   The following animals are exempt from the terms of this section:
         (a)   Service animals and search and rescue animals;
         (b)   Horses or K-9 officers used by law enforcement agencies;
         (c)   Pets entered in any sanctioned pet show being held at the
festival; or
         (d)   Animals that are a part of a festival-sanctioned event,
concession, ride or attraction.
(Prior Code, § 97.24) (Ord. 8-1978, passed 4-11-1978; Ord. 8-2008, passed 9-9-
2008; Ord. 15-2014, passed 8-13-2014) Penalty, see §
95.99
§ 95.25 GAMBLING AND SOLICITING RESTRICTED.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to gamble or violate any federal, state
or city laws pertaining thereto, or to beg, hawk, peddle, distribute or solicit
or offer for sale any article, thing, paper, privilege or service within the
parks, nor circulate petitions within the parks without permission from the
Board of Parks and Recreation.
(Prior Code, § 97.25) (Ord. 8-1978, passed 4-11-1978) Penalty, see §
95.99
§ 95.26 DISCHARGING FIREARMS AND POSSESSION OF WEAPONS PROHIBITED.
   It shall be unlawful for any person, unless authorized by the Board of Parks
and Recreation, to discharge any firearms or have possession of any firearms or
other explosive devices, or to endanger others by the use of any weapon,
article or device within any park, playground or on any property controlled or
leased by the Board of Parks and Recreation, or on which a concession has been
granted by it.
(Prior Code, § 97.26) (Ord. 8-1978, passed 4-11-1978) Penalty, see §
95.99
§ 95.27 ALCOHOL AND DRUGS PROHIBITED.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to be intoxicated or under the influence
or effect of narcotics, or to use alcohol or narcotics in any park, playground,
community building, golf clubhouse, swimming or wading pool or beach, or other
premises or places under the jurisdiction or control of the Board of Parks and
Recreation without the permission of the Board.
(Prior Code, § 97.27) (Ord. 8-1978, passed 4-11-1978) Penalty, see §
95.99
§ 95.28 ORGANIZED PICNICS; USE OF OUTDOOR OVENS.
   (A)   (1)   It shall be unlawful for any person who is not invited or
included by the sponsors thereof to intrude himself or herself on a picnic
without the consent of those in charge thereof, or to disturb any picnic within
the parks.
      (2)   The Board shall adopt general rules and regulations as necessary
for compelling persons holding picnics or eating anything within any public
park to clean up the ground and remove or dispose of all food, paper, litter
and other debris before leaving the premises.
   (B)   It shall be unlawful for any person, not an employee of the Board of
Parks and Recreation, to build, kindle or ignite a fire for cooking, heating or
any other purpose in any park, playground or on any property controlled or
leased by the Board, or on which a concession has been granted by it, or on any
other property under the control or supervision of the Board of Parks and
Recreation, except as allowed for any purposes in accordance with regulations
as the Board shall establish regulating the use of outdoor ovens at any
designated places or other uses in certain areas.
(Prior Code, § 97.28) (Ord. 8-1978, passed 4-11-1978) Penalty, see §
95.99
§ 95.29 ADVERTISING AND SALES RESTRICTED.
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person to paint, post or otherwise affix
any bill, notice or advertising sign on any structure, tree or thing within any
park, playground, golf course or other property under the control of the Board
of Parks and Recreation, without having obtained permission therefor from the
Board of Parks and Recreation.
   (B)   It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, offer for sale or barter
any goods, wares or merchandise of any kind whatever within any public park,
playground or other park property, without having first obtained consent or a
concession therefor from the Board of Parks and Recreation.
(Prior Code, § 97.29) (Ord. 8-1978, passed 4-11-1978) Penalty, see §
95.99
§ 95.30 DANGEROUS SPORTS AND ACTIVITIES.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to drive golf balls, fly model planes,
throw objects, practice archery or shooting or participate in any other games
or activities which are hazardous to others on property controlled or operated
by the Board of Parks and Recreation, or located in or on any park or
playground, however, the Board of Parks and Recreation may set aside and
designate places and specify the times and regulations for engaging in any like
activities. It shall be unlawful for any person to ride or operate a skateboard
on, in, or upon any portion of the “pavilion building” or the “band shell
building” located in Forest Park, which is a municipal park located in the
city.
(Prior Code, § 97.30) (Ord. 18-2004, passed 8-10-2004) Penalty, see §
95.99.
§ 95.31 HARMING OR ENDANGERING WILDLIFE AND ANIMALS PROHIBITED.
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person, being the owner of or having
control thereof, and without permission of the Board of Parks and Recreation,
to suffer or permit any animals or fowl to stray into or to run at large or
unattended or to trespass on any park, playground, waters or any property
controlled, leased or loaned by the Board of Parks and Recreation or on which a
concession has been granted by it.
   (B)   It shall be unlawful for any person harboring or controlling a dog to
permit or to suffer a dog, when not attended and under control of the person
and held by a leash, to be in any park, public playground or golf course, or at
any time to enter any wading or swimming pool or beach located therein.
   (C)   (1)   It shall be unlawful for any person to ride, lead or drive a
horse, mule, pony, donkey or any other beast of burden on any park property,
except that the Board of Parks and Recreation may designate certain portions of
park property as bridle paths or other areas wherein horses and other equine
animals may be ridden.
      (2)   Horseback and other animal riding shall be confined exclusively to
designated bridle paths and in public parks, or to other places set apart for
that use.
      (3)   Reckless riding or racing at any place shall be unlawful. Riding
horses or other animals on or across grass, lawns, flower beds, golf courses or
any park property, other than on bridle paths or places designated therefor,
shall be unlawful.
   (D)   It shall be unlawful for any person, not an employee of the Board of
Parks and Recreation or not authorized by the Board, to chase, catch, trap,
injure, molest, kill, disturb, annoy or remove any animal, bird, fish, reptile
or fowl, either wild or domestic, on land, in the air or water or in any place
in the parks, zoo or playground or any property controlled, leased or loaned by
the Board, or on which a concession has been granted by it.
(Prior Code, § 97.31) (Ord. 8-1978, passed 4-11-1978) Penalty, see §
95.99
§ 95.32 VEHICULAR TRAFFIC.
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person, excepting police officers,
firefighters and emergency vehicle drivers, to drive or propel or cause to be
driven or propelled along or over any road within the parks, any vehicle at a
greater speed than 15 mph, unless otherwise posted.
   (B)   It shall be unlawful for any person to:
      (1)   Drive any vehicle on any area except the park roadways or parking
areas or other areas as may on occasion be specifically designated as temporary
parking areas by the Board of Parks and Recreation or the Board of Public Works
and Safety;
      (2)   Drive any vehicle on footpaths, pedestrian walks, nature trails and
bridle paths designated and established for pedestrian travel and horseback
riding;
      (3)   Park a vehicle on a roadway or parking area in a manner or under
conditions so as to impede or obstruct the normal and safe flow of traffic;
      (4)   Operate a motor vehicle in the park without the use of a muffler
adequate to deaden the sound of the engine in the vehicle;
      (5)   Operate a vehicle in the parks which emits excessive noxious fumes
or dense smoke;
      (6)   Use a siren or other type of loud sounding device which makes
unusually loud and unnecessary noise, excepting persons driving police, fire or
emergency vehicles;
      (7)   Operate a motor vehicle on a service drive except in making
deliveries and servicing the facility to which the without permission of the
Park Superintendent or Board of Parks and Recreation;
      (8)   Park a vehicle within the boundaries of Forest Park at the
northeast corner of Roy Brann Stadium beginning at the east edge of the
crosswalk at the intersection of Miller Drive and South Nabuco Drive extending
westerly a distance of 50 feet; and on the south side of Miller Drive beginning
158 feet from the southwest corner of the intersection of Miller Drive and
South Nabuco Drive and extending northerly a distance of 30 feet (to be
designated as an ambulance entrance) during the hours when the swimming pool is
open to the public;
      (9)   Park or otherwise stop a vehicle within the boundaries of Forest
Park on the south side of Miller Drive in front of the swimming pool entrance,
beginning 102 feet from the southwest corner of the intersection of Miller
Drive and South Nabuco Drive and extending northerly a distance of 30 feet only
during the hours when the swimming pool is open to the public, unless the
vehicle shall have attached thereto a disabled license plate or other
conspicuous evidence that it is being used to transport a disabled. That area
shall be designated as disabled parking only when pool open; or
      (10)   Operate a vehicle through the following intersections within the
boundaries of and at Forest Park located within the corporate limits of the
city without first coming to a complete stop: King Avenue at the intersection
with East Pinkley Street; King Avenue at the intersection with East Deloss
Street; Miller Drive at the intersection with King Avenue; Ivan Fuqua Drive at
the intersection with King Avenue; South Nabuco Drive at the intersection with
South Forest Avenue; Miller Drive at the intersection with the Cabin Crosswalk;
Miller Drive at the intersection with South Nabuco Drive; Stadium Drive at the
intersection with South Nabuco Drive; East Nabuco Drive at the intersection
with South Nabuco Drive; East Nabuco Drive at the intersection with East
Pinkley Street.
   (C)   For the purpose of this section, the term VEHICLE shall mean any motor
vehicle, automobile, motorcycle, truck, trailer, semi-trailer, truck tractor,
bus, school bus, recreational vehicle, construction vehicle, tractor and
bicycle.
(Prior Code, § 97.32) (Ord. 8-1978, passed 4-11-1978; Ord. 28-1983, passed - -
) Penalty, see §
95.99
§ 95.33 PARK AND RECREATION FEES.
   (A)   Pool hours are 1:00 p.m. to 5:00 p.m. with a review after the first
months to see if lengthening the hours is warranted.
   (B)   A flat fee of $80 will be charged with lifeguard fees being paid by
the party givers. The number of lifeguards needed would depend on the size of
the party. Party guidelines will govern.
   (C)   Admission fees and passes:
      (1)   Daily rates:
         (a)   Ages zero to four: Free when accompanied by a paying adult;
         (b)   Ages five to nine: $2;
         (c)   Ages ten to 16: $2.25;
         (d)   Ages 17 and older: $2.50; and
         (e)   Ages 60 and older: $1.50.
      (2)   Passes:
         (a)   Ages five to nine: $50;
         (b)   Ages ten to 16: $55;
         (c)   Ages 17 and older: $60; and
         (d)   Ages 60 and older: $50.
      (3)   Family passes (up to four members):
         (a)   County resident: $100;
         (b)   Non-county resident: $125; and
         (c)   Each additional family member: $10.
      (4)   A block of 30 daily admission tickets will be discounted 20% if
paid in advance.
   (D)   The park shelter may be reserved at a fee based on the number of
people with a minimum fee amount of $20.
   (E)   The Park Manager and all related personnel will be paid at rates
established by the Board of Parks and Recreation.
(Prior Code, § 97.33)
MUNICIPAL GOLF COURSE OPERATIONS
§ 95.45 PURPOSE; AUTHORITY TO OPERATE.
   (A)   It is deemed necessary and proper that it is in the best interests of
the city, the public and golfing enthusiasts who utilize the municipal golf
course of the city, that a board be created and given the authority to control,
supervise and operate specifically and exclusively the golf course because of
its particular and special nature; that members of the newly created board be
especially sensitive to and knowledgeable of the particular needs of the golf
course and the desires of those citizens who utilize and enjoy the sport of
golfing at the golf course and that those persons who consistently utilize the
golf course facility be allowed to provide their input into the operation,
maintenance, improvement and expansion of the golf course.
   (B)   The city has the power to acquire, develop, improve and operate golf
courses, either as a part of or in connection with its public park, or separate
and apart therefrom, pursuant to I.C. 36-10-5-3(b).
(Prior Code, § 97.45) (Ord. 8-1981, passed 4-13-1981)
§ 95.46 CREATION OF MUNICIPAL GOLF COURSE BOARD; COMPENSATION AND TERMS OF
OFFICE.
   (A)   There is created the City Golf Course Board which shall have the power
to govern, control, supervise, operate and acquire property for purposes of the
golf course previously vested in the Board of Parks and Recreation.
   (B)   (1)   The Golf Course Board shall consist of five members appointed by
the Mayor, all of whom must be residents of the county for at least five years,
and, in the opinion of the Mayor, have actively participated in the sport of
golf in the county, have shown an interest in the operation of the golf course
facility and have the ability to make decisions concerning the operation and
maintenance of the golf course.
      (2)   The first members of the Golf Course Board shall hold office
respectively as follows: One for a term of one year; one for a term of two
years; one for a term of three years; and two for a term of four years. The
Mayor shall appoint a new member to fill each of the vacancies caused by the
expiration of the above respective terms, and newly-appointed members shall
hold office for a term of four years.
      (3)   If a vacancy occurs in the membership of the Board, by resignation
or otherwise, the Mayor shall appoint a replacement for the residue of the
departing member’s term.
      (4)   The Board members serve at the pleasure of the Mayor and may be
removed only for cause, upon a specific written charges filed against them.
         (a)   The charges shall be filed and heard by the Mayor unless the
Mayor brings the charges. If the Mayor brings the charges, the Common Council
shall meet and appoint a person to serve as hearing officer to hear the
particular charges against the accused Board member who is not related to the
accused member or the Mayor nor a salaried employee of the city.
         (b)   The hearing officer shall fix a date for a public hearing and
give notice to the accused member at least ten days in advance of the hearing.
         (c)   At the hearing, the member shall be entitled to present evidence
and argument on his or her behalf, be represented by legal counsel and cross-
examine opposing witnesses.
         (d)   Following the submission of all evidence and argument, the
hearing officer shall consider same and make special findings of fact and
determination of the member’s guilt or innocence of the alleged charges.
         (e)   The members shall serve without compensation except for actual
expenses to be approved by the Mayor and the Common Council.
(Prior Code, § 97.46) (Ord. 8-1981, passed 4-13-1981; Ord. 9-1982, passed 6-28-
1982)
§ 95.47 POWERS AND DUTIES OF BOARD.
   (A)   The Golf Course Board shall have the power to develop, improve and
operate the golf course, acquire the already existing golf course and lands
developed for that purpose and issue municipal bonds to pay the cost of any
acquisition, development and improvement, or for any of the purposes, subject
to statutes relating to the issuance of bonds and the making of appropriations
by the city.
   (B)   In addition to the above powers, the Board shall have the following
powers and duties:
      (1)   Exercise general supervision of and control over the operation,
maintenance, development and improvement of the golf course;
      (2)   Make rules and regulations governing the operation, maintenance and
use of the golf course facilities;
      (3)   Hire necessary professional, managerial and maintenance staff
personnel and employees for the efficient operation and maintenance of the golf
course without regard to political affiliation, plus discipline and dismiss any
personnel and employees for cause;
      (4)   Make necessary contracts and leases for facilities, services and
equipment necessary for the proper operation of the golf course;
      (5)   Contract with not-for-profit corporations or organizations for use
of the golf course facilities for teaching purposes, youth athletic programs,
tournaments and other related services;
      (6)   Acquire and dispose of real and personal property related to the
golf course or needed for the efficient operation, improvement or expansion of
the golf course;
      (7)   Exercise the power of eminent domain under the authority of any
laws generally made available to municipalities for this purpose;
      (8)   Establish standards and qualifications for the appointment and hire
of all personnel, fix their compensation and determine causes for disciplinary
action or dismissal of employees;
      (9)   Contract for special and temporary services and for professional
assistance;
      (10)   Make recommendations and an annual report to the Mayor and the
Common Council concerning the operation of the Board and the golf course;
      (11)   Invoke any legal, equitable or special remedy for the enforcement
of the provisions of any ordinance relating to the use and operation of the
golf course or any other applicable ordinance or law;
      (12)   Prepare and submit an annual budget in the same manner as other
departments of the city as prescribed by the State Board of Accounts;
      (13)   Authorize and regulate the operation of a golf pro shop, including
the sale of golf-related equipment and apparel; and
      (14)   Fix the fees and rates to be charged for the playing of golf on
the golf course and for tournaments authorized and held thereon.
(Prior Code, § 97.47) (Ord. 8-1981, passed 4-13-1981)
§ 95.48 MEETINGS; TRANSFER OF POWERS.
   (A)   (1)   Meetings of the Board shall be public. The Board shall fix the
time and place of its meetings, but it shall meet at least quarterly.
      (2)   These meeting shall be called by the President of the Board on his
or her own request or the request of any member. Written notice of the meeting
shall be sent to all members by the Secretary of the Board at least 48 hours in
advance of the meeting.
      (3)   All regularly scheduled and special meetings of the Board shall
comply with the state’s Open Door Law, I.C. 5-14-1.5-1 through 5-14-1.5-7.
      (4)   A majority of the members shall constitute a quorum, and any action
of the Board is not official unless authorized by at least three members
present and acting.
   (B)   In addition to powers and duties specified in §
95.47, the powers and duties previously vested in the Board of Parks and
Recreation pertaining to the golf course are transferred to the Golf Course
Board.
(Prior Code, § 97.48) (Ord. 8-1981, passed 4-13-1981)
§ 95.49 GOLF COURSE REGULATIONS.
   (A)   Except during the hours specified, no person other than employees of
the golf course shall be permitted to remain in the golf clubhouse on any part
of the course. No person shall play golf on the links, except on payment of the
fees stipulated by it and in compliance with its rules and regulations thereon,
as may be adopted by it at any time.
   (B)   All persons within the limits of the golf course must at all times
abide by the rules and regulations of the golf course, which shall be posted in
the clubhouse or on the course, and by the orders of the custodian of the
course, and shall not violate any laws of the city or state. Any person
violating this section may be punished as prescribed by §
95.99 and be excluded from the use of the golf course.
   (C)   It shall be unlawful for any person to sell or offer for sale golf
balls, clubs or any articles for whatever use in playing golf on the municipal
golf course within 500 feet of the boundary line of the golf course, without
written consent of the Board.
(Prior Code, § 97.49) (Ord. 8-1978, passed 4-11-1978) Penalty, see §
95.99
§ 95.50 ENFORCEMENT.
   The Board of Parks and Recreation, Park Superintendent, recreation
supervisors, Golf Course Manager, park police, police of the city and of the
state, all health authorities and other employees of the Board of Parks and
Recreation holding special police powers are authorized and empowered to
enforce any and all of the provisions of this chapter and laws of the state and
city in all places under the control of the Board of Parks and Recreation and
the Board of Public Works and Safety.
(Prior Code, § 97.50) (Ord. 8-1978, passed 4-11-1978)
§ 95.99 PENALTY.
   (A)   Any person violating any provision of this chapter for which no
specific penalty is prescribed shall be fined $50. A separate offense shall be
deemed committed on each day that a violation occurs or continues.
   (B)   Any person in violation of §
95.22, causing damage to a park or city property, shall be held responsible for
said damages.
   (C)   In addition, any person violating any provision of this chapter, or
any rule or regulation promulgated by the Parks and Recreation Board pursuant
to §
95.20, may be ordered to leave a city park or other recreational area by any
person with enforcement authority as set forth in §
95.50 and the pool manager and may further be banned or otherwise banned from
entering or using any city park or recreational area of the city for a period
of up to 90 days.
   (D)   Any person who has been banned or otherwise barred from entering upon
or using any city park or recreation area of the city may appeal the
prohibition to the City Parks and Recreation Board within 14 days of being
banned or barred from a city park or recreational area of the city.
(Prior Code, § 97.99) (Ord. 18-2004, passed 8-10-2004; Ord. 7-2014, passed 5-
14-2014)
CHAPTER 96: CEMETERIES
Section
   
96.01   Common Council to oversee cemeteries
   
96.02   Three city-owned cemeteries
   
96.03   Officers and office overseeing city-owned cemeteries
   
96.04   Rules for cemetery lot owners
   
96.05   Opening and closing of graves; fees
   
96.06   Purchase of burial plots
   
96.07   Removals; fees
   
96.08   Rules
   
96.09   Undertakers
   
96.10   Monumental work
   
96.11   Decorations
   
96.12   General management
 
   
96.99   Penalty
§ 96.01 COMMON COUNCIL TO OVERSEE CEMETERIES.
   The city-owned cemeteries shall be controlled and managed by the Common
Council, pursuant to I.C. 3-14-24-1 et seq., and applicable city ordinances and
other state statutes.
(Prior Code, § 98.01) (Ord. 14-1982, passed 8-30-1982)
§ 96.02 THREE CITY-OWNED CEMETERIES.
   The city manages and controls the following cemeteries:
   (A)   Cottage Hill;
   (B)   Old Hill; and
   (C)   Restlawn.
(Prior Code, § 98.02)
§ 96.03 OFFICERS AND OFFICE OVERSEEING CITY-OWNED CEMETERIES.
   (A)   The Supervisor of the city-owned and maintained cemeteries and
employed assistants shall be designated “the officers” and shall have the
responsibility of giving their constant and personal attention to the care,
maintenance, operation and management of the cemeteries.
   (B)   The office of the Supervisor is located at the Cottage Hill Cemetery
at the right driveway near the entrance. All the lot and grave owners in the
cemeteries should consult with the officers at all times. Advice and assistance
will be given without charge to those contemplating the purchases of monuments
or the making of other improvements.
   (C)   Orders for work, complaints and lost and found articles should be
reported at the office of the Supervisor or the City Clerk-Treasurer. All
business involving the cemeteries will be transacted at these offices.
   (D)   Employees of the cemeteries are prohibited from accepting orders or
instructions for work from anyone except the Supervisor. Every person is
requested to report to the Supervisor any errors or lack of proper care in the
execution of duties of the cemetery employees.
   (E)   No tips, gratuities or fees are permitted to be paid to cemetery
employees by any person.
(Prior Code, § 98.03) (Ord. 10-1945, passed 8-28-1945; Ord. 20-1981, passed 11-
23-1981)
§ 96.04 RULES FOR CEMETERY LOT OWNERS.
   (A)   All deeds to cemetery lot owners, when executed, shall be construed as
simply granting the purchaser of the lot the right to use the lot for the
interment of himself or herself, his or her family, relatives and decedents.
   (B)   Cemetery lot owners shall not be permitted to transfer their right to
any unused portion of a lot except by written permit signed and approved by the
Board of Public Works and Safety, the City Clerk-Treasurer and the Supervisor
of the cemeteries.
(Prior Code, § 98.04) (Ord. 10-1945, passed 8-28-1945; Ord. 20-1981, passed 11-
23-1981) Penalty, see §
96.99 
§ 96.05 OPENING AND CLOSING OF GRAVES; FEES.
   (A)   All lot owners are to bring their deed or proof of right of burial
when ordering graves opened.
   (B)   All orders for opening graves must be made at least 16 hours before
the time set for the funeral.
   (C)   When a new grave is opened in close proximity to a previous interment,
it is often impossible to avoid damaging the old grave. The management or the
city will not be responsible for that damage and remounding or reboxing. If
ordered, fees will be charged to the lot owner of the opened grave.
   (D)   In the case of death from smallpox or cholera, the grave will be
prepared by the cemetery employees, but neither they nor the Supervisor will be
present at the interment. The Board of Health must furnish the tools and
employees to handle the remains and close the grave.
   (E)   Price for opening and closing graves shall be as follows:
      (1)   All graves under four feet in length: $150;
      (2)   All other graves: $500; and
      (3)   Ash burial: $150.
   (F)   All improvement work on burial lots such as resurfacing, grading,
excavating, sodding, setting trees, placing foundation work for stonework or
setting corner posts must be done by cemetery employees under the supervision
of the Supervisor.
(Prior Code, § 98.05) (Ord. 20-1981, passed 11-23-1981; Ord. 4-2004, passed 2-
23-2004; Ord. 1-2014, passed 3-12-2014)
§ 96.06 PURCHASE OF BURIAL PLOTS.
   (A)   Persons desiring to purchase burial plots will, on application
therefor at the cemetery office, be accompanied over the cemetery grounds by
the Supervisor who will assist them in selecting a plot.
   (B)   Having decided on a suitable location for the grave plot, the
purchaser shall return to the office where he or she will be given an
application form properly filled out, describing the lot, section, number and
price. Upon presenting the completed application form at the Clerk-Treasurer’s
office in the city building, and payment to the Clerk-Treasurer for the
consideration for the plot, the Clerk-Treasurer shall execute a deed to the
purchaser.
   (C)   No interment will be allowed until payment of the full purchase price
for the lot on which the interment is to be made.
   (D)   Prices of burial plots shall be as follows:
      (1)   Single grave (adult): $250; and
      (2)   Single grave (children): $125.
(Prior Code, § 98.06) (Ord. 20-1981, passed 11-23-1981; Ord. 4-1994, passed 4-
12-1994)
§ 96.07 REMOVALS; FEES.
   (A)   Under no condition shall a removal of a body from a grave be made
where death was caused by smallpox or cholera.
   (B)   The price of removal of a body from a grave shall be $150.
   (C)   In making removals from one cemetery to another, the price shall be
governed by the distance, condition of the remains and time and labor required.
   (D)   Burial plots may be surrendered only after they have been cleared of
all encumbrances and when recommended by the Supervisor.
(Prior Code, § 98.07) (Ord. 10-1945, passed 8-28-1945; Ord. 20-1981, passed 11-
23-1981) Penalty, see §
96.99
§ 96.08 RULES.
   (A)   The proper burial certificate required by the municipal authorities
must be delivered at the gate office before any interment is made or anyone is
placed in any vault or tomb.
   (B)   All persons are prohibited from driving a horse-drawn or motor-driven
conveyance through the grounds faster than ten mph.
   (C)   Bicycle or sled riding in all cemeteries is prohibited.
   (D)   No person shall park a car within 50 feet of an open grave.
   (E)   All motor vehicles shall be stopped and the motor shut off within 50
feet of any burial service in progress.
   (F)   It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or company to advertise any
business or product in or on any cemetery, except by permission of the
Supervisor.
   (G)   All persons are prohibited from plucking flowers, whether wild or
cultivated.
   (H)   Taking pictures is prohibited in the cemetery, except by permission of
the Supervisor.
   (I)   Children under ten years of age shall be accompanied by parents or
guardian who will be responsible for their conduct while in the cemetery.
   (J)   Writing on or otherwise defacing any mausoleum, monument, marker or
memorial structure of any kind is prohibited.
   (K)   All persons are prohibited from discharging firearms in the cemetery,
except in case of military funerals or by special permission of the Supervisor.
   (L)   No visitors or curiosity seekers are permitted to be present at the
removal of a body.
(Prior Code, § 98.08) (Ord. 10-1945, passed 8-28-1945; Ord. 20-1981, passed 11-
23-1981) Penalty, see §
96.99
§ 96.09 UNDERTAKERS.
   (A)   Undertakers are requested to make complete arrangements with the
Supervisor so no confusion will result in burials at the same hour.
   (B)   All undertakers are urgently requested by the management to so arrange
funerals as to give the cemetery employees ample time to prepare and close the
grave during the regular working hours of the employees. An extra charge will
be made when employees are held overtime to complete the services. The regular
working hours of the employees are from 7:00 a.m. to 3:30 p.m.
   (C)   All funeral processions while within the grounds will be subject to
the control of the Supervisor and his or her assistants. Every possible effort
will be made by the Supervisor and cemetery employees to prevent any
inconvenience to funeral processions while within the cemetery. It is often
necessary to prohibit parking on certain driveways, and every person shall obey
the signs or signals at the intersections.
   (D)   Any person observed parking on the lawn will be subject to arrest for
malicious trespass.
   (E)   Driving a car backwards or making a complete turn on any drive or
avenue in the cemetery is prohibited. The sale of refreshments, merchandise and
flowers on cemetery property is prohibited.
(Prior Code, § 98.09) (Ord. 10-1945, passed 8-28-1945; Ord. 20-1981, passed 11-
23-1981)
§ 96.10 MONUMENTAL WORK.
   (A)   All workpersons engaged in erecting monuments or other structures are
prohibited from attaching ropes to any tree or shrub except by permission of
the Supervisor.
   (B)   All workpersons and builders are under the control and direction of
the Supervisor while on the grounds and must enter and leave the cemetery
during the working hours of the cemetery employees. Any workperson failing to
comply with this regulation shall not be permitted to work in the cemetery.
   (C)   No stonework shall be begun on Saturday that cannot be finished and
the debris cleared away before the regular quitting time of the cemetery
employees.
   (D)   No stonework shall be removed from the cemetery except by permission
of the Supervisor.
   (E)   All markers must be placed at the opposite end of the grave from the
monument. The management does not bind itself to maintain or replace any stone
or structure erected on any lot.
(Prior Code, § 98.10) (Ord. 1-1951, passed 4-10-1951; Ord. 20-1981, passed 11-
23-1981)
§ 96.11 DECORATIONS.
   (A)   Toys, cans, dishes, globes, shells, bottles or bric-a-brac of any kind
shall not be allowed on the graves, as they interfere with cutting the grass.
These articles will be promptly removed whenever found.
   (B)   Dead flowers, weeds, grass, paper or other forms of rubbish shall be
put in the containers provided for that purpose and shall by no means be piled
against trees or left on the section.
   (C)   Planting trees as boundary line marks to prohibited.
   (D)   Fences or enclosures are prohibited on any lot or part.
   (E)   Wooden trellises, vines or shrubs are prohibited on any lot or grave
unless approved by the Supervisor.
   (F)   Lot owners shall not place any chair, settee or portable seat of any
kind on their lot, as they attract strangers to the lot and the constant use of
them destroys the grass and is objectionable in other ways.
   (G)   When trees or shrubs, by means of their height or branches, become
detrimental to adjacent lots, or dangerous or inconvenient to passengers, it
shall be the duty of the Supervisor to remove the tree, shrub or offending part
thereof.
   (H)   No grave mounds shall be permitted.
   (I)   All bouquet holders must be set flush with the surface of the ground.
Vases with cut flowers may be placed on graves but will be removed when the
flowers wither.
   (J)   Unfilled vases and urns shall not be allowed to remain on lots after
July 1 of each year but will be removed from the lot and held subject to the
order of the lot owner for one year after which all responsibility of the
cemetery ceases, and disposal will be made as the management deems best.
   (K)   Floral designs or other decorations will be removed from lots or
graves as soon as the flowers become wilted or unsightly, and persons wishing
to retain the same must remove them within 48 hours after the funeral.
   (L)   Winter decorations, holly, evergreen or artificial wreaths may be
placed on the graves beginning November 1 and may remain until March 1, after
which date all decorations will be removed. If these are to be kept for future
use, they must be removed and cared for by the lot owner before March 1.
   (M)   Seats or benches of stone will not hereafter be permitted in the
cemetery, and as those now existing become broken or out of repair, they will
be removed and may not be replaced.
   (N)   Before ordering monuments or markers, lot owners must consult the
Supervisor and ascertain if there is space on the lot for the desired stone or
markers.
   (O)   If any trees or shrubs situated on any lot shall, by reason of the
growth of their roots and branches, or in any other way become detrimental to,
or dangerous of inconvenient to, the adjacent lots, walks, driveways or
avenues, it shall be the duty of the passers-by and/or the Supervisor to enter
on the lot and remove the trees or shrubs, or parts thereof, as are thus
detrimental, dangerous or inconvenient.
(Prior Code, § 98.11) (Ord. 10-1945, passed 8-28-1945; Ord. 20-1981, passed 11-
23-1981) Penalty, see §
96.99
§ 96.12 GENERAL MANAGEMENT.
   (A)   All lot and grave owners will be presented with a copy of this chapter
on application at the cemetery office.
   (B)   Questions which may arise, not covered in these rules, are subject to
the decision of the Supervisor, the Board of Public Works and Safety and the
Common Council.
   (C)   Visitors are requested to observe the decorum which should
characterize a place, and unnecessary noise or improper conduct of any person
will not be tolerated.
   (D)   The Supervisor is charged with the execution of these rules, and
persons are requested to inform him or her of any breach of these rules of
which they become aware.
   (E)   (1)   The Supervisor and his or her deputies are invested with full
police power to arrest any offender in these grounds.
      (2)   They shall expel from the grounds any violator of these rules or
any person disturbing the sanctity of the place by any act of disrespect
whereby the offender is subject to punishment.
   (F)   The cemetery gates or entrance will be opened at 7:00 a.m. and closed
at sunset.
(Prior Code, § 98.12) (Ord. 10-1945, passed 8-28-1945; Ord. 20-1981, passed 11-
23-1981)
§ 96.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter shall be guilty of a Class B
infraction and subject to a penalty of not more than $1,000. A separate offense
shall be deemed committed on each day that a violation occurs or continues.
(Prior Code, § 98.99) (Ord. 10-1945, passed 10-28-1945; Ord. 20-1981, passed
11-23-1981)

OCCUPATIONAL LICENSES AND PERMITS
§ 110.01 AUTHORITY TO LICENSE.
   The city has the authority to impose a license fee reasonably related to the
administrative cost of exercising those powers.
(Prior Code, § 110.01)
§ 110.02 ISSUANCE AND INSPECTIONS.
   (A)   The Clerk-Treasurer shall issue licenses upon payment of the license
fees and compliance with the applicable provisions of this code, unless
otherwise indicated.
   (B)   The Police Department shall inspect all places of business under
license or required to have a license.
(Prior Code, § 110.02)
§ 110.03 COMPLAINTS, REVOCATIONS AND SUSPENSIONS.
   (A)   The Mayor shall hear any complaint against a person to whom the city
has issued a license.
   (B)   The Mayor make revoke or suspend any license if he or she finds, after
proper notice, that the person has willfully violated a term or condition of
his or her license, or has willfully done or permitted to be done an act in
violation of a statute or provision of this code.
   (C)   The Mayor shall file a copy of his or her findings and determination
with the Clerk-Treasurer within 72 hours after it is made.
(Prior Code, § 110.03) Penalty, see §
110.99
§ 110.04 RESTRICTED HOURS OF BUSINESS FOR PLACES OF SELECTED ENTERTAINMENT.
   All pool rooms, billiard rooms, pool and billiard parlors, bowling alleys,
shooting galleries, public dance halls, skating rinks and places of business
where card games are played in connection with a business within the city shall
close at 11:00 p.m. and remain closed until 6:00 a.m.
(Prior Code, § 110.25) (Ord. 69-1931, passed 9-22-1931) Penalty, see §
110.99
§ 110.05 LICENSE REQUIRED; FEES; APPLICATION.
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, company or corporation, for
the purpose of profit or gain, to erect, maintain, use, operate or exhibit, or
to practice, engage in, do or perform any of the exhibitions, performances,
trades, avocations, businesses, professions, enterprises or things particularly
designated in this chapter, without having first procured from the city a
license to do so, and paid to the city for the license the sum of money
provided herein.
   (B)   (1)   The license fee to be charged for the purposes herein designated
shall be in sums and shall be issued for periods of time as set out in the
following divisions.
      (2)   All licenses so issued shall plainly set out the time covered by
licenses.
   (C)   (1)   Any person desiring any license herein provided for shall pay to
the Clerk-Treasurer the fee hereinbefore provided for and take his or her
receipt therefor.
      (2)   The applicant shall then present the Clerk-Treasurer with his or
her application for the license desired and for the length of time desired.
(Prior Code, § 110.27) (Ord. 64-1931, passed 9-22-1931; Ord. 77-1932, passed 2-
23-1932) Penalty, see §
110.99
§ 110.06 ROLE OF CLERK-TREASURER.
   (A)   The Clerk-Treasurer shall issue to the applicant the license applied
and paid upon proper review and approval.
   (B)   The holder of the license shall exhibit the same on the reasonable
request of any police officer.
(Prior Code, § 110.28)
§ 110.07 LICENSES NON-TRANSFERABLE.
   None of the licenses required herein shall be assignable or transferable by
the licensee.
(Prior Code, § 110.29) (Ord. 64-1931, passed 9-22-1931)
§ 110.08 ORDERLY AND LAWFUL COMPLIANCE REQUIRED.
   It is declared unlawful for any person, firm, company or corporation holding
a license hereunder and exhibiting or controlling by virtue thereof, any shows,
circus or other entertainment and controlling the place of entertainment to
allow any indecent, obscene or immoral language, or picture or exhibition to be
used or to appear in or as a part of entertainment or show, or to fail to
conduct and cause entertainment and place to be conducted in a lawful and
orderly manner.
(Prior Code, § 110.30) Penalty, see §
110.99
§ 110.09 RESTRICTED HOURS FOR HAWKERS AND PEDDLERS.
   (A)   Persons holding the license herein provided for as peddlers and
hawkers are required to conduct themselves while operating under the license in
a decorous and orderly manner on the streets and on the premises of persons
whose houses they may visit for any display or sale of goods.
   (B)   They shall not visit a premises for any purpose at any time except
between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. of each day and they shall not
importune persons to examine or buy goods to the annoyance of persons and
peddlers and hawkers, shall at all times while working under the license,
refrain from unusual demonstrations, loud, boisterous, profane or obscene
language.
(Prior Code, § 110.31) Penalty, see §
110.99
SPECIFIC BUSINESS REGULATIONS
§ 110.20 LIMITS ON SALES OF PRODUCTS CONTAINING EPHEDRINE AND THE LIKE.
   (A)   Definitions. For the purpose of this section, the following
definitions shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a
different meaning.
      CUSTOMER. Any person who purchases or acquires products from any retail
store.
      EPHEDRINE. Any drug, substance or compound, whether legal or illegal,
that contains ephedrine, pseudoephedrine, ephedrine hydrochloride,
pseudoephedrine hydrochloride, pseudoephedrine sulfate or phenylpropanolamine.
      PACKAGE. Any bottle, box, blister pack or other container in which
products containing ephedrine are sold.
      PERMITTEE. A person who has obtained a permit to sell ephedrine to
customers.
      PERSON. Any person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company
or organization of any kind.
      RETAIL STORE. Any single geographic location of any business, company,
corporation, person, employee or associate that sells ephedrine to any
customer. It does not include any wholesalers engaged in a wholesale
transaction.
      SELL. To furnish, give away, exchange, transfer, deliver, surrender,
distribute or supply, whether or not for monetary gain or other consideration.
      WHOLESALER. One whose business is the selling of goods in gross to retail
stores for purposes of resale.
   (B)   Permits. It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a retail store
in the city that does not possess a valid permit issued by the Clerk-Treasurer.
      (1)   The permit shall be posted in the establishment in a place
conspicuous to the public.
      (2)   No permit is required for a prescription written by a licensed
physician and/or a pharmacist providing the drugs for a prescription.
      (3)   An applicant may apply for a permit, at no cost, by submitting a
completed application form to the Clerk-Treasurer’s office.
      (4)   All permits issued by the Clerk-Treasurer’s office shall contain
the name of the retail store; name of the person to whom the permit is granted;
the address of the retail store for which the permit is issued; and the
inclusive dates the permit is valid, if other than for a calendar year.
      (5)   A permit issued to a retail store shall not be sold, assigned or
transferred.
   (C)   Limitations on the sale or purchase of ephedrine products.
      (1)   Each permittee shall require from its customer identification
showing he or she is of legal age (18), a picture form of identification and
current address. All information obtained on the customer shall be recorded in
an appropriate manner, and a copy of the report shall be forwarded to the City
Police Department at the end of each calendar month by the permittee.
      (2)   It is unlawful for any person or permittee during a single
transaction to sell to a customer more than two packages of products containing
ephedrine.
      (3)   It is unlawful for any customer to purchase or acquire more than
two packages of products containing ephedrine within a seven-day period.
   (D)   Exclusions. This section excludes any prescription written by a
licensed physician and a pharmacist providing the drugs for a prescription.
(Prior Code, § 110.12) (Ord. 6-2005, passed 4-27-2005) Penalty, see §
110.99
§ 110.21 SLAUGHTERHOUSES PROHIBITED.
   (A)   The slaughtering of cattle, sheep, hogs or other animals within the
corporate limits of the city is declared a nuisance.
   (B)   Any building or enclosure which shall or may produce any unwholesome
smell or annoyance to the inhabitants being in the vicinity thereof or any
slaughterhouse for the killing of animals, located within the corporate limits
of the city or within one-half mile of the corporate limits thereof, are each
and all declared nuisances.
   (C)   It is declared unlawful for any person or company to slaughter any
animals in the city or to maintain any building, or enclosure therein, or to
construct, maintain and operate any slaughterhouse within the corporate limits
of the city, or without the city within one-half mile of the corporate limits
of the city.
(Prior Code, § 110.26) (Ord. 61-1931, passed 9-22-1931) Penalty, see §
110.99
§ 110.22 GARAGE SALES.
   (A)   A garage sale or yard sale may be conducted on a premises which
includes a dwelling unit located within the corporate city limits in any S-1,
R-1, R-2, R-3, T, AG or MH zone.
   (B)   A garage sale or yard sale may be conducted not more than four times
in one calendar year per lot, and each sale shall not exceed four consecutive
days in duration.
   (C)   A garage sale or yard sale shall only by conducted during the hours of
sunrise to sunset.
   (D)   All personal property exhibited outdoors during a garage sale or yard
sale shall be removed from the premises immediately following the end of the
garage sale or yard sale.
   (E)   Any and all garage sale or yard sale signs shall be removed at the
close of the garage sale or yard sale.
   (F)   Nothing in this section shall be construed to prohibit one or more
owners or occupants from conducting a combined garage sale or yard sale on one
of the lots owned or occupied by the participants, provided that all other
provisions of this section are complied with.
   (G)   The terms and requirements of this section shall not be in effect
during the period in October of each calendar year in which the Covered Bridge
Festival takes place in Rockville, Indiana.
(Ord. 11-2014, passed 8-13-2014) Penalty, see §
110.99
§ 110.99 PENALTY.
   (A)   (1)   Any person, firm, company or corporation that shall violate any
of the provisions of this chapter shall, upon conviction thereof, be fined in
any sum not less than $1 nor more than $100.
      (2)   Each day’s continuance in the violation shall constitute a separate
offense.
(Prior Code, § 110.99)
   (B)   (1)   Whoever violates any provision of §
110.20 shall be fined $500. Each day the violation is committed or permitted to
continue shall constitute a separate offense. Each offense shall be considered
a separate offense and subject to a fine. Each 24 hours that a violation occurs
will be considered a separate offense and can be cited as so.
      (2)   Should any person fail to obtain a permit, pursuant to the
provisions of §
110.20(B), the person shall be charged a $250 penalty.
(Prior Code, § 110.12)
   (C)   Any person, group of persons, partnership, corporation or business
entity who violates the provisions of §
110.22 shall be subject to a civil penalty of $100 for the first offense and
$250 for the second and all subsequent offenses. A separate offense shall be
deemed committed on each day that a violation occurs or continues.
(Ord. 6-2005, passed 4-27-2005; Ord. 11-2014, passed 8-13-2014)
CHAPTER 111: CABLE TELEVISION FRANCHISED SYSTEMS REGULATIONS
Section
   
111.01   Definitions
   
111.02   Regulation of basic rates by Board of Public Works and Safety
   
111.03   Procedures for cable rates and charges
   
111.04   Rules and regulations of the Board
   
111.05   Opportunity for public input
   
111.06   Final rate orders
   
111.07   Common Council review of final rate orders
   
111.08   Hearing before the Common Council
   
111.09   Judicial review
   
111.10   Certification forms
§ 111.01 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   CABLE ACT. The Cable Communications Policy Act of 1984, as amended by the
Cable Television Consumer Protection Act of 1992, an amendment to the
Communications Act of 1934 (47 U.S.C. §§ 521 et seq.) as the same may be
amended or supplemented from time to time.
   CABLE TELEVISION SYSTEM, CABLE SYSTEM or SYSTEM. A facility, consisting of a
set of closed transmission paths and associated signal generation, reception
and control equipment that is designed to provide cable service which includes
video programming and which is provided to multiple subscribers within the
city, but the term does not include a facility that serves only to retransmit
the television signals of one or more television broadcast stations; a facility
that services only subscribers in one or more multiple-unit dwellings under
common ownership, control only subscribers in one or more multiple-unit
dwellings under common ownership, control or management, unless the facility or
facilities use any public right-of-way; a facility of a common carrier which is
subject, in whole or in part, to the provisions of Title II of the
Communication Act of 1934, being 47 U.S.C. §§ 151 et seq., as amended, except
that the facility shall be considered a cable system (other than for purposes
of § 621(c) of the Act and 47 U.S.C § 541(c)) to the extent the facility is
used in the transmission of video programming directly to subscribers; or any
facilities of any electric utility used solely for operating its electric
utility systems.
   FRANCHISE. An initial authorization, or renewal thereof (including a renewal
of an authorization which has been granted subject to § 626 of the Act (47
U.S.C. § 546), issued by the city whether authorization is designated as a
franchise, permit, license, resolution, contract, certificate, agreement or
otherwise, which authorizes the construction operation of a cable system.
(Prior Code, § 111.01) (Ord. 12-1993, passed 11-9-1993)
§ 111.02 REGULATION OF BASIC RATES BY BOARD OF PUBLIC WORKS AND SAFETY.
   To the extent permitted by § 623 of the Cable Act (47 U.S.C. § 543) and any
duly promulgated FCC rate regulations, the city, by and through its Board of
Public Works and Safety, shall regulate the basic service rates and charges for
cable television service to subscribers.
(Prior Code, § 111.02) (Ord. 12-1993, passed 11-9-1993)
§ 111.03 PROCEDURES FOR CABLE RATES AND CHARGES.
   The following procedures shall be used to review and approve changes in
basic service rates and charges of the company, or any other franchised cable
television system operating within the corporate limits of the city.
(Prior Code, § 111.03) (Ord. 12-1993, passed 11-9-1993)
§ 111.04 RULES AND REGULATIONS OF THE BOARD.
   The Board of Public Works and Safety shall adopt rules and regulations for
the review and regulation of basic service rates and charges for cable
television services provided by the company or other cable television
franchises consistent with the requirements of the Cable Act, FCC rate
regulations and this chapter.
(Prior Code, § 111.04) (Ord. 12-1993, passed 11-9-1993)
§ 111.05 OPPORTUNITY FOR PUBLIC INPUT.
   Regulations shall be promulgated to ensure all interested parties or persons
a reasonable opportunity to express their views regarding any changes in basic
service rates and charges of the company or other cable television franchises.
(Prior Code, § 111.05) (Ord. 12-1993, passed 11-9-1993)
§ 111.06 FINAL RATE ORDERS.
   The Board of Public Works and Safety shall adopt final rate orders in
accordance with its adopted regulations. Orders shall be final upon adoption,
but may be reviewed by the Common Council upon request by the company or other
cable television franchise, the Board of Public Works and Safety or any person
or interested party who participated orally or by filing written positions with
the Board in the rate proceedings held by it.
(Prior Code, § 111.06) (Ord. 12-1993, passed 11-9-1993)
§ 111.07 COMMON COUNCIL REVIEW OF FINAL RATE ORDERS.
   Review by the Common Council shall be initiated by filing a request with the
Clerk-Treasurer within 15 days of the date of the Board’s final rate order. The
request shall state briefly the reasons for which the review is being
requested.
(Prior Code, § 111.07) (Ord. 12-1993, passed 11-9-1993)
§ 111.08 HEARING BEFORE THE COMMON COUNCIL.
   Within 30 days of the filing of a request, the Common Council shall hold a
hearing on that request. The Council may affirm the final rate order or remand
the order to the Board for further review. If the order is so remanded, the
Board shall hold additional hearings as it deems appropriate and may either
affirm or amend its final rate order.
(Prior Code, § 111.08) (Ord. 12-1993, passed 11-9-1993)
§ 111.09 JUDICIAL REVIEW.
   The order of the Board shall be final subject only to judicial review as
provided by law.
(Prior Code, § 111.09) (Ord. 12-1993, passed 11-9-1993)
§ 111.10 CERTIFICATION FORMS.
   The Mayor, or his or her designee, is authorized to execute on behalf of the
city and file with the Federal Communications Commission certification forms or
other instruments as are now or may hereafter be required by the FCC rate
regulations in order to enable the city to regulate basic service rates and
charges.
(Prior Code, § 111.10) (Ord. 12-1993, passed 11-9-1993)
CHAPTER 112: PEDDLERS, HAWKERS, SOLICITORS AND ITINERANT DEALERS
Section
   
112.01   Definitions
   
112.02   License fees
   
112.03   Surety bond required
   
112.04   Exceptions
   
112.05   Nuisances declared
   
112.06   Solicitation and distribution at or in public places
 
   
112.99   Penalty
§ 112.01 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   HAWKER. Anyone who goes about the streets, or elsewhere in the city, selling
or offering for sale, any goods by public outcry, placards, signals or any
other device designed to attract purchasers.
   ITINERANT DEALER. Any transient person or any person who shall engage
temporarily in the making or selling of any kinds of goods, wares or
merchandise within the city, regardless of whether the goods, wares or
merchandise are peddled from house to house, sold on the streets or other
public places, or sold from any room, branch store, establishment or concern,
building, structure or lot owned, rented or leased for the purpose of carrying
on a temporary business.
   PEDDLER. Anyone who goes about the streets or from house to house selling or
offering for sale, any goods, wares, merchandise or other articles.
   SOLICITOR. Any transient person who goes from house to house or from place
to place in the city selling or taking orders for, or offering to sell or take
orders for goods, wares, merchandise, service or any other thing of value
whatsoever.
(Prior Code, § 112.01) Penalty, see §
112.99
§ 112.02 LICENSE FEES.
   (A)   For each foot peddler, hawker, solicitor or itinerant dealer of goods,
wares or merchandise, or other articles or products, the license fee shall be:
 
For each day, when taken by the day     $10
For each week, when taken by the week   $40
For each month, when taken by the month $100
For each year, when taken by the year   $300
 
   (B)   For each peddler, hawker, solicitor, itinerant dealer of any articles
or service dispensed from any vehicle or conveyance:
 
For each day, when taken by the day     $15
For each week, when taken by the week   $60
For each month, when taken by the month $150
For each year, when taken by the year   $450
 
(Prior Code, § 112.02) Penalty, see §
112.99
§ 112.03 SURETY BOND REQUIRED.
   (A)   In addition to the license fee required herein, the applicant for
license shall be required to file and deposit with the Clerk-Treasurer a bond
with sureties to be approved by the Clerk-Treasurer in the penal sum of $5,000
running to the city.
   (B)   The bond shall be for the use and benefit of any purchaser of any
goods, wares or merchandise or service who might have a cause of action of any
nature arising out of a sale against the applicant, or for the payment of any
fines that may be assessed against the applicant, agents or employees for the
violation of this section, or the satisfaction of all cause of action commenced
within one year of the date that the sale is made provided that the aggregate
liability of the surety on the bond shall in no event exceed the amount of the
bond and that there shall be no limit of liability against the foot peddler,
solicitor, hawker or itinerant dealer, or the applicant for the license;
provided further, the Clerk-Treasurer, in lieu of the bond, may accept proof by
the applicant that he or she is presently bonded in the penal sum of $5,000 or
more, which would provide coverage for sales made within the city during the
time of the applicant’s license.
(Prior Code, § 112.03) Penalty, see §
112.99
§ 112.04 EXCEPTIONS.
   (A)   The license provided for in §
112.02 shall apply to all peddlers, whether selling goods for cash or immediate
delivery, or on orders. For future delivery or on the installment plan, and to
hawkers, solicitors, itinerant dealers, and to all persons assisting in
conducting the business, selling for cash on immediate delivery or taking
orders for future delivery or selling on the installment plan, but this section
shall not apply to agricultural products or fruits cultivated and grown by any
peddler, hawker or itinerant dealer.
   (B)   The provisions of this section shall not apply to the sale of
newspapers, meat, wood, coal, ice or milk and sales made to dealers by
commercial travelers, and nothing in this section shall be so construed and
enforced to place a burden on interstate commerce.
(Prior Code, § 112.04) Penalty, see §
112.99
§ 112.05 NUISANCES DECLARED.
   The practice or act of going in and on private property or residences, by
solicitors, peddlers, hawkers, itinerant merchants or transient vendors of
merchandise, not having been requested or invited to do so by the owner or
occupant of the private property or residences, for the purpose of soliciting
orders for the sale of goods, wares or merchandise, or the rendering or
furnishing of any service or for the purpose of disposing of or peddling,
hawking, rendering or furnishing the same, is declared to be a nuisance and to
be unlawful.
(Prior Code, § 112.05) Penalty, see §
112.99
§ 112.06 SOLICITATION AND DISTRIBUTION AT OR IN PUBLIC PLACES.
   (A)   Definitions. For the purpose of this section, the following
definitions shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a
different meaning.
      DISTRIBUTION. The offering, giving, distributing or making available for
distributing of any item of property, including but not limited to food, drink,
leaflets or other written materials, by any person or who is a bona fide
resident of the county, and any organization which is located or based in the
county.
      ORGANIZATION. A person or group of persons who is or are bona fide
residents of the county; and any corporation, whether for-profit or not-for-
profit; any charitable association, corporation or entity; any church or other
religious-based entity; any civic group or entity; any service club or entity;
any labor union or other labor-based association or entity; and any municipal,
county, state or federal governmental group, department, agency or entity of
any governmental unit, or other organization which is has an office or locally
based location within the county, including any national, state or regional
charitable, religious or educational organization.
      PUBLIC PLACE. Includes any street, alley, highway, sidewalk, park, public
conveyance, building or other place that is open or available to the general
public at large and owned, operated and maintained by any municipal, county,
state or federal governmental unit or entity.
      SOLICITATION. The requesting, pleading, appealing or the attempt or
exercise of requesting, pleading, appealing for the purpose of obtaining money
or other objects as donations from members of the general public by any
organization, charitable or otherwise, on or within any public place.
   (B)   Solicitation or distribution. Any person or organization that desires
to engage in the solicitation of money or other objects or to engage in the
distribution of any item of property from or to members of the general public
at or on any public place located within the corporate limits of the city must,
prior to solicitation or distribution, register the name of the person or
organization who desires to engage in solicitation or distribution with the
Clerk-Treasurer during normal business hours of that office at least two weeks
prior to the intended date of solicitation or distribution. Registration shall
include the following information:
      (1)   The name and address of the organization intending on engaging in
solicitation or distribution;
      (2)   The date(s) of the planned solicitation or distribution;
      (3)   The intended locations(s) of the planned solicitation or
distribution;
      (4)   The purpose of the intended solicitation or distribution; and
      (5)   The name and address of any person in charge of or supervising the
intended solicitation or distribution.
   (C)   Solicitation or distribution requirements. Any person or organization
engaging in solicitation or distribution pursuant to this chapter shall comply
with the following:
      (1)   Place or carry a flat sign or placard not attached to any container
in a place clearly visible to the general public affected by the solicitation
or distribution that clearly identifies the organization engaging in the
solicitation or distribution to the public affected thereby and that is clearly
readable to persons in vehicles and pedestrian passers-by;
      (2)   The sign or placard shall state the purpose of the solicitation or
distribution;
      (3)   The intended solicitation or distribution shall be performed only
during daylight hours;
      (4)   The person or persons engaging in the solicitation or distribution
shall wear bright colored protective vests that are clearly visible to
motorists and other passersby if the solicitation or distribution is occurring
at or on a public street, road or highway, or the intersection thereof; and
      (5)   The Police Department may cause any solicitation or distribution
provided for by this ordinance to cease or terminate if any congested traffic
condition or emergency occurs.
   (D)   Solicitation or distribution limited. Any person or organization
engaging in solicitation or distribution within the corporate limits of the
city, or desiring to engage in solicitation or distribution, shall be entitled
to do so only one time during any calendar year. Any desired solicitation or
distribution more than one time per year shall be at the sole discretion of the
Board of Public Works and Safety.
   (E)   Solicitation or distribution prohibited. No person or organization
shall engage in solicitation or distribution in any intersection, street or
highway, for any purpose, charitable or otherwise.
(Prior Code, § 112.06) (Ord. 12-2003, passed 9-9-2003; Ord. 13-2009, passed 12-
8-2009) Penalty, see §
112.99
§ 112.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter shall be subject to a civil
penalty of $100. A separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day that
a violation occurs or continues.
(Prior Code, § 112.99) (Ord. 12-2003, passed 9-9-2003)

GENERAL REGULATIONS
§ 113.01 FEES FOR CIRCUSES, PARADES AND WILD WEST SHOWS.
   (A)   For each show commonly known as a circus or as a wild west show, or
any show of similar character, the license fee shall be $60 for each day.
   (B)   For each parade of a show in the city, the license fee shall be $60.
   (C)   However, where a show is showing within the city limits and has
procured a license from the city to show, no license fee shall be charged by
the city for a parade of the show.
   (D)   For each show accompanying any show and known as a side show, the
license fee shall be $5.
   (E)   It shall be unlawful for any circus or side show to exhibit in the
city any indecent or immoral performance. Exhibitions shall be conducted in an
orderly manner and no gambling or any immoral practices shall be allowed on the
grounds occupied or controlled by any show management. In making any parade of
a circus on the streets of the city, the parade shall be conducted in an
orderly and decorous manner and in a manner so as to cause no injury directly
or indirectly to any person or property.
(Prior Code, § 113.01) Penalty, see §
113.99
§ 113.02 ANIMAL SHOWS; FEES.
   For each trained animal show or menagerie, the license fee shall be:
   (A)   For each day, when taken by the day: $20; and
   (B)   For each week, when taken by the week: $60.
(Prior Code, § 113.02) Penalty, see §
113.99
§ 113.03 NON-SPECIFIED EXHIBITIONS AND ENTERTAINMENTS.
   For exhibitions and entertainments not herein, or in any other ordinance of
the city specifically provided for, the license fee shall be:
   (A)   For each day: $15; and
   (B)   For each week: $50.
(Prior Code, § 113.03) Penalty, see §
113.99
§ 113.04 MEDICINE SHOWS, LECTURES AND EXHIBITIONS; FEES.
   For shows, exhibitions, lectures, discourses or entertainments for the sale
or advertisement of medicine, medical remedies or methods of treatment of
diseases, or for the sale or advertisement of any article, held in any room,
hall, building on the street or vacant grounds, whether admission is charged to
the same or not, the license fee shall be $10 for each day.
(Prior Code, § 113.04) Penalty, see §
113.99
§ 113.05 STREET FAIRS OR CARNIVALS.
   (A)   For every aggregation of shows, exhibitions or entertainments,
commonly known as a street fair or carnival, where aggregation is carried on
under one or a common management, the license for the same shall be:
      (1)   For each day, when taken by the day: $25; and
      (2)   For each week of six days: $125.
   (B)   Where shows, exhibitions or entertainments are under separate
management, for each of the shows, exhibitions or features of entertainment
constituting aggregation, the license fee shall be:
      (1)   For each day when taken by the day: $6; and
      (2)   For each week, when taken by the week: $25
(Prior Code, § 113.05) Penalty, see §
113.99
§ 113.06 SKATING RINKS, GYMNASIUMS OR OTHER SPORTS EVENTS.
   For each commercial skating rink, gymnasium or place where polo, basketball
and like games are played, or other miscellaneous entertainments are held, the
license fee shall be $3 for each day when the license is taken by the day; $4
for each week when the license is taken by the week; $10 for each month when
taken by the month; and $20 for each year when a license is taken by the year.
(Prior Code, § 113.06) Penalty, see §
113.99
§ 113.07 SHOOTING GALLERY AND PICTURE MACHINE; FEES.

   (A)   For each day: $1;
   (B)   For each week: $5;
   (C)   For each month: $7; and
   (D)   For each year: $20.
