§ 113.08 STRIKING, BLOWING OR ELECTRIC MACHINE; FEES.
   For each striking, lifting, pulling, blowing or electric machine:
   (A)   For each day: $1;
   (B)   For each week: $5;
   (C)   For each month: $7; and
   (D)   For each year: $20;
(Prior Code, § 113.08) Penalty, see §
113.99
§ 113.09 MERRY-GO-ROUND; FEES.
   (A)   For each merry-go-round:
      (1)   For each day: $3;
      (2)   For each week: $10;
      (3)   For each month: $12; and
      (4)   For each year: $20
   (B)   It is declared unlawful for any person, firm, company or corporation
to conduct or operate the same on any lot or plot of ground within one block
from National Avenue, extending from Alabama Street west to the city limits.
(Prior Code, § 113.09) Penalty, see §
113.99
§ 113.10 BILLIARD, POOL OR OTHER MACHINES OR DEVICES.
   No person shall have, keep, operate or maintain for hire or profit in any
public or private place, any billiard, pool or bagatelle table, any electronic
video game, pinball machine and any other mechanical or electrical gaming
machine or device or other machine or device for sports and games, without
obtaining a license specifying the number of tables, games and devices
renewable on or before January 1, 2007 and each year thereafter, conspicuously
displaying the license in the place or establishment where the table, machine
or device is placed or kept, and paying the following annual license fee:
   (A)   For each billiard, pool or bagatelle table: $25 per table;
   (B)   For each electronic video game, pinball machine, other mechanical or
electronic gaming machine or device or other machine or device for sports and
games: $25 per machine; and
   (C)   For each additional or new table, game, machine or device, obtained
following the issuance of the annual license, a new license must be obtained by
payment of the respective fees, specified in divisions (A) or (B) above, for
each additional table, game or device placed in the establishment where the
same are to be operated.
(Prior Code, § 113.10) (Ord. 28-2005, passed 8-24-2005) Penalty, see §
113.99
§ 113.11 BOWLING ALLEYS; FEES.
   For each bowling alley kept for hire:
   (A)   For each day: $1;
   (B)   For each week: $3;
   (C)   For each month: $8; and
   (D)   For each year: $10.
(Prior Code, § 113.11)
§ 113.12 JUNK STORES OR PAWN BROKERS; FEES.
   (A)   For carrying on the business of junk stores or pawnbroker, the license
fee shall be $10 for each year.
   (B)   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
      JUNK DEALER. One who keeps a place of business for the purchase or sale
of junk, old metal, rags, old rope, old canvas, old paper or the like.
      PAWNBROKER. Any person who loans money on deposit or pledge of personal
property on condition of selling the property or other valuable things or who
deals in the purchasing of personal property on condition of selling the same
back again.
   (C)   (1)   Every person, company or corporation holding a license from the
city to conduct the business of a pawnbroker and conducting the business in the
city thereunder, shall make a report in writing to the Marshal on Monday of
each and every week in which report shall be set out every article of jewelry,
watches, rings, silverware, bric-a-brac and other small articles of property,
which have been pawned or sold to or for any purpose left with the pawnbroker
during the calendar week just preceding, and the report shall give the name and
place of residence of the persons so pawning, selling or depositing any
article, and give a full and detailed description of every article together
with the probable value thereof and the time of so leaving the same.
      (2)   Every junk dealer in the city shall make a report as aforesaid on
Monday of each week in which he or she shall state, set out and describe all
brass or copper that may have been purchased by him or her during the preceding
calendar week, giving the name of the person from whom the same was purchased.
And it is further ordained that no person, firm or corporation shall conduct
the business of junk dealer within two city blocks of National Avenue or within
two city blocks of any church, hospital or public school building.
(Prior Code, § 113.12) Penalty, see §
113.99

§ 113.31 ITINERANT OR TRANSIENT PHOTOGRAPHER; FEES.
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business or to
exercise the vocation of an itinerant or transient photographer in the city
without having first procured from the city a license to do so and pay to the
city for the license the sums of money hereinafter designated.
   (B)   Any person desiring to procure the license as above provided for shall
pay to the Clerk-Treasurer the fee hereinafter provided, for which the Clerk-
Treasurer shall execute to the applicant his or her receipt. On presentation of
a receipt to the Clerk-Treasurer, the Clerk-Treasurer shall issue to the
applicant a license to conduct the business or vocation of an itinerant or
transient photographer, as the same is hereinafter defined, within the city for
the period of time for which the applicant shall have paid according to the
scale hereinafter set out. The license shall be signed by the Clerk-Treasurer.
The license shall be issued for the period of one day or for any number of days
less than one week, or for one week, or for any number of weeks less than one
month, or for one month or for any number of months less than one year,
according as the same may be applied and paid for, and the charge for the
license shall be:
      (1)   For each day: $2;
      (2)   For each week: $10;
      (3)   For each month: $25; and
      (4)   For each year: $100.
   (C)   For the purpose of this section, an ITINERANT PHOTOGRAPHER or
TRANSIENT PHOTOGRAPHER shall be any person who goes about from place to place
in the city taking photographs or pictures of scenes, objects, buildings,
structures, animals or person or groups, assemblages or processions of persons,
for hire or pay, or for the purpose of developing the negatives so taken and
selling the developed picture or negative, or for the purpose of receiving
compensation, or a consideration for a work or picture, in any way.
   (D)   It is declared unlawful for any person so licensed as hereinbefore
provided, or for any person not so licensed, engaged as an itinerant or
transient photographer or acting as so in the city, to take any flash light
picture of any public assemblage or person or persons in any church, theater,
hall, building or other enclosure in the city, and any person engaged as a
photographer in the city is prohibited from taking any obscene, licentious,
indecent or immoral pictures or from taking any snapshot of any person against
the wishes of the person or to his or her annoyance, except the snapshot be
taken to aid in the detection and prosecution of crime.
(Prior Code, § 113.31) Penalty, see §
113.99
§ 113.32 THEATERS OR OPERA HOUSES.
   (A)   Authority is granted to the Clerk-Treasurer for the issuing of a
license by the city, to the owner, lessee or person in control of any theater,
opera house, room, building or other designated place in the city for show or
exhibitions in those places, which license shall be known as a “house license”
and shall be issued for the period of one year only. The license must be
secured before shows or exhibitions may take place.
   (B)   The license fee for a license shall be $25 for any show charging an
admission of not to exceed $0.05 and $50 for any show charging an admission of
not to exceed $0.10 and $75 for any show charging an admission of more than
$0.10.

separate offense.

CHAPTER 114: TAXICABS AND COMMERCIAL VEHICLES
Section
   
114.01   Commercial vehicle defined
   
114.02   Bond, liability contract and insurance requirements
   
114.03   Application procedure; sign designation
   
114.04   Annual license fee
   
114.05   Time and days of operation
   
114.06   Legal age for operation of vehicle
   
114.07   Receiving and discharging passengers
   
114.08   Notification of police of lost articles
   
114.09   License revocation by Council and suspension by Mayor
 
   
114.99   Penalty
§ 114.01 COMMERCIAL VEHICLE DEFINED.
   (A)   Every person, firm or corporation operating any motor vehicle along
and on any public street or highway within the city, for the purpose of
affording a means of local street or highway transportation by accepting and
discharging persons as may offer themselves for transportation either at
temporary street or highway parking places or along the course or within the
terminal on which the motor vehicle is or may be running or operating or that
may be operated for the transportation of passengers, from place to place in or
about the city from any street curb, alley or highway stand or stands, or
parking or stopping places, either on calls or otherwise, from so, is declared
to be a commercial motor vehicle for hire.
   (B)   This section does not include motor vehicles owned and operated by
hotel companies or hotel proprietors, between their hotels and depots, for
their exclusive use and benefit in conveying their guests to and from the same.
(Prior Code, § 114.01) (Ord. 63-1931, passed 9-22-1931)
§ 114.02 BOND, LIABILITY CONTRACT AND INSURANCE REQUIREMENTS.
   (A)   No person, firm or corporation shall operate any commercial vehicle,
and it shall be unlawful to do so, unless there shall have been filed with the
Clerk-Treasurer, duly approved and accepted by the Mayor thereof, a good and
sufficient indemnity surety or indemnity company created under the laws of the
state, or duly authorized to transact business thereunder, which the bond shall
describe the motor vehicle by factory number, maker’s name, rated seating
capacity and number of passengers capable of being accommodated therein at one
time, and number of state and city license under which the same is operated.
   (B)   (1)   When the license is changed by the issuance of a new one, it
shall be indicated on a bond by the attachment of a rider thereto. The bond
shall provide, among other things, that the company issuing the same shall be
liable for and pay all damages including injury to person or property not
exceeding $300,000 to any one person, or $300,000 for any one accident that may
be recovered in any action against the person, firm or corporation so licensed
to operate the commercial vehicle by reason of the negligent use and operation
of the same.
      (2)   However, when any claim has been made or an action commenced
against a person, firm or corporation operating the commercial vehicle,
described in the bond, growing out of an accident by reason of the operation
thereof and while operating hereunder, the person, firm or corporation shall
not further operate the commercial vehicle hereunder until another bond meeting
the requirements of this section shall have been filed.
      (3)   In lieu of the furnishing and filing of the bond the person, firm
or corporation shall have filed with the Clerk-Treasurer a liability contract
of insurance issued him or her by an insurance company organized under the laws
of the state, or authorized to transact business herein, providing among other
things, for the payment of any final judgment that may be rendered against the
insured for damages to property or bodily injury or death to others resulting
from accident or collision for which the person, firm or corporation may be
liable as a common carrier while operating the commercial vehicle described
therein within the provisions hereof by reason of and growing out of the
negligent operation of the commercial vehicle.
   (C)   The bond or insurance shall be in a sum not less than $300,000 to
cover liability to property or person and $300,000 to cover liability and
damages for property or persons as a result of any one accident.
   (D)   (1)   The policy contract of insurance or bond shall further, among
other things, provide that in the event of a final judgment being rendered or
sustained against the insured, within the provisions of the company’s assumed
liability, payment thereof to the insured shall not be made, without the
written consent of the person recovering the same, within a period of one year
from the date the judgment was finally rendered or sustained. Thereafter, if
not paid, the person recovering judgment may be subrogated to all of the rights
and subject to the conditions of the insured and may directly enforce the
company’s liability, if it existed, and the contract shall further provide that
the stipulations and the conditions therein contained which refer to the
insured’s conduct with the company and company’s conduct with the insured, in
reference to accidents and claims thereunder and any rules governing the
conduct of the insured or company or any branch thereof shall not be a defense
in any action brought to enforce a liability under a policy or bond by any
person other than the insured.
      (2)   It shall be the duty of every person, firm or corporation to keep
the insurance or bond in force during the full period of time for which he or
she may be operating thereunder, and in case the policy contract of insurance
or bond is canceled, the city shall be notified and the contract shall so
provide, by suitable provision therein, and if any bond so filed shall become
inoperative or the policy of insurance canceled, the commercial vehicle shall
not be operated until a bond or policy of insurance meeting the requirements of
this section shall have been filed.
(Prior Code, § 114.02) (Ord. 9-2004, passed 5-11-2004) Penalty, see §
114.99
§ 114.03 APPLICATION PROCEDURE; SIGN DESIGNATION.
   (A)   (1)   A bond or policy contract of insurance shall be accompanied by
an application on blanks furnished by the city, stating the name, age, (if an
individual) business and residence of the applicant and the length of time in
which he or she has operated motor driven vehicles, the territory within which
it is proposed to operate, the commercial vehicle or the manner or method of
operation and the proposed hours, the character of operation and the rate of
fare to be charged for carriage therein.
      (2)   It shall state the license number and a description of the vehicle
to be used by factory number and maker’s name, rated seating capacity and
number of persons capable of being carried therein at one time.
   (B)   (1)   If the application and bond or policy contract of insurance
compares with the provisions hereinbefore set forth and the applicant has paid
the hereinafter license fee, the Clerk-Treasurer shall thereupon issue to the
applicant a license permitting the operating of the commercial vehicle therein
described under the provisions of this chapter, which license shall be numbered
severally, contain the number of the motor vehicle, state license number, date
of its issuance and expiration thereof.
      (2)   It shall be the duty of the person, firm or corporation receiving
the license, to plainly mark, in a permanent manner, each commercial vehicle
covered thereby by painting or securely fastening on the sides thereof in
letters not less than two inches in height and the letters of which shall be
not less than one-fourth-inch in width, the words “Bonded Carrier” or “Insured
Carrier” (as the case may be) followed by the city license number, so that all
commercial vehicles claimed to be operated under the provisions of this
division may be readily identified.
(Prior Code, § 114.03) (Ord. 63-1931, passed 9-22-1931) Penalty, see §
114.99
§ 114.04 ANNUAL LICENSE FEE.
   Any person, firm or corporation desiring to obtain a license hereunder shall
pay to the City Clerk-Treasurer for the benefit of the city for each commercial
vehicle to be so driven or operated an annual license fee of $10.
(Prior Code, § 114.04) (Ord. 63-1931, passed 9-22-1931) Penalty, see §
114.99
§ 114.05 TIME AND DAYS OF OPERATION.
   All vehicles operating under this chapter shall be operated at least five
days out of each and every week and shall be operated at least eight hours on
each of the days so required to be operated.
(Prior Code, § 114.05) (Ord. 63-1931, passed 9-22-1931) Penalty, see §
114.99
§ 114.06 LEGAL AGE FOR OPERATION OF VEHICLE.
   No license shall be issued to any person under the age of 18 years, and it
shall be unlawful for any person under the age of 18 years to drive or operate
any commercial vehicle or for any licensee to cause or permit any person,
underage, to drive or operate a commercial vehicle so licensed for the purpose
herein provided.
(Prior Code, § 114.06) (Ord. 63-1931, passed 9-22-1931) Penalty, see §
114.99
§ 114.07 RECEIVING AND DISCHARGING PASSENGERS.
   (A)   Every person, firm or corporation operating commercial vehicles
hereunder shall receive and discharge passengers as close to the right-hand
curb of streets as possible and shall at all times keep vehicle so used in a
clean and sanitary condition, and no person shall be permitted to sit or stand
on the running board or fenders, or sit in the doors or door while same is in
motion.
   (B)   The left rear door, while a commercial vehicle is being operated
hereunder, shall be locked or otherwise fastened, so that it cannot be opened.
The rear or tonneau part of every commercial vehicle, while in operation, shall
be lighted during the night time when a winter top is used thereon and the
sides thereof closed.
(Prior Code, § 114.07) (Ord. 63-1931, passed 9-22-1931) Penalty, see §
114.99
§ 114.08 NOTIFICATION OF POLICE OF LOST ARTICLES.
   It shall be the duty of every person, firm or corporation operating under
the provisions hereof to promptly notify the Police Department of all articles
found in any commercial vehicles operated by them, a description thereof, where
they are kept and where they may be found so as to be returned to the owner.
(Prior Code, § 114.08) (Ord. 63-1931, passed 9-22-1931)
§ 114.09 LICENSE REVOCATION BY COUNCIL AND SUSPENSION BY MAYOR.
   (A)   The Common Council may revoke any license issued hereunder on notice
to the licensee, and after a due hearing for the violation of any of the
provisions of this chapter.
   (B)   When any person has been convicted for three successive times within a
period of six months of violation of any of the provisions of this chapter or
any other ordinance of the city regulating street travel of motor vehicles, the
license of the person may be, by the Mayor, suspended for a period not to
exceed 90 days nor less than 30 days during which time the commercial vehicles
shall not be operated hereunder.
   (C)   The licensee may appeal from suspension to the Common Council and, on
hearing, the Common Council in its discretion may either affirm or overrule the
suspension of the Mayor; if overruled, the commercial vehicle may continue
operating under the license.
(Prior Code, § 114.09) (Ord. 63-1931, passed 9-22-1931)
§ 114.99 PENALTY.
   Any person, firm or corporation, on conviction for the violation of, or
failure to comply with, any provisions of this chapter shall be fined in any
sum not less than $5 and not more than $25 for each and every offense
hereunder.
(Prior Code, § 114.99) (Ord. 63-1931, passed 9-22-1931)
CHAPTER 115: GASOLINE STATION REGULATIONS
Section
   
115.01   Written consent for gasoline stations
   
115.02   Description and location; removal or relocation
   
115.03   Specification of exact location
   
115.04   Restrictions on city square
 
   
115.99   Penalty
§ 115.01 WRITTEN CONSENT FOR GASOLINE STATIONS.
   It shall be unlawful for any person, company or corporation to hereafter
install any gasoline filling station in any street, alley or sidewalk or other
public place, or in any place where an installation is made for the purpose of
selling gasoline or oil or both at retail or wholesale prices within the city
without having first obtained the written consent of the Street and Alley
Committee or Common Council in writing signed by the Chairperson of the
Committee.
(Prior Code, § 115.01) (Ord. 17-1931, passed 9-22-1931) Penalty, see §
115.99
§ 115.02 DESCRIPTION AND LOCATION; REMOVAL OR RELOCATION.
   (A)   Before locating any gasoline station filling station, the person,
company or corporation desiring to do so shall give notice in writing to the
Committee or to the Common Council of his or her desire to locate a gasoline
filling station and shall set out in a notice a description of the place on
which it is desired to locate the same.
   (B)   The Street and Alley Committee or the City Engineer, together with the
person or the representative of the company or corporation, shall go over the
street, alley or public place named in the notice and the committee, City
Engineer shall designate the exact place where the filling station shall be
erected and maintained, subject however, to future removal or relocation on
reasonable notice from the city in the event of reasonable requirements of
street or other public improvements or other reasonable necessity for the
removal or relocation of the filling station; and the city shall be the sole
judge of the reasonable necessity for the removal or relocation of any filling
station at any subsequent time.
(Prior Code, § 115.02) (Ord. 17-1931, passed 9-22-1931) Penalty, see §
115.99
§ 115.03 SPECIFICATION OF EXACT LOCATION.
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for a person, company or corporation to install
any filling station at a point other than that designated by the committee or
City Engineer, and the written permit provided for in §
115.02 shall specify the exact location of the filling station so designated by
the Committee or City Engineer and it is provided, that in case of the
installation of the same at a point other than the place designated as
aforesaid or in case there should exist a reasonable necessity for the removal
or relocation of any filling station for reasons as set out in §
115.02 hereof.
   (B)   If the person, company or corporation so installing any filling
station shall fail or refuse after reasonable notice, to remove or relocate the
filling station, then in any event, the city, through its officers and
officials and employees, shall have the right to remove or relocate any filling
station and the costs of the removal or relocation may be recovered in any
court of competent jurisdiction by the city from the person, company or
corporation owning the station and failing to obey the city’s notice to
relocate or remove the same.
(Prior Code, § 115.03) (Ord. 17-1931, passed 9-22-1931) Penalty, see §
115.99
§ 115.04 RESTRICTIONS ON CITY SQUARE.
   It is provided that there shall be only one gasoline filling station located
and installed in any street, alley, sidewalk or other public place on either
side of any city square.
(Prior Code, § 115.04) (Ord. 17-1931, passed 9-22-1931) Penalty, see §
115.99
§ 115.99 PENALTY.
   Any person or corporation violating any of the provisions of this chapter
shall, on conviction thereof, be fined in any sum not less than $1 or more than
$100 and each day’s continuance in the violation shall constitute a separate
offense.
(Prior Code, § 115.99) (Ord. 17-1931, passed 9-22-1931)
CHAPTER 116: ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES
Section
   
116.01   Definitions
   
116.02   Persons exempted from regulations
   
116.03   Offenses
   
116.04   Recycling containers exempted
   
116.05   Signs posted
 
   
116.99   Penalty
§ 116.01 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGE. Has the same meaning as set forth in I.C. 7.1-1-3-5, or
a liquid or solid that is, or contains, 0.5% or more alcohol by volume; is fit
for human consumption; and is reasonable likely, or intended, to be used as a
beverage.
   CAR. A motor vehicle, that, in common usage, is referred to as a CAR. Common
elements of a CAR include four tires, front and back seats that do not provide
room for standing and the names “sedans” and “convertibles.”
   CONTAINER. Has the same meaning as set forth in I.C. 7.1-1-3-13, or a
receptacle in which an alcoholic beverage is immediately contained and with
which the alcoholic beverage contained in it is in immediate contact.
   IMMEDIATE AREA.
      (1)   For vans, the interior area of the van, which is located behind the
area farthest to the back of the van where a seat can be affixed, regardless if
the seat is, in fact, affixed.
      (2)   For station wagons and other cars without trunks, the total area of
the interior of the car, except the area to the rear of the seat which is
located the farthest to the back.
      (3)   For cars with trunks, the total interior area of the car.
      (4)   For recreational vehicles, the interior area encompassing the front
seats. This area includes the area between the driver’s and front passenger
doors, the glove compartment, dashboard, interior windshield area and any
cavities in the driver’s door and front passenger door.
      (5)   For all other types of motor vehicles including all types of
trucks, the total interior of the motor vehicle.
   MOTOR VEHICLE. As set forth in I.C. 9-13-2-105, a vehicle that is self-
propelled, including motorcycles and motorized bicycles that are self-
propelled.
   RECREATIONAL VEHICLE. As set forth in I.C. 9-13-2-150, not including vans.
   TRUCK. As set forth in I.C. 9-13-2-188.
   VAN.
      (1)   A motor vehicle that, in common usage, is referred to as a VAN.
      (2)   Included within this definition are motor vehicles commonly
referred to as “converted vans,” “mini-vans” and “passenger vans.” This
definition applies to all VANS, whether or not back seats are affixed.
(Prior Code, § 91.01) (Ord. 11-1993, passed 9-28-1993)
§ 116.02 PERSONS EXEMPTED FROM REGULATIONS.
   (A)   The following individuals shall be exempt from this chapter:
      (1)   A passenger of a vehicle in which the driver is operating the
vehicle pursuant to a contract to provide transportation for passengers and the
driver holds a valid chauffeur’s license pursuant to I.C. 9-24-4-0.5;
      (2)   A passenger of a bus in which the driver holds a valid chauffeur’s
license pursuant to I.C. 9-24-4-0.5; and
      (3)   A passenger in a recreational vehicle.
   (B)   The exemption in division (A)(3) above shall not apply to any
passenger located in the immediate area.
(Prior Code, § 91.02) (Ord. 11-1993, passed 9-28-1993)
§ 116.03 OFFENSES.
   Any person who knowingly consumes an alcoholic beverage or possesses a
container that has been opened, that has a broken seal or from which some of
the contents have been removed, while in a motor vehicle that is being operated
on a public street within the city commits a violation of this chapter with the
following exception: A person may possess a container that has been opened,
that has a broken seal or from which some of the contents have been removed, if
the container is possessed solely for the purpose of transporting the same, or
storage, are not consumed in the motor vehicle, are not present in the
immediate area and are otherwise allowed to be possessed under state law. The
operator or owner of a motor vehicle who, while the motor vehicle is in
operation, knowingly keeps or allows to be kept in the immediate area of the
motor vehicle a container that has been opened, that has a broken seal or from
which some of the contents have been removed, commits a violation of this
chapter.
(Prior Code, § 91.03) (Ord. 11-1993, passed 9-28-1993) Penalty, see §
91.99
§ 116.04 RECYCLING CONTAINERS EXEMPTED.
   This chapter shall not be applicable to containers in generally recognized
trash bags, trash containers or recycling containers in a motor vehicle if the
operator is in the process of transporting same to a recycling facility or
other facility used for the deposit of solid waste materials, including
landfills.
(Prior Code, § 91.04) (Ord. 11-1993, passed 9-28-1993)
§ 116.05 SIGNS POSTED.
   Signs giving notice of this prohibition of open alcoholic beverage
containers shall be posted giving notice of this chapter at all locations
deemed appropriate by the Chief of Police or his or her designee to give the
public adequate notice hereof.
(Prior Code, § 91.05) (Ord. 11-1993, passed 9-28-1993)
§ 116.99 PENALTY.
   (A)   Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of this chapter and
who has been issued an ordinance violation citation by any officer of the City
Police Department shall be fined the sum of $50.
   (B)   For each subsequent citation issued to that person, the fine imposed
shall be not less than $100 and not more than $2,500, as determined by a court
of competent jurisdiction over ordinance violations.
(Prior Code, § 91.99) (Ord. 11-1993, passed 9-28-1993)
CHAPTER 117: WIRELESS COMMUNICATIONS FACILITIES
Section
   
117.01   Definitions
   
117.02   Administration
   
117.03   Procedure for implementation
§ 117.01 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   PERMIT. Any local permit, license, certificate, approval, registration or
similar form of approval required by policy, administrative rule, regulation,
ordinance or resolution with respect to a project.
   PROJECT. The construction or deployment of wireline or wireless
communications facilities to provide communications services (as defined in
I.C. 8-1-32.5-3) in a unit.
(Ord. 4-2020, passed 3-11-2020)
§ 117.02 ADMINISTRATION.
   Notwithstanding any other provision of the city’s ordinance(s), resolution
(s), regulation, policy or practice, the following shall apply to a project.
The applicable governing body of the unit shall:
   (A)   Appoint a single point of contact for all matters related to a
project;
   (B)   Establish procedures to allow all forms, applications, and
documentation related to a project to be filed or submitted and signed by
electronic means;
   (C)   Review and approve or reject all applications for a permit related to
a project within ten business days after an application is filed or submitted;
and
   (D)   Assure that after an application is approved pursuant to division (C)
above, any inspections, including any additional necessary approvals, related
to a project will occur in a timely and expeditious manner.
(Ord. 4-2020, passed 3-11-2020)
§ 117.03 PROCEDURE FOR IMPLEMENTATION.
   (A)   The city shall adopt adequate processes and procedures to implement
the provisions of §
117.02.
   (B)   Processes and procedures established hereunder may not do the
following:
      (1)   Require an applicant to designate a final contractor to complete a
project;
      (2)   Impose a fee to review an application or issue a permit for a
project;
      (3)   Impose a seasonal moratorium on the issuance of permits for a
project; or
      (4)   Discriminate among communications service providers or utilities
with respect to any action described in this section or otherwise related to a
project, including granting access to public rights-of-way, infrastructure and
poles, river and bridge crossings and any other physical assets owned or
controlled by the city.
(Ord. 4-2020, passed 3-11-2020)
TITLE XIII: GENERAL OFFENSES
   Chapter

GENERAL OFFENSES
§ 130.01 FIRING GUN WITHIN THE CITY; EXCEPTIONS.
   (A)   It is declared unlawful for any person to fire any gun or pistol in
the city.
   (B)   This provision shall not be construed to extend to any police officer,
nor to any peace officer while in the performance of any duty in pursuance of
any ordinance, or in obedience to any law of the state.
(Prior Code, § 90.60) (Ord. 16-1931, passed 9-22-1931) Penalty, see §
130.99
§ 130.02 GIVING FALSE ALARM IN PUBLIC PLACE PROHIBITED.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to strike a match, or to cry out “fire”
in a church, hall or theater, while the church, hall or theater is occupied by
a public assemblage, or to utter any cry tending to create a panic in the city.
(Prior Code, § 90.61) (Ord. 12-1931, passed 9-22-1931) Penalty, see §
130.99
§ 130.03 LITTERING.
   (A)   The city, having received complaints from the residents of the city
concerning certain litter violations occurring in and on city streets, declares
it unlawful to litter on any street located in the city.
   (B)   The City Street Department is directed to install sign locations
giving notice of anti-littering regulations on each U.S. 40, city limit west,
U.S. 40, city limit east, State Road 59, city limit north, and State Road 59,
city limit south.
(Prior Code, § 90.62) (Ord. 6-1991, passed 8-13-1991) Penalty, see §
130.99
§ 130.04 CONTROL OF PUBLIC ASSEMBLIES AND GROUPS.
   (A)   It shall be the duty of every owner, proprietor, manager or person in
control of any theater, opera, moving picture show, public entertainment or
public assembly, to keep the aisles and ways of ingress and egress to and in
the room where people are assembled, by chairs, persons or other unobstructed
obstructions of any kind or character, so in case of that fire or any other
emergency, the aisles in the room and the exits therefrom will be unobstructed,
and thereby facilitate the escape of persons from the room. The failure to
perform that duty is declared unlawful.
   (B)   It is declared unlawful for any person to obstruct the aisles in any
theater, opera, moving picture show public entertainment or other public
assembly, or the exits therefrom, by congregating or standing therein, or in
any other manner, to the end that aisles and exits shall be free and
unobstructed so that persons in the room in case of fire or other emergency,
may escape therefrom without any delay.
   (C)   (1)   In every room used for theatrical, operatic or moving picture
show purposes, or for public entertainments or public assemblies, the word
“Exit” shall be painted in plain English language, not less than eight inches
in length, over each door or place of egress, and every word “Exit” shall have
over the same a red light at times when the room is being used for public
gatherings.
      (2)   The light shall be in relation to the word “Exit” that the light
will be reflected thereon, so that the word “Exit” may be seen by all persons
in the room whenever the room is in use for any of the purposes aforesaid.
   (D)   It shall be the duty of every owner, proprietor, manager or person in
control of any moving picture show to cause to be constructed and maintained
from the film room, in which the films are operated, an airtight flue or duct
14 inches in diameter to the outside of the auditorium or assembly room in
order that all fumes and smoke may pass through the duct or flue from the film
room to the outside of the auditorium or assembly room in case of fire, and not
escape into the auditorium or assembly room, so that the danger of persons
breathing the poisonous fumes and gases and smoke will be prevented, and it
shall be unlawful to conduct any moving picture show or operate any film unless
the room in which the film is operated shall be connected with the outside of
the auditorium or assembly room by and with a flue or duct and it be so
arranged and constructed that the fumes and smoke and gases resulting from the
burning of the film, or other matter in the film room, will pass through the
duct to the outside of the auditorium or assembly room and not escape into the
auditorium or assembly room.
(Prior Code, § 90.63) (Ord. 20-1931, passed 9-22-1931) Penalty, see §
130.99
§ 130.05 DISTURBING THE PEACE.
   (A)   It is declared unlawful for any person to congregate, scuffle,
wrestle, box or to be guilty of any other boisterous or disorderly conduct on
any sidewalk in front of any plate glass window in any building in the city, or
to sit or lean against a window, or to loiter, or sit in, or in any manner to
obstruct any public stairway in any business building in the city, or to sit or
loiter on the steps or in the entrance to any building.
   (B)   It shall be and is declared unlawful for any person or persons to idle
or loiter in any public place, park, shed, car, car shop, outhouse, street,
alley, railroad depot or switch house in the city.
   (C)   It shall be unlawful for any person to be found begging in the city or
lying or sleeping in, along or on any public street, alley, park or public
place or grounds, or in any stable, outhouse, building, warehouse, shed,
railroad depot or railroad car, or in or about any yard, mill or factory in the
city, without having the permission of the owner or occupant thereof to sleep
or be in that place.
   (D)   Any person who, within the limits of the city, shall unnecessarily
make any loud and unusual noise and clamor, or commit any unseemly and
boisterous conduct, to the disturbance of the peace and quiet of the city shall
be deemed guilty of disorderly and unlawful conduct and, on conviction thereof,
shall be fined.
(Prior Code, § 90.64) (Ord. 71-1931, passed 9-22-1931) Penalty, see §
130.99
§ 130.06 RESISTING OFFICIAL ACTION.
   It shall be unlawful for any person or persons to knowingly or intentionally
interfere or attempt to impede or interfere with any city official or employee
in the performance of his or her official duties.
(Prior Code, § 90.06) Penalty, see §
130.99
CURFEW
§ 130.20 PURPOSE OF CURFEW.
   (A)   After review of relevant information provided by the Police
Department, the Common Council has deemed it necessary to enact restricted
curfew hours for minors in the city due to increased complaints of thefts,
criminal mischief and other juvenile involvement by children under 18 years of
age.
   (B)   The purpose of this subchapter is to protect minors from victimization
and exposure to criminal activity during late night hours, to promote the role
of parents in the raising and control of their children, to promote the health,
safety and welfare of persons and property in the city and promote the peace,
order and safety of cemeteries and other facilities used to memorialize the
dead.
(Prior Code, § 130.01) (Ord. 5-2000, passed 9-26-2000)
§ 130.21 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   DIRECT ROUTE. The shortest reasonable path of travel or a commonly used
route to reach a final destination without any detour or stop along the way.
   EMERGENCY.
      (1)   Any unforeseen circumstances or combination of circumstances, or
state or condition resulting therefrom, that requires or calls for immediate
action to safeguard life, limb or property.
      (2)   The term includes, but is not limited to, a fire, natural disaster,
an automobile accident or any situation requiring immediate action to prevent
or respond to any serious bodily injury or death or serious property damage.
   ESTABLISHMENT. Any privately owned place of business within the corporate
limits of the city operated for profit to which the public is invited,
including, but not limited to, any place of amusement or entertainment (such as
movie theater, pool or billiard establishment, concert hall, video machine
establishment and the like).
   MINOR. Any person under 18 years of age.
   OFFICER. A police officer or other law enforcement officer charged with the
duty of enforcing and having jurisdiction to enforce the laws of the state and
the ordinances of the city.
   OWNER/OPERATOR. Any person or entity operating, managing or conducting
business in any establishment, and the employees, agents, officers or
representatives thereof (including a sole proprietorship, partnership,
association or corporation).
   PARENT. A person who is a natural or biological mother or father, adoptive
parent, foster parent or stepparent of another person who has custody or
control of a minor, or other person to whom legal custody of a minor has been
given by court order.
   PUBLIC PLACE. A place to which the public or a substantial group of the
public has access, including, but not limited to, streets, highways, roads,
alleys or parking lots, transportation facilities, theaters, restaurants,
shops, bowling alleys, schools and school grounds, museums, playgrounds, places
of business and amusement, swimming pools, cemetery, community centers, YMCA,
hospitals, office buildings, governmental buildings and property and any other
areas that are open to or accessible to the public.
   RESTRICTED CURFEW HOURS.
      (1)   For a minor 15, 16 or 17 years of age: After 11:00 p.m. on any
Sunday, Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday or Thursday, and before 5:00 a.m. on Monday,
Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday or Friday, and between 1:00 a.m. and 5:00 a.m. on
Saturday and Sunday;
      (2)   For a minor less than 15 years of age: After 11:00 p.m. or before
5:00 a.m. on any day; and
      (3)   For a minor in a cemetery or other facility used to memorialize the
dead within the corporate limits of the city: After 9:00 p.m. and before 5:00
a.m. on any day.
(Prior Code, § 130.02) (Ord. 5-2000, passed 9-26-2000)
§ 130.22 VIOLATION OF RESTRICTED CURFEW HOURS.
   (A)   It shall be unlawful and a violation of this subchapter for a minor to
be or remain in or upon any public place or in or upon the premises of any
establishment within the corporate limits of the city during the restricted
curfew hours, unless:
      (1)   The minor is accompanied by a parent or legal guardian;
      (2)   The minor is involved in an emergency;
      (3)   The minor is engaged in a lawful employment activity, or is going
to or returning home from the activity by using a direct route without detour
or stop;
      (4)   The minor is on the sidewalk directly abutting a place where the
minor resides with a parent or guardian;
      (5)   The minor is attending or traveling to or from by direct route, a
legal school, religious or recreational activity that is supervised by adults
sponsored by a school, governmental entity, civic organization or other similar
entity;
      (6)   The minor is on an errand at the direction of a parent or guardian
and the minor has in his or her possession a writing signed by the parent or
guardian containing the following information: Name, signature, address and
telephone number of the parent or guardian authorizing the errand, the name of
the minor, the minor’s destination and the date and time that the minor is
authorized to be engaged in the errand;
      (7)   The minor is exercising his or her First Amendment rights protected
by the United States Constitution, such as the free exercise of religion,
freedom of speech and right of assembly; however, the mere presence or “hanging
out” of minors in public places, or the aimless cruising of city streets are
not considered to be within the protection of the First Amendment; or
      (8)   The minor is married and emancipated.
   (B)   It shall be unlawful and a violation of this subchapter for a parent
or guardian of a minor who knowingly permits, or by insufficient control
allows, the minor to be or remain in any public place or establishment within
the corporate limits of the city during the restricted curfews hours.
      (1)   For purposes of this division (B), the term KNOWINGLY includes
knowledge that a parent should reasonably be expected to have concerning the
whereabouts of the minor in that parent’s custody.
      (2)   It is the intent of this division (B) to hold a neglectful or
careless parent to a reasonable community standard of parental responsibility,
and it shall be no defense that a parent was indifferent to the activities or
conduct or whereabouts of his or her minor child.
   (C)   (1)   It shall be unlawful and a violation of this subchapter for an
owner/operator of an establishment to knowingly allow a minor to be or remain
upon the premises of an establishment during the restricted curfew hours.
      (2)   For purposes of this division (C), the term KNOWINGLY includes
knowledge that an owner/operator should reasonably be expected to have
concerning the patrons of the establishment, and the standard for KNOWINGLY
shall be whether a reasonable person in the owner/operator’s position should
have known that the patron was a minor in violation of the terms of this
subchapter.
   (D)   It shall be unlawful and a violation of this subchapter for any person
18 years of age or older to aid and abet a minor in violating the terms of this
subchapter, or for a parent or guardian to refuse to take custody during the
restricted curfew hours of a minor for whom the parent or guardian is
responsible.
(Prior Code, § 130.03) (Ord. 5-2000, passed 9-26-2000) Penalty, see §
130.99
§ 130.23 DEFENSE.
   It shall be a defense to prosecution for a violation of this subchapter when
the owner/operator of an establishment, or any employee, officer, agent or
representative thereof, or the person in charge of or overseeing a public
place, promptly notified the Police Department that a minor was present on the
premises of the establishment during the restricted curfew hours and refused to
leave.
(Prior Code, § 130.04) (Ord. 5-2000, passed 9-26-2000) Penalty, see §
130.99
§ 130.24 ENFORCEMENT.
   Before taking any official enforcement action pursuant to this subchapter,
the officer shall undertake an immediate investigation to determine whether or
not a violation of this subchapter has occurred, including asking the minor’s
name, address, age, name of parent(s) or guardian, the reason for being in a
public place or establishment during the restricted curfew hours and requesting
any writing from the minor’s parents or guardian as provided for in this
subchapter. If the officer determines that a violation has occurred, the
officer shall issue an ordinance violation citation to the minor, to the parent
or guardian of the minor who likewise is in violation, to the owner/operator of
an establishment who is in violation or any other person who is in violation of
this subchapter, charging the violator(s) with a violation of this subchapter.
(Prior Code, § 130.05) (Ord. 5-2000, passed 9-26-2000) Penalty, see §
130.99
§ 130.99 PENALTY.
   (A)   Any person violating any provision of this chapter for which no
specific penalty is prescribed shall be subject to §
10.99 of this code of ordinances.
   (B)   (1)   Violations of any provision of §
130.01 shall be fined not less than $1 nor more than $10.
      (2)   Violations of any provision of §
130.02 shall be fined not less than $1 nor more than $25.
      (3)   Violations of any provision of §
130.04 shall be fined not less than $5 nor more than $100.
      (4)   Violations of any provision of §
130.05 shall be fined not more than $10.
(Prior Code, § 90.99)
   (C)   Any person who litters on a street located in the city in violation of
§
130.03 shall be fined $500.
(Prior Code, § 90.62)
   (D)   (1)   Violations of any provision of §
130.20 shall be fined not less than $1 nor more than $100.
      (2)   Violations of any provision of §
130.22 shall be fined not less than $1 nor more than $10.
      (3)   Violations of any provision of §
130.23 shall be fined not less than $1 nor more than $25.
      (4)   Violations of any provision of §
130.24 shall be fined not less than $5 nor more than $100.
      (5)   For violations of §§
130.20 through 130.024, a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each
day that a violation occurs or continues.
      (6)   Any minor 15 to 17 years of age who violates §
130.22(A) shall be subject to a civil penalty of $25.
      (7)   Any minor under the age of 15 years who violates §
130.22(A) shall be subject to a civil penalty of $50.
      (8)   Any minor who violates §
130.22(A) in a cemetery or other facility used to memorialize the dead shall be
subject to a civil penalty of $100.
      (9)   Any parent or guardian of a minor who violates §
130.22(B) shall be subject to a civil penalty of $50.
      (10)   Any person or entity who violates §§
130.22(C) or (D) shall be subject to a civil penalty of $50.
      (11)   For each violation of §
130.22 by any minor, parent or guardian of a minor, owner or operator of an
establishment, or any other person within 90 days of a previous violation, the
violator shall be subject to a civil penalty of $100.
   (E)   Any person violating the terms of this chapter shall pay the
appropriate penalty at the office of the City Clerk-Treasurer within 30 days
from the date of the citation. If the penalty is not paid within 30 days, the
Clerk-Treasurer shall refer the citation to the City Attorney for filing and
prosecution of the citation in a court of competent jurisdiction over ordinance
violations located in the county.
(Prior Code, § 130.99)
(Ord. 12-1931, passed 9-22-1931; Ord. 16-1931 passed 9-22-1931; Ord. 20-1931,
passed 9-22-1931; Ord. 71-1931, passed 9-22-1931; Ord. 6-1991, passed 8-13-
1991; Ord. 5-2000, passed 9-26-2000)
